content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ok, this sandbox game, THIS sandbox game, THIS SANDBOX GAME, right here, if you are in to SANDBOX GAMES, this is it for you! The developer is doing an insane job with updates, and he is truly building an outstanding sandbox game *with an awesome mix of campaign/strategy gameplay* that just blew my mind away. I play minecraft, terraria, starbound, space engineers, etc etc, and this one took me from all of them. Absolutely awesome game, great updates on a routine basis, open minded developer, great player community, and a fun and interactive experience to keep you looking forward to playing when you get off work huzzah!!! I highly HIGHLY recommend it, big time kudo's to the dev.*Adding notes* Mk so, reading my review, I realized it doesn't really, give a great review. It's just me being like, super excited because I love the game. So i'm gonna go for a more 'in depth' approach to some things i've come to love and the things i enjoy but, don't love....yet >.> First off, the pro's and cons.Pro's 1 Great building interface, with 2 ways to build, keyboard and mouse. Both of which have their own pros/cons. It also boasts a significant variety of blocks making every creation truly unique in it's own way. 2 Sub assembly system - Ever build something on something else, and wish you could take that something off the something else, and put it on something else? Well, in this, you can. Say you make a kick♥♥♥♥♥turret on one ship hull, but realize the hull just wasn't the right style, and couldn't hang. Well, damn, you don't want to rebuild that turret all over so, you make the hull work, right? Wrong, you can save subassemblies so that when you build more ships later you can add the same things to them w/out having to do all the work to recreate the things that work3 4 area's of combat *although space has been...interesting...follow up on that in the cons >.>* You can fight on land, sea, air, and yes, even space. 4 AI system for your creations to make your own fleet and evolving options to control the actions of your AI drones. I for example have my B-ship i control, with 4 fighters and a destroyer escort that are all AI controlled to escort my Big boat♥♥♥♥♥around. w00t w00t5 Open minded and honest hard working dev team. Now as of now, the only 'dev' i know of, is Mr. Nick Smart. But he has been ON IT. I mean, I participate in alot of early access games. And this is the only one where the dev is constantly in the forums, posting on others and publishing his own, on a frequent basis. He is constant with updates, and is truly doing a phenominal job trying to keep the game in the direction his vision has for it. 6 Campaign system - ok this will be my last pro, as I don't want to bore anyone Ok so, the campaign, has some ups and downs of it's own. Upsides - harvest multiple resource zones, have multiple fleets, multiple battle fronts, simple interface to navigate around your fleets, simple dipolomacy panel to♥♥♥♥♥♥peeps off or make them like you, Pretty good map layout, difficult AI once you get about 1/2 across the map. Overall the campaign, I luv it. I know there are some things in the works so i'm going to list them in the cons section BUT, big disclaimer, they are already on nicks workload and I can't wait to see what he hits us with when he starts evolving them. MK so, Cons. I'll be honest, not alot of huge game crippling things i have found. There are some nuisances but, the dev's actively working on them and, i'm not an impatient guy so, w00t w00t can't wait to see them fixed. Here they are1 MP (creative) is a little buggy. The host is the only one who tends to see all the action going on in the map. For example, if a cannon has a prediction piece on it, and you are the client, you won't be able to see the line drawn to show where your round will go. YOu also can't see the power, speed, drag, so on so forth. Now, do'nt get me wrong, the client can still do everything the host can, but the downside is, he won't SEE everything he's doing. Creative is basically no resource costs, on the campaign map, where you and all connected players can just, build.    MP (AI fight) is a neat concept, but it can be hard finding games up unless you have buddies who have the game to get on at the same time. Basically, you build a ship with an AI interface. You load it against someone elses, and you both watch the ships fight to the death, with no involvement from you. It's great to do to see how your creations stack up against other players. Neat little game mode.2 AI in campaign is, well, garbage >.> As in you can just flot over to a ship, SHOOT the AI mainframe, and walla you have a new ship. Now if you decide to not do that, it can get hard granted if you up the difficulty it does get pretty rough, BUT you have to have a high end machine to handle the big boys, and that means you may be annoyed with the scrub ships your stuck on depending on your gaming monster which takes me into 3 Frame rate can get pretty low when alot of stuff is going on. Another *disclaimer* is that nick is already working on moving to a different game engine, in order to improve this. But as of now, if you aren't sporting a hot rod, and your just cruising with a sedan, you may want to keep your block count a little low to keep from getting to choppy. 4 Getting to space *this might be restricted to just me* Now i have been having the hardest time getting a ship to leave orbit and actually get into space. The only way I have been able to get into space is to, well, build in space. I've been trying to build jets with ion thrusters that could leave the planet go to space and come back in, but i've had no success. Again, this could be a just me moment, but it shouldn't be that hard to leave orbit if you already have the engines to get you to max altitude in the first place. which rolls me into 5 the playable field, while awesome, is also kinda limited. Now it's cool because, you can really chew someone up and they can't get away from you b/c the deepest the water gets is like, 50 meters, and the air goes up as far as 500 meters, and your weapons can easily reach 1000 + meters. So, ya, they can't get away unless they just run, horizontally, str8 away from you. However, if your on the 'oh♥♥♥♥♥♥i gots to go' end of this, ya, it sucks. You have nothing going for you as the height/depth of the playable area is pretty small and therefore you have to just go for speed to run for your life. The last 2 cons, are the only ones on my list that I honestly don't know if the dev is working on, and to be honest, if he didn't change it, i wouldn't be heart broken. B/c yeah, it sucks to not be able to go higher or lower in order to increase my survivability, but it has led me to make more interesting designs with a little more armor to take those hits. And the space thing, meh, i can get over that, i'll just keep building in space. End of discussion Game review - Overall, i've been in 18 Early access games, and so far, this one and space engineers are the only 2 that truly paid off. This one is STILL in early access, but still is truly on point and moving forward at an amazing pace. Again, great dev, great gaming community, evolving game interface and AI systems make it a truly unique experience. Again, if you would like to play a sandbox game, and bring some idea's to the table, or just enjoy the game, this is a great pick. and hey, it'll be going in and out of sale frequently, so get it when it's cheap. I could easily see this game going for 40+ once it's finished. great game. If you happen to get it, by all means send me a message to do some building together, or to blow each other up, i'm always down for both!!

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								A great game I highly reccomend if you have time and patience. The game is still in alpha so expect some problems like somewhat poor graphics and a lot of lag during big battles. Although the developer is working on these. FTD is essentially a building game, mixed with an rts, and an fps. Because of this the game is immensely complex. The greatest complexity comes from the building process, which will take a lot of time to learn. You will need to learn to build hulls, ai's, cannons, missles, and engines. Each one of these has different rules that detirmine what parts can be connected to what section, and these rules will force you to make decisions about your ships design.  This will be espicially true when you play campaign where resources are limited. You can even use LUA scripting in the game to give your vehicles or missles custom behaviours.Because of the ability to build what you want, the rts like gamepley is pretty interesting. Like modern battles from the depths battles are often detirmined by range and the ability to gain intelligence on enemy movements is crucial to success. The ability to download units from the steam workshop also makes it possible to play the game without needing to design a ton of vehicles. If you've ever wanted to design your own weapons and take them into battle, then ftd is a great game for you. Just realize that this game gives you a ton of design options and a lot of the possible designs suck. This comes from the games balancing that usually forces you to choose between multiple factors especially how big your willing to go.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is hard, there is no denying that. The controls are clunky and awkward and DEFINITELY not suited for new players. But I love it.It took well over 20 attempts to get just a decent hull designed that A) floated and B) was stable, so new players please please do not give up when your first boat fails horribly. Slight tips: I found that bigger is usually better for air pumps, (most of my ships are capital sized battleships), and ships really don't have to look nice at the start, (I have a cube, that floats, it's epic).The building controls take a few hours to get used to BUT there is an option to use a more familiar, minecraft style system.This game is very good to teach yourself how to do stuff in it. I watched one tutorial for guns, gave myself a few hours, and could design them to specific characteristics rather quickly.NEVER go straight into the campaign, stick to the designer while you learn, turn waves off (in the settings) and build. It is very easy to zone out and find you built several warships without even thinking.There is something really satisfying about setting your best ship off into an enemy flotilla and watch it destroy every last one.Possibly the best thing I own to take me to nirvana.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								I absolutely adore this game and the sheer freedom of design it gives to the player. You can build practically anything. Realistic warships, flying castles, sea monster submarines, laser-spewing hovercraft, the list goes on for ages.With that said, it's not perfect. The controls are difficult to learn at best, with two options of a mouse-based control scheme that's easy to use but can make building difficult at times, and a keyboard-based scheme that is vastly superior to the mouse-based scheme for building, but much harder to learn and use. The learning curve is very harsh as well, considering just how much stuff there is to build with and how complex building effectively can get.Pros/Cons:Pros:-Allows an unreal degree of design freedom-Great fun once you get the hang of it-The build mode has a lot of useful features like mirroring and the ability to copy and paste subobjects (turrets/rotating parts).-Absurd skill ceiling, you will never stop learning clever tricks or new methods-Updates fairly frequently-Combat is hilariously destructive, in some cases with weapons blasting entire chunks of enemy vehicles off-Vehicles can be fitted with customizable AI that allow the ship to be controlled automaticallyCons:-Battles can cause massive drops in performance if the fight is big enough (huge vehicles/lots of vehicles).-Difficult to get the hang of.-Difficult, period. Enemy vehicles WILL give you trouble when you start out.Overall, it's a very good game and can be a lot of fun once you get the hang of it, but the difficulty and learning curve are pretty intense. Highly recommended for anyone that enjoys designing their own vehicles, as this game allows you to do precisely that.

number of helpful: 21 of 22 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ah yes, From the Depths, this is an interesting little sand box game that is hard to describe. Remember when you were a kid (or maybe right now?) and you would make spaceships and other stuff out of lego, and then have them fight? Well that is a very basic way to describe this game.Now lets just clear this out of the way, this game has a steep learning curve (some would describe it as a cliff), and the in game tutorials are not the greatest, however, the community, both on youtube and on the forums have some fairly comprehensive guides on the various aspects of the game.As for the gameplay, there are three main parts, you have the vehicle designer which in its basic form is a sandbox where you design and test your own vehicles and can spawn in any of the vehicles already in game. There is a basic "story mode", which mostly just acts as a simple tutorial as well as a set of challenge missions. Finally you have the campaigns; in the campaigns you put the vehicles that you have designed to the test in a quasi real time strategy game with resource and army management.In the main campaign you do battle against the various AI factions (8 in total) of the world of "Neter", these factions range from the ramshackle wooden designs of the Deep Water Guard, and their eternal foes, the Onyx Watch with their floating castles mixed with Age of Sail Galleons. In the Steel Striders you have more conventional warships that would be familiar to a World War Two buff alongside futuristic destroyers and battleships. For some truly unique designs, there are the "alien" Scarlet Dawn, and the tribal Grey Talons with their imposing airships. Of course the most unique in my opinion are the White Flayers, a group of religious fanatics whose ships seemed to have been designed in the wastelands of the Mad Max franchise.There are other worlds as well, including one meant for a World War II Axis vs Allies campaign.As for the vehicles that you can build, they come in a few different flavours; you can create a wide range of naval craft, along with helocopters (very complex to do however), airplanes, low orbit space craft, land vehicles, and if you are so inclined, you can also make stationary buildings.While the game is in Early Access, it is complete enough that you are only really limited by your imagination (and your ability to actually make said imagination work) as well the game recieves frequent updates. Of course, if you purchase the game, you do have to be prepared for updates that may change how the game plays, or messes with your carefully designed vehicles (the much needed engine rework was a good example of this). However, the games developer is pretty good at making it so that any changes are fairly backwards compatible so as to avoid completely breaking designs.So yeah, get out there, make a raft that can barely float, and then before you know it, you will find yourself conquering the world.*Edit* I forgot to mention that the controls in this game are awkward to get used to, standard WASD to move the camera/character, but the vehicle controls use other keys such as UJHK, which would probably make the game awkward for some people, particularly left handed individuals. However, the controls can be rebinded in the launcher, though I have not attempted to do so, as a result I am not sure how well the game responds to this.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game...oh this game. Where to begin?How about by getting something out of the way first: this is no Minecraft. It isn't download and just "get" it straight away, and the included tutorials...well they're tutorials, they get their job done. Point is, there's a learning curve to this game as others have mentioned, both in the construction of parts such as cannons, AI, and engines, then in the actual build process itself.It takes some getting used to when using tools that expedite construction to say the least.But then you get your first boat built and working in the creative mode. Maybe you rig it with the simple weapons. Maybe you make your own weapons. Maybe, just maybe, you start building the largest most fearsome ship possible and just pack that thing full of custom cannons that are essentially full bore autocannons, enough missiles to start and end a war with one of the game's factions, turreted lasers that burn aircraft out of the sky, and a gigantic slash elaborate drill system just to get the point across to your enemies: this is not a boat to be trifled with. Then you make more and more.Perhaps you go into the actual story missions. They have restrictions, parameters, quotas that can't be surpassed. You could just choose to use the resources ie ships given to you to complete them, or you could just make your own machines, using those same restrictions to guide how you cobble them together. Therefore you can complete them your own way, and with plenty of trial and error.Eventually; very quickly if you continue to just smash enemy story mission ships to smithereens; you unlock the campaign mode. Suddenly, all the wonderful ships you built and the machines you used to beat the story missions can become your very own personal fleet with a bit of time, AI, and some patience. Just as suddenly the game ceases to be some sort of "meet the objectives" shooter but rather an RTS where your units are those you've built yourself from the twisty maddening reaches of your own imagination. Now you're after efficiency: how can you, the admiral of your fleet, get ships built that are as cheap but effective as possible to mount an assault or defend against enemy fleets? So you continue to build. Upon which you realize that this has ceased to be a sandbox; it is now a "toybox." A vehicle simulator, shooter, real-time-strategy, and a huge heaping box of building blocks all mashed together to let you build your own naval and air-force warmachine. And best of all, it gives you most of the building pieces from the get-go. Criminy, if you're still a little iffy on getting From the Depths since it's on Early Access at least follow the confounded game!

Early Access Review
								This games pretty good.Positive things -+ You can build large ♥♥♥♥ off massive boats that fire cannons who's shells diameter is the size of someone who is like 7ft.+ Cannons have a limit, which stops people from making things 'too big' , for example the largest it can get is 200CM or 2000MM.+ It uses wave physics and has gravity act on every piece of the boat.+ You can make steampunk esque flying boats.+ You are able to build a hot air balloon.+ There are simple cannons, but also absurdly complicated ones.+ You need at least a basic knowledge of how physics works.+ You can make railguns that have amazing penetration power, however they eat through energy.+ You can make custom missiles and shells.+ This game is amazing with friends.+ You can make giant lasers. (As in ♥♥♥♥ing huge lasers.... kinda makes you want to scream "IMA FIREIN MA LAZOR" when you fire a quad barreled one or something).+ Lasers can set fire to things and melt through metal.+ You can make a plethroa of flying vehicles and seafaring vehicles.+ You can make aircraft carriers.+ You can build drones.Negative Points.- Steep learning curve.- More advanced cannons such as the railguns aren't explained correctly ingame.- Tutorials could do with visual guides as well.- Better UI and Controls as the current ones are slightly confusing.- Better rotating- Mirror mode needs to be better implemented- Physics end of the game needs to be slightly improved, as i made a boat that was perfectly symmetrical but it kept flipping even with a 'keel' i think its called to keep the bottom as the bottom. - Better descriptions on how to build sails along with cannons.- Servers sometimes wont let people join if your in the middle of a session, the host generally has to go back to the lobby.- Lags slightly badly even if you have a ping of like 30-40.- Thus far from what i've seen 'Repair tentacles' don't repair my ships. I don't understand the reasoning for this.Suggestion points~ Could do with flamethrowers or some form of incendiary weapony.~ Specialized weapons for outerspace, such as 'kinetic bombarment tools'~ Napalm warheads for things such as missiles and advanced cannons.//This might not be a fully accurate review due to me now having played a 'tutorial'.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								All was quiet on the southern Front. It had been days since we had seen any signs of the White Flayer scouts. Expecting attack, the Admirality ordered the construction of Anti Air defenses and deployed a small fleet to the area. In the waking hours of the morning, most of the men were either still asleep, with only the early warning radar operators awake. And thank God they were, for there actions that morning saved countless lives. It started with a strange radar signature, about two kilometers off the coast, moving incredibly fast. then two more. Then five. Then ten. It was an entire Flayer airwing, prepared for a swift victory against our motly defenses. The early warning station, against Admirality orders to only send a warning with visual contact, warned the entire coastal area that an attack was imminent. Thats where I come in. I was the lead engineer in charge of defending this area. Seeing that most of our defense towers were still being repaired, I scrapped together as many missile launchers and flak cannons as I could, but I was too late. one after another, the towers burst into flames as they were saturated with missile fire. We lost the battle, but bought enough time to evacuate the servicemen, who would live to fight another day.-Steel Striders engineer, in defense of the Southern Coal Plant.If you can't already tell, I love this game :)

number of helpful: 16 of 17 people (94%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pretty solid in its current state, promising future, dev actually interacts with community and the game was a functional and playable product when released on Early Access, which already makes it more likely to not get abandoned than 99% of games on here.That being said, if you want a more 'secure' project or a game that can be played for merits other than sandbox elements I'd wait a month or even several. There's a big update coming soonish to the 'main' gameplay mode, and a huge list of not-yet-implemented features at the current time.Gameplay wise. It uses a very well fleshed out sandbox building tool to design ships either on the fly or in advance that can be made or spawned into the various game modes. Eventually should feature a rather lengthy campaign that looks like it'll basically be a set of scenarios and goals, simple but entertaining, a Multiplayer campaign mode ("world domination" style gameplay with resource zones and stuff), and single battles pitting ships against eachother within a resource budget.Pros:-The building tools are amazing, actually including features like fill tools, mirroring both 'along a line' and between two blocks allowing both odd and even number symmetry. Saving and loading sub parts of vehicles (tad odd at this time), and a lot of other "Blatantly obvious" things that it's always annoying when sandbox games lack.-The game appears to have a fleshed out backstory and lore that the vehicles of the factions and the story missions are being created to match, and will likely feature a content rich and interesting game world in the end.-The aesthetics. The game's graphical style is quite nice, with wooden structures and vehicles appearing a tiny bit ramshackle but still sturdy, metal stuff solid and sleek in form but covered in weld lines and rivets, the avatars(player controlled characters) interesting and unique. All in all it reminds me of steampunk with a bit of a clunkier appearance that I think fits the general design of the game perfectly.Neutral:-The weapons, while satsifying and powerful, suffer from a bit of 'one best option' problems. For example cannons are best served as being stupidly long guns with obscene fire rates, without much reason to do things like a massive caliber slow firing gun as you could make it rapid fire for purely an additional resource cost. Meaning "Bigger is always better, faster firing is always better" with nearly no exceptions.-The physics engine for vehicles is a decent blend of realism and gameplay/CPU intensity concessions. Don't expect an accurate naval warfare simulator or realistic aerodynamics but it's definitely solid.-The combant. Sans current minor AI derpiness the combat is rather well done, with versatile weapon options for your vehicles, ammo and fuel management being things you need to take into account, and lots of information presented in nice visual and auditory manners that don't look out of place. (Shell tracers that indicate shell type, energy shields showing up in world, engines changing pitch by power drain, thrusters for fortresses and jets showing information about themselves by the color of their trails, etc)Cons:-The AI is a little clunky at present, does ok navigating and fighting solo but tends to ram allies repeatedly, make a beeline for stationary structures or sky forts and get caught on those, and the 'orders' system is as of this update not terribly useful or fleshed out, and results in even more of the above. Unfortunately, this is also a key feature of the game, and will almost be required for success in campaign after the coming update, so hopefully it's put in a better state in the next few updates.-Lacking in content, obviously, it's an Early Access game, but the core gameplay ideas are present and largely functional.-Multiplayer is in early testing this version, don't buy it for that, yet.-Current implementation of campaign mode maps is unwieldy and a little derpy in how it handles diplomacy, e.g. allies will 'capture' any territories you leave defended only by structures or empty, but you will still receive resources from your harvesting objects there. Next version this should change but we have limited info on that, so perhaps hold off if that bothers you.

number of helpful: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Challenging and very, very addictive. It's hard to believe this thing is still in Alpha. There are a few eccentricties that I hope get ironed out, but it's really hard to tell whether these things are user error or bugs (though I must admit I usually find through trial and error that they're my fault). The only complaint I have is very minor, and that is that certain objects cannot be inverted...this sometimes impacts the performance of my designs or at the very least detracts from their aesthetic appeal. I'm really splitting hairs there though...overall it's truly amazing.Now the learning curve is rather steep, but I've found that looking over some of the many designs available through the workshop as well as the included designs that you can get an idea of how to actually design things yourself. If you're unwilling to put the time in, though, you should just keep on browsing and find something else. It takes some thought, tweaking, and occasional reloading of previous designs (definitely save your builds often, if there's an undo button I haven't found it and find myself occasionally detaching entire portions of builds and can't bring them back) to get something really usable.However, the reward of watching your functional (if ugly, in my case) aircraft streaking across the sky and firing giant heat seeking missiles down onto a ship until the AI detaches the magnetic free fall bomblets all while continuing on to circle back around for another attack run...well...it's totally worth every agonizing hour of design work.Try it out...I mean it's already awesome and this early in development it can only get even better.

Early Access Review
								This is one of those rare games that come along that just makes you say wow.  Ive over 1700 games on Steam, even more since Ive been gaming all the way back to the 80's. This is one of those very very rare gems that just literally makes me go wow.  Technically pleasing and advanced enough to make me even want to spend endless hours using it. This will certainly be ONE of those games people talk about for years if not decades to come. When Minecraft came out it was a massive hit, this could very well be that next big thing. Its just way way to fun as it is, and I cant imagine how much more fun it will be when its done. By no means does that mean its not feature fun, it certainly is.  My mind just cant get wrapped around the idea that its still early access and has more content coming in.  Certainly more challenging than minecraft mind you, think minecraft with ubber tekkit and you have an idea whats involved here. Just mind numbing options available to a person to build, let alone fly, sail, drive it into battle and watch it fall apart. Now this is a classic in the making.

content:

Early Access Review
								This is one of those early access games that will have you coming back over and over again no matter what. Its fun, challenging in its own way, and in most cases, brutal. However thats my opinion.If I were to list the pro's and cons they'd be as follows:Pro's:- Potential for Epic Battles - Ability to build almost anything that maintains the games logic (Which means you can build a lot of stuff)- VERY ACTIVE DEV AND COMMUNITY- Very nice and helpful community- There is a steep learning curve, but that's what makes it fun- Large reserve of resources ingame as well as on Youtube to help learn the gameCon's:- If you dont have the patience or time to learn, the learning curve will seem more like a vertical wall than a curve.- The game is early access and you may want to wait for it to be leave alpha, however the content we have to work with currently is superb- If you can't handle losses, than you'll dislike the campaign as its inevitableEnding Notes: This game is pure awesomeness wrapped into a nice little package. This game is like Minecraft and Robocraft but taken to the next level.Sorry for the essay, but I needed to get my point across. 15/10 would buy again.

Early Access Review
								This is very well one of my favorite games on steam. It is not merely a vehicle designer, making a few ships, get bored, quit and then never play again. it has so many diffrent aspects, almost eveything is costomizable, and the sheer scale you can build ship and they will actually have the proper physics for large ships astounds me. i am a senior programmer with unity and i still have no clue how they fine tuned the physics and areodynamics in this game. But like i said before, it is not a mere vehicle designer, you can pit your designs against the nuilt in ones, or fight to the death with your friende or one of your own ships. and afteryou play around in the vehicle designer for a while, a campaign is unlocked. Putting a whole new flood of challenges to overcome. now instead of one on one ship battles, you fight your entire fleet against another entire fleet. this is the best game in my library, and thats saying a lot, i have 40+ games.   10/10

								>Buys From the Depths, having seen some of the gameplay.>Messes around in vehicle design mode.>Ends up spawning an enemy ship, whom promptly started to wreck my s***.>Restarts designer after saving vehicle.>Resumes work on said vehicle, CAPSLOCK'ing to hold it in place, starting to work on cannons.>Finds the custom cannons and starts making one after looking at short in-game tutorial.>Wants to make an artillery-like cannon, thus making the barrel twice as thick as my guy is tall, the barrel thrice as long as the whole f***ing tiny boat I got it on.>S***-eating grin the whole time, mind going rampant on the carnage it could possible do given the stats.>Spawns a Vanguard to test it out on.>Unfreezes the ship to try and aim the cannon at it.>Forgot about bouyancy and the weight of the cannon, ship sinks.>Forgot ammunition barrels to make sure the Really Really Big Gun could even fire.>Neglected to put said cannon on turret for me to actually aim it.>Enemy boat takes out the barrel then me after.>Flips table and restarts the designer, loads ship to prior the cannon.>Actually looks at tutorials on how to make a tub that won't sink.>Repeat this for over a month, getting better and better at ship designing.>Current project is a giant♥♥♥♥♥floating fortress of death.>Armed with lasers, underside cannons, and missile arrays to possibly take out fleets.>Has enough power to supply a small town, fuel for several airports, and can rip up supplies from the earth at a rate for a small army.>Grins evilly and spawns another Vanguard.>Weapons turn to fire at it, ripping the little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to shreds.>Missiles start flying, me thinking they were going to utterly decimate it.>Finds out that the missiles aren't even turning towards it, instead just flying up towards the sky.>Computer's taking a s*** in framerate due to the number of missiles that go flying.>Gets so bad that game ends up crashing.10/10 Would buy a better computer for this game!

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								I cant really describe this game as there is nothing like it so here are the pros and consPROS- once youve learnt how to build engines and cannons you can make some pretty awsome creations- plenty of blocks to build with (unlike comparable build systems which only have up to 2x2 slopes ect) so you can get more shaping- the most customisability from any game ive seen (you can change anything shell type, cannon size ect)CONS- The cannon and engine system can be difficult to understand at first as certain things work in certain ways- making stable ships and functional aircraft without them looking ugly is really hard to do - the "pid controller" (a little computer to help stability) is painful to set up as lots of un-noobfriendly jargon is usedoverally i would recommend this game if you like building stuff and customization but if your impatient with things and get annoyed when it doesnt work DONT BUY because you will just get frustrated at it and wont relax at all. However with that said if your favorite thing to do is sit down and build something for 2-3 hours then this game is amazing.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing, so customizable, and so many things to do. 200+ hours in and I'm still not even close to discovering the best methods for building things. And there are a lot of things to build. You want a giant battleship that can destroy every enemy that dares face it, you can do it. You want a small destroyer that unleashes hundreds of missiles? You can do that, too. Want a submarine that can launch planes? That's possible too. Want a battleship that flies? That's possible too. Just want to make a man's sausage that fires missiles? Well, you do you. You could also build a floating castle, spaceship, submarine-helicopter hybrid, flying tank, land battleship, fighter jet, bomber, helicopter, hovercraft, submarine-spaceship hybrid, ship with a giant saw on the front that cuts through other ships, kamikaze, ICBM, robotic person that shoots lasers, robotic chicken that shoots lasers, motorcycle, sports car, house, sailboat, galleon, the Black Pearl from Pirates of the Carribean or any other ship from that franchise, a flying galleon, a vertical take off plane, airship, galleon airship, scultpture of whatever person, creature, or thing you want, a paddlewheel steamship, ironclad, or even bumper car.I would say the sky's the limit, but it isn't. You do anything, and I mean anything. The list I made isn't even a full list, there are so many more things to build that I didn't write down, and the developer is STILL implementing now things. Speaking of the developer, he listens to what you have to say. If you go on the forum right now, I garuntee that there is a comment made by one of the developers. They listen, talk to you, give reasons why something is or isn't in the game. If they like an idea, they might even put it in the game. On top of all this, if you build a good quality ship on the workshop that you put a lot of effort in, there is a good chance the developers might put your ship in the game as an enemy faction. How cool would that be?TL;DR Great game, lots of stuff to build, developers listen to you.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Alright, FTD fans! This game is great for it's entertaiment and creativity value! In fact, it taught me my alphabets:A is for Andy, who bought with him a crystal pickaxe, clearly in the wrong game.B is for Beth, who'd bought this game in 2014 and still haven't even started the campaign.C is for Calvin, whose 7x5x3 boat keeps sinking everytime he attached his 20x15x10 CRAM cannon to it.D is for Donny, who for some unfathomable reason places all of his unprotected ammo barrels on the top deck, 'to keep the powder dry' he says.E is for Edward, whose ship keeps capsizing so much that he essentially says 'frak it' and rebuilds the entire hull out of glass.F is for Frank, who fears drowning and shuns submarines like the plague, complaining about there being too much water despite the fact that he's a robot.G is for Gail, who boards an enemy ship and proceeds to tear its insides out with her trusty grenade launcher, only to blow herself up when she stood too close to the ammo barrel she was attacking.H is for Harriet, who shoots the enemy robotic captain and captures a large ship it was piloting after spending hours searching for any mainframes she may've missed, only to get blown up by her own ship's missiles. I is for Ingrid, who wasn't being careful on the deck of her ship during a battle and got taken out by a well-placed shot.J is for Justin, who'd thought that rushing headlong into a paddlegun's field of fire with SMG blazing was both heroic and a good idea.K is for Kenny, who'd died many times trying to close the distance with a bastion using the starter boat just so that he can board and capture it. You b.a.s.t.a.r.d.s!L is for Leon, who fought with the Gray Talons like a lion but died like a cat who'd ran out of lives just because he didn't bring sufficent anti-air/air support.M is for Mark, who'd built his laser assembles all over the ship but forgot to add the transmitters.N is for Nancy, whose newest mystery case involves figuring out why her engines are burning through the fuel so fast...O is for Oscar, who resigns to his trashcan in frustration after taking a refinery explosion too many.P iz fo Peter, who wantz ta clobba fings togetha loike ah roight an proppa Ork but findz out why Ork techyology iz zo killy but unstable...Q is for Queen, whose confidence was immediately demoted to the level of her new name 'Peasant' after realizing that nobody in Neter respected royalty, especially royalty whose ships cannot survive an encounter with their weakest ships...R is for Rommel, who is not as intellectually endowed as his WW2 namesake and who, instead of building up his fleet or defenses like his namesake would, decided to wait for the Deepwater Guard's first ships to come, confident that his pistol will protect him. He'd fought and defeated sea vipers after all, so what's the worst that can happen? Needless to say, his bowel continence and life were not long for this world.S is for Samuel, who unlike his namesake in Life is Strange, actually died when his base got attacked by flying squirrels.T is for Terry, who built a ship that can launch hundreds of missiles but cannot figure out why they keep targetting his own ships.U is for Ursula, who foolishly attacked the Scarlet Dawn's spaceships with simple cannons and dropped bombs.V is for Victory, who then changed his name to 'Defeat' after sending wooden, unprotected planes against the Lightning Hoods.W is for Waldo, who everyone in multiplayer is looking for after making disrespectful trashtalk matched only by an inability to deliver.X is for Xavier, whose struggles in vain to read the minds of the ships coming at him like his X-Men namesake and who couldn't get away fast enough in his wheelchair to avoid the salvo when they got within range.Y is for Yale, who will have too many students not studying because they still trying to learn how to build ships and stuff.Z is for Zod, who built a huge, lag-producing fleet of spaceships with the intent of conquering Neter for the glory of Krypton but somehow forgot to add the weapon controllers to any of the ships.ABC's are fun! - 26 letters/10

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you enjoy building games like me, this game is gem in the rough.  It has similar vehicle design to Empyrion, but much more detailed.  Of all the building games I've tried (7 Days, ARK, Subnautica, Eden Star, Empyrion, Intersteller Rift, Space Engineers, Miscreated, WURM, etc ,etc.) the combat in this game is by far the best.  Submarines, surface ships, aircraft, spaceships, land vehicles and forts can all participate in the same battle.Pros:- Sky's the limit in design possibilities.- Lots of combat.- Repair bots function automatically.  No need to repair/replace damaged blocks by hand.- Thousands of designs on the Steam Workshop.Cons:- Some counter-intuitive physics at times.  (For example, ships use bouyancy rather than displacement)- Incredibly steep learning curve.- Maximum of 50,000 blocks per battle.- The UI is difficult to navigate and controls are somewhat clunky.

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Finally, Minecraft and pirate battles meet!If you have ever played games like Pixel Piracy and Guns of Icarus Online, you will probably agree that destroying ships while keeping your one operational, can be intense but also a heck of a lot of fun! I have always wondered if there was a title out there that gave you the freedom of creating a vessel that you could then use to challenge other ships.While there are some pirate battle simulators out there (Air Buccaneers and Guns of Icarus Online to name but a few), none of them allow you to fully customise your vessel through the process of building it from individual blocks (I suppose Pixel Piracy offers this, but it is 2D sadly and therefore limits your creativity substantially)!Even at early access level, I can see that this game has a lot to offer! I am excited to see what future updates bring. I strongly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys sandbox-build-and-destroy-simulator type games.

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Im going to start off by giving some advice to anyone thinking of picking this game up. First off, the learning curve is a slap in the face, if you start trying to play campaign/etc without looking up tutorials or guides you will not have a clue what your doing. The second is that this game is an early access game, its not finished yet and can be buggy, I personally have had instances where the game crashes mid battle or at the end of one. This hasn't occured very often but is annoying when it does. I therfore recommend saving before and after every battle just in case it does crash.After getting over the negatives of bugs/crashes and the insane learning curve i have to say that this game is absolutely amazing (when you know what your doing :P) The conctruction is really good, basically if you think of something in this game you can build it. Replicas of ww2 warships? yep, large bombers? yep, A death star orbiting the planet? yep. The battles are awsome, they allow you to slow down time, zoom over to your enemies and see the chunks being blown out of them by your ships weapons. In all this game is really really good but is a challenge to learn and can be buggy at times. If your willing to push through that then by all means pick this beauty up!

content:
Posted: April 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Written as of Release 1.947, 19 April, 2016.        This game is one I've been addicted to for months now. I may not have the hours to show it, as I play a fair amount offline, but the experience is definitely here. I'll have a quick summary. Would I recommend From The Depths to someone who is willing to learn and values gaining experience through trial and error? Yes. Would I recommend it to someone who just wants a simple game that's easy to get into and you can easily become a powerful god in? Absolutely not.        Well, why would I recommend this to the first type of people? Well, it's a hard game. I'm not going to lie. This game will slam your face in the ground many times. But the ones who learn from things like that will thrive off of what they learned from that. They'll get back up, dust themselves off, and fix the problem before heading back in. A fair amount of knowledge is useful in From The Depths. Simple physics, some mathematics, advanced problem solving, etc. But even people who don't know those can easily excel with the will to learn from mistakes. Your ship keeps flipping over? Well, time to make sure the center of mass sits lower in the vehicle. Basic problem solving can soothe the rage I see in others.        But what about the second group, Dim? As I said, it's a hard game. Not everything will just pop right up to you. I first started playing this before the new tutorial additions, and let me tell you, it was hard. 90% of what I know came from reverse engineering, experimentation, and watching others. But now there's a much better tutorial system that even helped me with some things. I can say if you instantly want to be a god at building things, this will never be the game for you. No amount of tutorials will ever make it so. You have to be able to not get frustrated at every little thing and be able to problem solve. It takes time.        Now some people complain about the "horrible" UI. Well, yes, it's extremely simple and definitely not pretty. But it gets the job done. There are a few things that I'd say are difficult to figure out, but once you get it, it's second nature. I will admittedly say the multiplayer is lackluster. It's originally what I got the game for, to play with friends. But now they're working on it. It's an Early Access game after all. There will be issues. There are quite a few other little issues, but everything is subject to change since I first typed this. No game is perfect. I will say the learning curve was rough, but the game must have some addictive drug in it after you get the hang of what to do.Pros:Amazing building capabilitiesSmart AI systems (usually)Infinite combinations of gun systemsHighly reactive physicsSuperb combat effects (shell impacts, pieces flying off, etc.)Amazingly rewarding for the ones who persistGreat graphics (for a Voxel game)Cons:Harsh learning curvePoor optimizationPoor multiplayerSmall glitches (shouldn't be much of a problem, however)Overall:8/10. Amazing game in my opinion, but it has flaws. Worth the buy for those willing to invest some time into it.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								*ahem**read imaging Morgan Freeman as the narator for full experience*Long ago, a young walrus laid in his bed watching Netflix late at night. He had loved customization in video games, so much so nothing quite solved his hunger for customization; not Grand Theft Auto Five, and even not DC: Universe Online. This creative young walrus envisioned a sandbox-survival where you could do more than slap 200 pre-build engines and cannons on a vehicle to make it good; a game where he could customize every aspect of everything in the whole fuzzing universe. Long since then, that poor little walrus gave up on that dream, realizing nobody would ever go the extra mile for such a game. But Brilliant Skies Ltd. proved little Willie walrus very wrong. They went the extra GIGAPARSEC (for those who  are NOT the largest nerd in ze world, zat is the largest unit of measurement, a.k.a. 3.6 billion light years). Little Wilhelm was ecstatic at this marvelous game. As fast as a tubby little walrus could run, he grabbed 20 bucks out of his wallet and sacrificed it for this marvel. But it was too good to be true right? NAY, NAY I DO SAY. Little Willie walrus discovered he didn't even know where to start when trying to POWER his vehicle with an engine. Willie could not even make a ship that drove correctly; he had to make a katamaran (3-platformed boat). But with the power of his friend YouTube, Wilhelm Walrus make a boat (given, it is not very good a fighting), and soon enough he joined the campaign to stick it to the Deepwater Guard (he still actually hasn't, but he is trying (:3=)).*nerdy white kid lispy voice*Now that I have told the story of little Willie Walrus, he shall list the pros and consPROS-This game has already improved its graphics form the older videos on the steam page.-Brilliant Skies has managed to find balance between content and bug-fixing updates, like ye old Space Engineers.-It never gets old, there is simply too much to do, too much to make, *deep-voiced black guy*too much love.-3 types of weapons is actually enough to play hundreds of hours, 3; that shows the complexity of this game.-You can make any type of vehicles, form fortesses, to mountainside artillery, to cars (i think, haven't expirimented), boats obviously, balloon-craft, helicopters, helicarriers, aircraft carriers, jets, propeller planes, space or air satellites, and maybe spacecraft, I haven't seen it one but I'm confident someone will.-Controls are intuitive once you learn them, but you better spend some time with 'em TO learn them.-There are 19 parts for missles. You can make any type of missle, even torpedoes or, uh, harpoon missiles...-Everything is balanced.-No bugs that ruin any experience.CONS-It can be a bit annoying just staring at your resources going up when you're saving up to spawn in your pimping new battlecruiser in campaign.-Campaign mode is a bit simple (at the moment at least)-LAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAG. And I have a ASUS G750 Republic of Gamers. So if you run your games in POTATO OS v. 6.7, I reccomend staying away till further notice.-I have been failed far too many times by early access (looking at you Starforge and Stranded Deep, and, well Stomping Land), however this looks very promising.-If you're a bit more casual, then look at that street sign over there, <Steep Learning Curve Ahead>All-in-all, 13.536 out of 5 stars. It is my new favorite Steam game. It beat Payday fudging 2. A must for people who like games they have to research, and btw a great place to learn is Lathrix's channel on Youtube, it helped a lot.*UPDATE* They have now added a 4th type of weapon, of course not counting simple weapons. They are complex cannons, and they are far more customizable with different mantlets and best of all custimizable projectiles (:3=)! They have also improved the texture for wood further, and it now looks like it could actually be used in more than a flimsy wee raft.*NOTE* As I said in my cons list, this game be not for the casuals. It is very hard, it can take hours to design a simple corvette, or a little raft with a gun. Some of the UI doesn't make this much better, just with the way it is presented seemingly randomly.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: You need to make a large time commitment and motivation to get anything done, but please read the entire review.Before you read this, this is a negative review because of the fact that while I would love this game, it has flaws that make it impractical for me.When first opening, there are no problems. The main GUI is simple to understand and easy to navigate, although grammatical errors appear every now and then. The main issues are with the steep learning curve and the fact that the tutorials don't really give you an idea of how to make a ship/airplane that fulfills all of the "requirements" that most set; It must be good looking, dangerous to the enemy, resource, fuel, and energy efficient, and have a practical purpose. It gives the building blocks, but lacks an explanation on how to put them together. I do understand, however, that games that "hold your hand" can quickly become annoying, but some early instruction would be nice.The learning curve is quite steep; it took me 10-15 hours to get a moderate grasp of most of the components and how they work. It can get frustrating when the tutorial doesn't explain the concept well enough for you to understand (the airplane ones were like this for me).Once past most of the tutorials, I hopped into designer, and, seeing people like Robbaz, Lathland, and Redstonize, I set about making a ship to beat them all! Then failed. One of the biggest challenges faced by the newcomers is the fact that you have to build your own ships from scratch, without any guides on the simple things like how to shape you hull and the best layout to organize things like ammo, engines, and mainframes, or a general idea of how much you'll need. IMPORTANT PART STARTINGThe time commitment is huge for From the Depths. It will take a considerable amount of time to build any decently performing ship. Battles can take a while, restocking and moving fleets takes time to learn and perform. All of your desings need prior thought to build; it is not a "sit-down-during-lunch-and-play-for-5-minutes-game." It will be easy (and almost required) to play for hours at a time, and for younger kids with "technology time" restrictions, it will be challenging. You will need to plan and plan and plan to make sure everything fits together nicely. Finallly, time for the gameplay. It is well put together, clean, pretty easy to understand, and gets harder as you progress. The killer: time. Yes, my biggest and (almost) only problem is time. If you have the time to spend, go for it. For the casual gamer, balancing a job, school, or time restraints placed by parents or schedules, this is problably no for you. If you have the motivation, then go for it, as the sucesses outweigh the troubles in the long run.IMPORTANT PART ENDED

number of helpful: 14 of 17 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's kinda like Minecraft and Kerbal Space Program had a baby which had all the ingrediants to fail horribly and fall into the pit of clone games that are all essentially "Minecraft with a slight twist", however the baby turned out to be the Mozart of block building games, even in alpha stages it is incredibly fun and rediculously engaging. During the campaign you can feel how innefective a one man army is so your first priority is to automate your ships, planes and fortresses and once that's done this game transforms from a complex block builder, to a full blown Real Time Strategy. It has no real constrictions to the way you play, you can build monstrous battleships that are almost unsinkable, hitting harder than a Sunday morning hangover, or squadrons of ultra nimble fighters that can outpace missiles and bullets with ease, though personally I go for edge of space motherships that rain down molten pain from a distance. The ability to craft a cannon piece by piece is something I've never encountered before, taking into account what kind of weapon would be appropriate for the craft you can fully customise the weapons capabilities from the range, to the accuracy, firerate, caliber and ammunition type, or opt for a laser or missile system with just as many options.Another wonderful thing about this game is the developer's 100% commitment, I've seen on the forums more than once, someone having an issue getting something to work correctly or encountering a bug of sorts and the developer promptly replying, first to appologise, then to explain how to make something work or to say that he will fix this in the next update, which he seems to always follow through with. The developer's liveliness in the community is reason enough to buy this game as he listens to suggestions and responds almost always saying that he will add this as a feature, or that it may damage the balance and it may possibly come as a feature in the future. With this in consideration it honestly feels like a game "by the people, for the people".10/10 would play forever

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								-Core flaw (of personal opinion): Very tiring and steep learning curve with the build interface, I would say thats its biggest flaw. Example: theres an 'align block with camera' button, but not a rotate button? Or if they do its very hidden, so again, deep (lol) learning curve. You can always find guides on youtube for ship building / button layout, etc. But for example: I purchased this game some time in 2015 and had a blast with it, trying to relearn the controls again after remembering the several sessions I spent trying to memorize things so it didn't take me an eternity to build the simplist of things really sort of just 'turned me off' again from playing, my feelings on its flaws aside and how they discouraged me from re-learning at the present moment aside!------------------------------------------It's a very 'deep' voxel based game, not quite as hands on as minecraft, you dont collect your resources by hand. The process is some thing of harvesting resources from visable fields in the ocean / using the remains of your enemies. The game does offer missions, multiplayer, a few different campaigns. If you lack ideas you can grab almost anything conceaved on the workshop, no one seems to be shy about sharing their vessels, terrible or not some times. The campaigns sort of turn into an RTS of sorts pretty quickly, as you manage AI fleets and build / repair / arm said vessels with autorepair parts once you can afford them / build repair AI vehicles / Add guns, missiles, torpedoes, etc. -Build anything from 'Space Ships' (I'm not sure if you could call it space, look into that if its a selling point to you*) to old timey galleys to submarines to helicopters to zeplin airships, Aircraft carriers, aircraft carrier subs, sub carrier subs, space ship carrier subs?- the sky is sort of the limit along with your imagination (hence the title) and it can seem a bit primitive, users have come up with some very creative content and shared in the workshop to help 'put wind in your sails' for creative ideas of your own.-Battles can become very exciting, and you can witness your dreams get ripped to shreds, luckily you can save blueprints of your works in progress pretty much any time you like before hand so yeah, you'll learn to save often. I would say having your creation fight other AI craft and win or lose can be quite satisfying and challanging especially at first. Combat can be done manually (manual turret aim, etc) or have AI do 50% - 100% (shoot, or shoot & drive) depending on how you've designed your ships, again because its a voxel game using odd blocks to represent ideas of ship componenets, there is a learning curve even on how AI works on a boat, unless its been changed you must add certain AI controller blocks to work with other AI blocks, its not quite as complicated as it sounds but does take a bit of reading and guide sloothing. That being said, because of its complexity with parts it will allow users to create very cool and unusual concept vehicles. -Bugs and crashing, it's at a minimal if any, and if memory serves me correct earlier versions were relitively bug and crash free, though again if I remember correctly from the peroid I played when I purchased, it did not include multiplayer of any sort less sharing vessels, so I cannot speak for the potential bugginess of the MP aspects of the game.DO I recommend this for you?:--------------------------------If you enjoy playing creator mode more so in minecraft for the end results of aesthetics or loved tekkit because of the layers of complexity from new blocks it added and how they worked together, and you can learn a 'new way of building' with some keys that almost seem to have purpose behind their strangeness after you remember/figure out why, then yes I do recommend this title to you, especially if you're a fan of naval combat. on the other hand if you're looking for some thing quick where the user simply plays the game more so then building ships in the ship / vehicle creator then you may not quite enjoy this title like I and others have, though like I've mentioned its vast armada of user created content avialable in the workshop allows you to download and plug into your campaign any vehicle of any purpose, refinary, rig, or what ever you might need at almost any time, but be weary you can't build GaryColeman68's USS Enterprise (with A-4, F-14, & AH-64) if you just start your campaign and have limited resources! So keep all that in mind, though at any time you could take said Enterprise into a combat simulator against JakeLongArm82's Space Drednaught (with submersive and sub-bay abilities) and see who's fleet 'keeps afloat', Both those examples of users content are totally made up, though lots of that stuff does exist.-------------Short & Sweet: It's a creative man's fleet builder and psuedo RTS, in no way is it a quick way to burn some time for fun though.

Early Access Review
								This game is so intensely fun, I can't believe it's not well known. It's definitely a gem in the rough of steam games. In my opinion, the very best, most addicting games out there are the ones that offer a wide expanse of creativity through building and customization. From the Depths is just that. I'm sure many people put most of their time into the campaign-like modes, but my favorite part of the game is the editor. You can create any ship, plane, flying-fortress, submarine - ANYTHING! You can pit your own creation against hundreds of developer-made creations, slowly perfecting each part of your vessel. There is a steep learning curve, but it is manageable with some patience, especially with the infinite possibilities that this game offers.

								This game is like battleship lego. You have pieces from engines to missiles to cannons all of which you make yourself. That being said, if you want a fun, creative, and mechanically deep game, this is the way to go.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've played for a little over ten hours now, and it's still faily confusing. I can build small vessels, make custom (Somewhat working) cannons and gun batterys, but large ships, planes, spaceships, or heck, engines? Not a chance. If you don't mind a confusing start (Or i'm overlooking something) this game is great. Taking part in a massive fleet battle, with aircraft carrying out bombing runs on enemy ships, or defending your flagship from airborne threat. Submarines sneaking in to sink enemy command vessels, cruisers firing missiles at the enemy, small attack boats dodging in and out launching torpedos, high altitude bombers obliterating enem coastal gun positions. You take a look around as a ship slowly capsizes and begins to sink, or another plows into a smaller enemy ship, snapping it in half, and you can't help but be impressed. At it's best this  game is just incredible, plain and simple. The basic buidling is essentially easy, but getting the balance right, and the finer points, like weapons, propulsion, and control (Rigging the thing up to an AI system) is complicated at best. This is well worth the twenty dollars, even for an early access game. I have yet to find something that even comes close to this. If you don't really want to part with that much money for it though, pick it up on sale. This truely is a great game. The graphics are fairly decent, the underwater scene could use some help, it's very barren, but the gameplay compensates for this. Who has time for scenerey when your jet powered submarine plane is racing along at high speed.  Bear in mind this game is EARLY ACCESS! As a result you will find bugs, problems, and other manner of in development game problems. But this game is coming along nicely, and I rarely encounter a bug. If you've got the money, and are a fan of naval combat pick up a copy (And one for a friend while you're at it.)

Posted: January 24
Early Access Review
								Edit, Day of Posting: I actually wrote this review about a week after the update that removed resources. Steam was glitching out at that point tho, and did not allow me to post the review at that time.From the Depths is an in-depth Naval Design/Constuction/RTS/FPS/Ship Capitan game. The game has 3 gamemodes as of current: the Campaigns consists of building physics-reactive ships/planes/tanks/structures in which to combat other ships/planes/tanks/structures for resources in an RTS manner. Adventure Mode has you build a ship under pressue of encroaching enemies, and forgoes most of the RTS elements for a more centralized capitaning of your craft. And in Creative you can play around with unlimited resources to create whatever you desire, the sky is not the limit. For those concerned about the difficulty curve, while it is extremely steep, once you get about 3/4's up it becomes seccond nature, and a very enjoyable.And overall, I would recommend this game in every respect, if it were not for the most recent update (v1.9587 as of writing).Before the update, there were 5 resources: Natural (For wood and so on), Metal, Scrap, Oil, and Crystal (Catch all for exotic materials: nuclear power, computer components, etc). A 6'th if you count Energy/Power from engines and RTGs.In the most recent update, this was reduced to 2 ("it makes the game far more streamlined, balanced and understandable." - The Dev), and that is Materials (Power is unchanged from before the update).I am going to give my oppinion from here on in this review: I am not in support for this change. I feel this removes a large chunck of the depth from the game, just slap a bunch of gatherers and storage on a ship and you will get everything you need without need to know what resources you needed. (This specific example is much less relevant than I make it out to be, I just wanted to got it off my chest. Edit: I have described a similar version of this issue in an edit at the botom of the review.)I am going to give 2 examples on how this is a bad decision, one an in-game example, the other an analogy to other games.EX1: Say you fight a very strong force of DWG ships, DWG builds with primarily wood. You capture a few of these ships and scrap them, now you can make a decently sized metal ship that can tear through other forces 3-5 times its represented power level. How is this balanced? Or realistic at all? Unless I have some sort of fusion mass converter (Lore-wise I do not know if these objects exist), I cannot turn a bunch of pine logs into a full fledge AI system and a pulse-laser to match, all on a steel hull.EX2: Say I take Path of Exile, a game with no universal currency (Gold coins, ect) but I must buy things with tiered items in a barter system. Say I remove the whole tiered-item currency system and replace it with basic gold coins for the sake of "Streamlining". If you play PoE, this would infuriate you to no end, you would probably quit! (I would)Well guess how I feel.Albeit I haven't played the game in a little while, I still liked the concept and execution, and wished to support the project. I cannot do that now as I fundamentally dissagree with where the dev is taking this game, and under these curcumstances cannot recomend anyone spend money on this game. That does not dictate what YOU do tho. If you can tolerate, or even like, the new resource system go right ahead and buy the game.TL;DR: Game is good, the dev oversimplied resource mechanics for the sake of "Streamlining and Balance."Edit: @spudcosmicI already have my examples and reasons why I dislike it. It does not have "zero impact on the game". I guess another way to put it, is that it removes a major game-time based balance mechanic. With the extra resources, you had to make ships of similar power to that of your enemy, because you had similar resource amounts and types compared to them. They removed that, and in turn it removed that barrier, allowing the construction of overpowered ships before even wiping out the DWG. I also feel that it forced players to expand more than the new system. Unless you are going to live off of the single all-infinite-resourcezone, you have to find other resouce zones, many of which have varied amounts of specific resources. You could find a place that had a great deal of metal or natural, but nothing else. Now it's just pure quantity, no need to find zones that have the specific resource you need. To an extent, it also defeats the purpose of the centralized resource system, making it to where there are no specific resources that you would need to haul across the map.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								There is something oddly compelling about this game....Despite the fact that I have died time and time again in the Adventure mode, and despite the fact that the game has an extremely steep learning curve (though, if you have played Minecraft Mods like Buildcraft, it's not really as bad as it appears on the surface), this is a surprisingly engaging game, possibly because of the promise of what you CAN do if you persevere.Like Dwarf Fortress, losing is 'fun', and each iteration takes you slightly nearer to survival as you learn your way through the components you are using, your knowledge of how to assemble and use the equipment available is the key to your survival.Looks-wise the game is reminiscent of games like Minecraft or Starmade, the GUI is basic, and can be fiddly at times, it works ok, but probably needs (and will probably get) a polish in the future.There ARE glitches, the AI can have the occasional strange mood, and I can understand how the level of complexity can be offputting, engines are easy, but some of the weapon stuff is pretty complex, I've yet to manage a working anti-missile laser, but I'll get there. If you're the sort of person who doesn't mind losing frequently, and who doesn't mind having a wiki open in their browser whilst playing, this is a fun, challenging game with a massive amount of scope. Even the tutorials try to kill you and you know what? That's oddly refreshing.

Early Access Review
								it's really good in a very kerbal kinda way!for starters i will say i dont think this game will ever be done, which will♥♥♥♥♥♥some people off but ya gotta understand what its going for. this game is basicly a sandbox wherein you build vehicls and mash them against other vehicles to see which one would win in  a fight. there really is no "complete" version of this game since it doesnt really have an end goalthe graphics are really sub par as well as about every singe art asset in the game from menus to blocks to textures so in that sense dont expect much but what it lacks in visual beauty it makes up for in sheer mechanical depth. the player can design not only the hulls of the ships but also every missile to bullet thats fired and even the weaponry themselves, adding extra barrels or autoloaders to custom cannons and extra missile/torpedos that are uinque to your ships.the player can also design custom AI scripts for combat and movement or specialised rotation blocks to build at odd angles, you can build gunships with AI designed to hover and circle around the enemy, you can build kamakaze vehicles to ram head first and decimate a target, you can build aircraft carriors with sub-vehicles like planes that take off from the runway, you can build working tanks, airships, spaceships and jets. the possibilities are endless!if you want to spend 30 hours not knowing what your doing but having as much fun as a kid with their legos, buy it. If your looking for a standerd minecraft style survival expiriance or a far cry esqe open world adventure then you might wanna try annother game ;3

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've watched hours of videos on how to play this game before I bought it so don't let the hours I have in it at the moment deceive you. So far this is the best game I've played in years, Honestly my entire life I've looked for a game with such an easily customizable AI system that's still super in-depth as this one.Don't get me wrong, however. This game is NOT easy. The controls aren't easy, the mechanics aren't easy, and even the battles aren't easy. This game is more than just a challenge for your reaction skills though. This game is a challenge for your brain. Coming up with new and innovative ways to use the mechanics to make amazing creations for either looks or potency is what is, has, and will always be what separates this game from the others. This game is Minecraft on steroids. If you enjoy being able to build legos with computers that you can program to do pretty much whatever you want, then this game is for you. I would highly recommend even though there is one glaring issue I will address down below.I'll cut the developer some slack and let any bugs slide for now since it is after all an alpha. The one thing I do have slight issue with however is the framerate. My pc is more than capable of running most games and in smaller engagements I lose slim to no fps. However in the larger battles and even the benchmark it goes and stays around 10-12 fps on the lowest settings. I sincerely hope the dev will have some sort of breakthrough in the code to get more performance out of the larger battles because that's the only thorn in the side of this game right now.Other than that, I would recommend this to only the more intelligent of my friends. Not to insult anyone's intelligence but unless you're smarter than the average gamer, this game will get on your nerves quickly with all of the mechanics it has available. It can easily overwhelm a newbie or a more casual gamer so take caution, this game is not for the faint of mind.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								I didn't know i wanted this game, until i got it. From The Depths is a game about both creativity and efficiency. In order to vanquish your enemies you must build up an automated army of ships and flying vehicles that can fufill it's job as efficiantly as possible. making a wodden boat with a big cannon on the front you let you get by... for a little while, but eventually your opponents will start making truly fearsome vessels, at wich point you must start thinking outside the box and approach things in different ways. I could spend litteraly days in the vehicle designer, testing designs, optimising older ones and then pitting them against enemies to see how they perform, so that i can see what i did well and what needs improving. The concept of FTD is what makes this a worthy investment, but you may want to purchase it later on. As is the way of early access games, there are things that are planned, but not in the game yet. Indeed there are quite a few missing features as of writing. There are also performance problems, mainly when huge battles take place, the game can slow to a crawl. The way I see it, if you're gonna buy one early access game, this is a great choise. I guarantee, if you like the sound of the concept alone, then you will find it worth your time. I wholehartedly reccommend this one.

								As you can see, I have a good amount of time spent in this game. It's not every day that you can get that many hours of entertainment for the price of a large pizza. It's not even finished yet, and there is already plenty to enjoy.PROS:Extremely impressive for an alpha build, despite having a very small dev team.Very good community interaction.Virtually all aspects of the game under constant improvement.Already has a functional single player campaign and skirmish missions, dedicated build mode, and multiplayer cooperative construction.Mod support being implemented.Multiple custom campaigns made by the community.World creation with customizable gravity, air density, water buoyancy, space altitude, etc.All built-in vehicles and structures can be examined in build mode to see how they work.Active forum community willing and able to answer questions and help players.Developers active on forums.CONS:Not a finished game yet.Performance slowdowns in some situations.Many game systems still being adjusted, not fully balanced yet.Learning curve can be steep for beginners.
