content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								About:This game is a sandbox based around water and Aerial fights. Just for being in Pre-Alpha there is an insane amount of content in this, one of my favorite aspects is the custonizable weapons, (custom cannons and missiles). All you can do in this game so far is a few story missions and a campaign where you conquer the map while building better and better ships along the way. Infact, you dont have to build each ship block by block, you can make ships in the editor and save them, then make them in the campaign so long as you have resources for it.Creativity:This game relies heavily on your own creativity. The better you can imagine something, the better you can make it in-game. Not trying to turn people away here, because there is the workshop where you can look for inspiration for your own creations.Difficulty:This game can be very challenging when you first start as you can not just build a little raft with a cannon twice the size of the raft and expect it to float (it will sink like a rock, trust me i tried). once you get where you can build the bigger and better stuff later in campaign the bigger and better your ships can/have to be as the AI has better and better ships as you progress.Performance:I run an okay rig with about 6GB of ram and this game runs nicely, so long as you dont have anything open in the background. With me only having 6GB of RAM it takes almost all when you get into a battle with ships that fire ~4 shells a second. Other than that one small problem It runs nicely.

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you ever built tanks and planes and spaceships with your Legos when you were a kid and made them fight each other, boy have I got a game for you.First off, keep in mind that this game is in alpha, which means bugs happen, performance isn't the best, lots of stuff is placeholder and things change constantly.That being said, From The Depths already has more content and replayability than 90 percent of fully developed and released titles out there, including triple-A releases by big developers.  This game is under constant, aggressive development; gameplay systems, build components, and game balance are actively being added, expanded, and improved.  There's typically at least one game update a month, sometimes more, the lead developer is very accessible, and the dev team is largely drawn from the community and is highly active with updates and feedback on the game's website forums.That's great and all, but how does it play?  Frankly, I've never been a big fan of sandbox building games like Minecraft or KSP or Besiege, but From The Depths has sucked me in like no other game ever has.  The learning curve is steep, but once you've absorbed how components and systems work you'll find that you can build nearly anything you can imagine: ships, planes, helicopters, dirigibles, tanks, submarines, spaceships, satellites, hovercraft, drones, fortresses, buildings, even mechs (well, sort of, vehicles interact weirdly with solid ground and you can't really make functional legs).  Then, you can weaponize all these these vehicles, equip them with custom AI, and drop them into a real-time strategy campaign to test out against a huge variety of community-built enemy factions.  You can even make your own campaigns on your own planets.  There is literally no end to the gameplay From The Depths offers, and it's only becoming more detailed and interesting as development progresses.I've already sunk hundreds of hours into this game.  I can't recommend From The Depths highly enough.  It's the Lego set you always dreamed of having.

content:

Early Access Review
								好像不太有中国玩家玩这款游戏，但还是想分享一下自己的感受。首先这绝对是一个由纯理科生制作出来的游戏，美工和UI的水平和一般得到“特别好评”的独立游戏完全不在一个级别。交互的反人类（复杂的载具切换 武器系统很难展现出打击的快感 舰只与飞行器操作的不方便 复杂的建造系统 难看的UI等等）很明显的说名了这一点。可如果只是这样的话我也就不会在这推荐这款游戏了这本是我steam队列里的推荐，应该是给予我对沙盒游戏的爱好。From the Depths 是一直很想要的终极沙盒（当然你可以说还有 No Man's Sky，可惜人家现在还不支持多人，而且建造元素没有这么强），上天入地什么的毕竟是一个很吸引人的IP。整个游戏应该需要一个探索的过程，由于两个教学视频好像都在 U土鳖 上所以可以挂个VPN什么的看一下。包括对英语基础也会有一定的需求，毕竟菜单选项是密密麻麻的。OK以上是对玩家的建议------------------------------华丽丽的分界线-----------------------------For developersI strongly appraciate the core of this game. Its high felixability feature is the thing that most attracts me. But it is not perfect, not yet, at least.There are some minor problems that you guys could try to dealing with:1. User interface: The current UI is not quite friendly to be honest, the construction mode is to complicated and unconvinient for building such a large scale structure such as the bettle ship. Warping from one vehicle to another is not smooth enough. Also, the UI should looks better.2. Better art design required: The texture and the shapes of different component is not yet satisfying. Is that possible to add some better visual effects in later update?That's basicly all the information I want to imply. From the Depth is definitly a fantastic game and you are all doing a great job!

								This is essentially the greatest engineering game ever made. content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								:TLDR - Excellent physics based battle block building game, where the sky is the limit as well as the depths of the ocean. Custom made weaponry from lasers and missiles to flack cannons and gatling turrets. Hours of fun and updates enough to keep it fresh. Needs polish but we can wait for that :)I have played from the Depths for quite some time now, and the one thing i will say is that the learning curve is quite steep. The sub menes and construction UI may dazzle your eyes at first, but after a few hours (took me about 4)  you will be well on your way to making AI controled ships planes and even space craft.The main fun in this game for most people (and i guess the main draw) is that the game has very few limits on what you can actually do with your creations. Want to make a submarine that can surfance and then fly ? well its entierly possible in this game as long as you know how to do it, and there in lies a problem. As the games in game manuals really dont go into enough detail on exactly how they work. After time though you will just learn these things with experimenting. Its the same with missiles - you can make so many different types - torpedos, flak, anti missile missiles flares mines  you name it you can probably make it, but the manuals dont really tell you how - only how to construct the actual functioning weapon system. The games does use LUA programing how ever and these blocks can be placed to run custom scripts and AI  on your ships, which is nice.The other main draw of this will be ofcourse - the Co-Op Campaign which is just alot of fun from the get go as all players can work on the smae construction - making some truely massive flasg ships and world destroying craft. In the campaign the AI will attack you quite regulary so its essential to protect your resourse gathering areas, how you ask ? well he is another cool feture of the game - your not just able to build ships - but you can also build structures and floating fortresses  that while are not mobile - will be able to carry the biggest and heavyist weapons you can dream of with out you haveing to worry about the physics affect that such things would have on ships.All in all - for the price - you really can not go wrong !10/10 would build massive world destroying flying ships again.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								(This is an Early Access game, review written on 4/8/16)From the Depths is an engineering game where you construct naval ships, aircraft, subs, and structures to shoot at and conquer other ships, aircraft, subs, and structures.  This is done mostly in first-person although there are map overview RTS aspects as well.From the Depths has a lot of, well, depth to its building.  Every aspect of your air/water craft is constructed of essentially minecraft blocks.  Even fuctional aspects, like the engines or weaponry, are contructed of special blocks.  There are several weapon types to build, including two types of naval cannon, missiles and torpedoes, and even lasers, each with relative checks and balances.  There is a ton of customization when it comes to building your fleet, but there is also a big learning curve.  I feel this curve is not insurmountable though.There is a strategic campaign where you fight and defeat 8 unique factions for world domination or something.  The forces featured are largely designed by the community.  The campaign can be fairly challenging for a newer player, but it can get very unbalanced later on, as you get an over abundance of resources.While Early Access titles are typically very dubious in value, I find From the Depths trustworthy.  The dev is fairly active on the official forums, and often informs us on what he is working on.  I've owned this game for about six months, and multiple major updates with big features have been released.Overall, From the Depths is a complex but nonetheless fun and intriguing game in the build-stuff-out-of-blocks genre.

content:
Posted: February 14
Early Access Review
								One of the most rewarding, yet most complicated games I have ever played.PROS:-The game itself is very complex, yet not so much as to bar entry. It directly influences the reward from building right.-The "Tiering" is very extensive. 7 factions, each with ship in 4 subtiers of quality. Add in that speciffic builds can directly couunter other builds that would otherwise be universally strong, and you end up having a reason to build a varied fleet.-Due to both prior reasons, along with general immersion, gameplay time on this title is quite long.-A unique take on sandbox building. Despite a surface level similarity to Empyrion: Galactic Survival, it is entirely a new spin on these types of building games, derived mostly from it's complexity. You can't just slap thrusters on a box and use it. You have to plan ahead, and quite often make last moment modifications. The first game I have seen to ACTUALLY offer building that rewarded smart thinking more than abusing exploits.-The RTS feel is actually quite nice when you finally get some footing in your compaign.CONS-The interface is harder to learn than the game itself. After building a few successful models, even managing to 1v1 most of the godly enemy ships, I looked back and realized I had spent about half of my entire playtime learning to navigate the GUI. I feel that a more thorough tutorial is required on all the unlisted keybinds, menus and functions, and that this would remove a very large barrier to new player immersion.SUMMARY: -One of the best and most addicting games I have played in the past few years.-Satisfying, complex, and yet STILL open to casual players who play only a little each day.-The interface is extensively unintuituve, and thus I advise you to check YouTube or twitch for any tips on hidden screens you didn't know existed. The only significant suggestion I could give to add to the game's experience. I state this as a warning, not as a reason not to buy. It can be learned, but you will be far more pleased if you take the time to figure it out before trying to play as usual.-It is very fun to spend hours in Designer because you got your butt kicked trying to design a new ship.. Then go back to campaign and just steamroll everything in sight. It makes you feel like you learned something and it shows in volumes how much it mattered.

Early Access Review
								Well, where to start.This is a brilliant little Indie game!  Extremely tactical and strategic on a grand scale.It is really satisfying spending hours creating the perfect Submarine/Ship/Airplane/Spaceship and then either controlling it yourself or watching it dominate the competition or fail miserably because of a weakness that you overlooked :)Incoming Features planned by Nick Smart, the head dev:Coop Campaign and coop in general!Even more costomisable weapons, like Rail Cannons!Even more simple non-customisable weapons!Nuclear Reactors!Many more listed here:http://www.fromthedepthsgame.com/forum/index.phpThings already included in the game and which I enjoy very much..some of these are still work in progress and are marked clearly ingame as such.  The things listed below though are functional and enjoyable :)Customisable engines...electric and diesel!Resource gatheringCharacter Development (Stats, Items, Self Buffs, Fleet Buffs)Customisable Cannons, Lasers, Missiles, Torpedos, Ships, Aircraft, Submarines, Spaceships, Ballons and Blimps!Proper physics...build your boat fully out of metal..its gonna sink!  Lose an important chunk of your aircraft during a fight, it will drop like a stone!  Unless of course your creation is a homing Kamikaze flying bomb, then you want it to do that!Anyway, so sum it all up, if you like creating, destroying, imagining or copying, this is your game!I hope you enjoy this gem of a game as much as I do.

number of helpful: 33 of 56 people (59%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 21
Early Access Review
								From The Depths is a voxel based, naval sandbox game where you construct ships, airships, and all sorts of other craft in order to defeat various campaign factions.Pros:Near unlimited amounts of freedom in creating player made designs(Mostly) Friendly and active community on the official forums, though is no stranger to petty infighting between membersCan be fun to play if you ignore all the broken and/or unfinished mechanicsCons:Has been in alpha since mid 2014Has not been updated with mechanic changes/additions since November 9, 2016 due to the developer having moved on to a "spinoff" (AKA: FTD redo). It is currently unknown if he will return to this game or if said spinoff will even be finished.Steep as hell learning curve, and increasing with every new added featureDeveloper tends to start work on game mechanics and then leave them imbalanced. This leads to very blatantly abysmal game balance. (One example is the fact that thrustercraft/airships are superior to similarly sized surface ships simply due to not touching the ocean, being guaranteed to be faster moving, and being invulnurable to torpedos. In some cases it is almost easier to construct airships than surface ships. This has been an issue for almost as long as the game has been in development yet nothing has been done to correct this.)Mediocre performance/optimization (lower end systems will struggle to render multiple higher block count ships at once at a decent framerate. Even higher end systems will see steep performance dips with several projectiles in the air at one time)Very imbalanced main campaign. Severe "unit-bloat" due to it's difficulty settings relying on having 4 different ships (one for each difficulty setting) that do nearly the exact same thing to varying degrees of efficiency. Several "half-baked" mechanics such as a half functioning mod creator/editor, world editor, half of the "Advanced Projectile System" shell modules/types, etc.Developer has promised to add several systems to the game (IE: Plasma weaponry, fire, nuclear engines) and only implemented some. (Advanced Cannons, Steam engines)TLDR; Fun game, ruined by developer incompetance. Only buy this if you're okay with an unfinished, abandoned, but still mildly fun game

Early Access Review
								Game:Build your own units block by block, customize their weapons, create fleets, romp around the map and kill other custom ships. Cannons, lasers, missiles, mines, torpedoes, missiles that turn into torpedos or mines, big warheads, small warheads, lots of warheads, guided, shrapnel, unguided...Have fun watching your custom build ship or jet or spaceship or sattelite or weird ballon-laser-missile battery munch through their targets, weep as you recognize critical flaws in your desings as they crumble and get destroyed. Watch your first iron hulled ship drop right down to the ocean floor, be happy when your first iron hulled jet-rockethelicopter thing takes to the skies, immediately fails to shoot someone but still wins because it hit and killed the enemy when it crashed down to earth after getting shot....From the depths is great fun, its a strategy game where you build your own units, block by block and then conquer the map with them. Look at the workshop to see what we predictable lot have already build.Game state:No severe crashbugs or gamebreaking gamebugs in the gameworld have been observed by me in my time of playing, which began at around mid september.I rate the game as stable and the gamepaly is already functional (construct your ships, build them  in campaign, wipe the map clean of filth colored differently than you.). Dev:The Developer has no negative trackrecord to my knowledge, the game is getting updates.Dev is active in both the steam forum as well as his own.I sincerely recommend this game.

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Congratulations. You've successfully descended into the world of niche titles. Unlike most others from this category, this is an amazing game. Buy it now.Not enough juicy, succulent review meat for your tastes? Then let me lead for you.This game is unlike anything I've ever seen before. Seriously, the team of two devs (I think there are only two, they're the only two I've heard about) is a wonder duo, one specializing in PR (Her name is Elizabeth, she gave me this game free!) and one for the game (Nick, he updates his game almost daily!). The game focuses (obviously) on the construction (and following demolition) of massive...whatever-you-wants, basically. You can make trains, planes, ships, spaceships(!), orbital cannons, you name it. You can even do stuff like  this . You really don't have a set goal, the play style reminds me somewhat of Minecraft. The game can fit to your personal fetishes, in my case spaceships. You're probably saying "Meh'" and moving on. Wait! You haven't even seen the best part.  You can completely customize your systems, including but not limited to: AI Mainframes (autotargeting and performing of customized if/then statements), Engines (focusing on either insane fuel-gulping power or fuel conservation, or a balance), Cannons (you can change ammo types, barrel  length  for increased accuracy, determine whether it's a one shot explosion or an 18 shot salvo), shields (whether focusing on a wide area with weaker deflecting, or a smaller shield capable of deflecting the strongest explosions), and even targeting system priority (for AI mainframe). Nick says he's soon gonna implement something From the Depths players have been waiting eagerly for a long time: Sea Monsters. This inspired the name of this game: From the Depths (just think here for a second)! Imagine battles like this but instead of fighting massive battleships, we will fight sea monsters! As of right now, this game is mainly focused on single player. Multiplayer exists but only comprises of simulating a battle between two ships, you can't control it (but that IS planned). Suprisingly, there actually is a campaign, but I haven't experimented with that yet. I only have minor qualms about this game-NUMBER ONE ON MY LIST IS THAT JETPACK. Seriously, that jetpack. Many times have I tried to keep up with one of my creations before it takes off, but stopped an  inch before I got to the ledge because of that jetpack. Could we at least get a noclip? Another thing: we need to be able to move a group of blocks (regardless if it's our creation or not). Last thing: we need MOAR documentation for the engines, AI, and other systems. I still haven't mastered them.Overall, this is a fantastic game. I highly recommend this to all of my friends, and to all you guys out there. Please give this adorable little game a chance in the big mean world of Steam. I wish the best to all you guys out there that play this game and to the Little Dev Team that made this little slice of history.Stay frosty, y'all.10/10

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Absolutley flawless, and its even still in early access with this level of polish! A solid game here even in this stage of development, fun mechanics, easy to learn design system, resource based consructions and real time damage on a block by block basis. Careful and clever design is key to making a solid ship/sub/plane/spaceship, build your ammo storage with too little armour and you'll get a spectacular explosion if you're hit in that area. You can customise missiles to be armour piercing to punch through like a needle or use high explosive to cause damage over a wide area, or even somewhere inbetween. You can make custom cannon turrets too, want dozens of tiny barrels firing like a shotgun or a mammoth cannon that takes 2 whole minutes to reload? Why not build 2 mammoth cannons bolted together?!This is one of the best games i've played in a while, and new features, tweaks and mechanics are in the works making this a title that just keeps delivering.Solid 9.75/10!!!!

content:

Early Access Review
								I honestly have to say.Like Minecrafft? Always wanted your boat to have guns? Wanted guns in Minecraft? This game is for you.Pros- This game is absolutely amazing, the amount fo customization for Early Access imrepssed me and hooked me, and the water and ship graphics are very pretty- You "feel" the power in your weapons when the destroy an enemy ship or aircraft.-The single player campaign is very fun, you get to take on  diverse factions. I've spent about 60 hours in one and finally took out the first one.- The AI layouts and LUA scripting do a good portion of the work for you in many aspects once you get them down. ( Isn't smart enough for LUA scripting, so that's still getting figured out. )- The guns? The "cannons"? You have your way with them and you can create an EIGHT BARREL CANNON, and just obliterate enemies with those.- The missles are hugely customizable, just add lots of missle blocks and you got some serious firepower there.- The engines, while complex, 'sound' like they give you lots of power. You'll get the hang of it quickly, take a look at the example in the Prefab section, and you got it.- Haven't even "touched" the multiplayer, but I've heard nothign but good things, while buggy, works fine and there's CO-OP. WHO DOESN'T LIIKE CO-OP DESTRUCTION? (This is Early Access, so of course it's gonna have bugs, so duuuuuh.)Cons- It's early access. This is an Early Access game. This is buggy, it's getting worked on. Don't like it? Go blow up stuff in another game.- It does slow down when you have lots of blocks, so you'll need a decent computer.- Does tend to crash a lot. ( IT'S EARLY ACCESS, THIS IS NOT SURPRISING )- Does tend to freeze here and there when loading a crap ton of blocks. ( Like my massive warship of over 30,000 blocks and it's 5 fighter jets of about 15,000 blocks altogether, but again, this is probably gonna get fixed. )ConclusionThat's pretty much it. This game is amazing, I bought it a couple weeks ago and already have about 100 hours into it. it 'is' absolutely worth the 20 bucks if you want a complex, gun-toting, seafaring, explosive, "massive" minecraft from AWESOMEVILLE. ?While it has it's faults, you'll see from my comparisons, they are vastly outweighed by what it has to offer. Take some time to look at the controls, the tutorials -totally didn't do this part, but I had lots of fun figuring it out on my own-, and get to builidng your ships, yours gun, and claim those resource points!

Early Access Review
								This game is without a doubt amazing! It has a very unique feel to it and the customization is done just right. you are able to customize EVERYTHING but you won't need to micro manage if you don't want to. The developer seems to be a very good guy who cares deeply for his work, and rightly so! even this early on, I call it a masterpiece as it is.There's just a certain freedom in this game that I wish bigger name developers would learn to incorporate. I really don't have any significant problems with this game. The only thing that i could possibly consider a downside is that the ai of my boats is a tad bit clunky but I'm sure the ai will be improved soon, the updates have been regular and the developer has been very dedicated from what i've seen.I would say this game is easily worth the money, good on you Brilliant Skies!

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm bit ambivalent about this game, to be honest. It's hard not to reccomend with a fully realized resource system, single-player campaign, regular updates, and a truly bewildering array of components that puts Space Engineers to shame. That said, it's also hard to reccomend this game, at least solidly, due to the many technical limitations.Don't get me wrong, I'm aware that it's incomplete and that work hasn't been finished and that, given the track record so far coupled with my own personal (if limited) interactions with the developer, it's very likely that this WILL see a final release. That said, you can'y play it right on anything beyond a dedicated gaming rig. The preveiws would have you believe that it's a game that's filled with epic clashed on the sea, in the sky, and among the heavens beyond... AND IT IS! But... they can only be realized by machines that can handle that sort of thing, and since (as of yet) the game still runs on 32-bit, so no one on a moderately powerful lappy willl likely ever see them.However! For those with machines that can run this game without slow-down or imcomplete fleet pop-in? It's a fantastic experience. Skies choked with missiles, the sea churning with explosions, blocks flying in every direction, lasers burning through armor, shields deflecting exploding shells. Guns, lasers, missiles, torpedoes, mines, aircraft, ballooncraft, ships of every description, AND WOODEN SPACE SHIPS! Incredible battles with meticulously crafted vehicles, where unprecedented customization finally passes the barrier of mere "customization in games" and actually becomes ENGINEERING.So, I have trouble recommending this game because not everyone can enjoy it as it should be enjoyed. But for those who can... get it. Get it now. WHY AREN'T YOU GETTING IT YET?!

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have no idea what I'm doing.Edit 8/9/16SEND HELP I CAN'T STOP PLAYINGEdit 8/21/16Alright heres an actual review since I really love this game.TLDR at the bottomFrom the Depths is a Sandbox, Building, and Strategy game all in one. You can make Ships, Battleships, Cruisers, Aircraft Carriers, Submarines and a hell of a lot more. If you aren't too much of a naval guy, then you can also make aviation vehicles such as Airplanes, Jets, Airships, and even Spaceships. If you aren't too much of a naval guy or aviation guy then don't worry, I'll get to that later in this review.The Official CampaignsAlright so this game has 6 main campaigns, each where you play as each different faction. The planet you play this campaign at is called Neter. I have not played the faction campaigns at all so I won't be giving a description for those since I know jack♥♥♥♥♥♥about them. But I will say which faction is for which campaign.Quest for Neter - If you wanna be independent and not play as any faction, then this one is for you. You wanna fight everyone and reign supreme? Then go ahead. You wanna make friends with other factions? Go ahead, it's your game.Of Oil and Pirates - Deepwater GuardOperation Iron Maiden - Steel StridersThe Steel Inquisition - White FlayersSurge Protection Protocol - Twin GuardThe Ascension Project - Lightning HoodsScarlet Skies - Scarlet DawnThese are the main campaigns you can play.The Custom CampaignsAlright so you might be thinking, "This♥♥♥♥♥♥sounds easy". It isn't. But if you want more of a challenge, then here's the custom campaigns.The Quest for Glao - Play on a different planet called Glao. The air is toxic and you require a "Heart Stone" in order to not die horribly by the toxic air. Not to worry, you can make one easily. You play independently in this campaign.Dangerous Waters - Are you not too creative. Are you too lazy to make♥♥♥♥♥♥ Do you love WWII? Then this campaign is for you. This campaign is set around WWII and is more of an RTS than other campaigns. You cannot build in this campaign but you can get resources and chose historically (almost) accurate vehicles that you can control. You can chose normal ships, submarines, planes, and even tanks! You can only play as the Liberty (USA) Faction in this campaign for now.Ashes of the Empire - This campaign takes 10 years before The Quest for Neter campaign. You play on Neter again, but something is very different.Originally posted by Mr.Spookyman: If you aren't too much of a naval guy or aviation guy then don't worry, I'll get to that later in this review.   That's right. Land! You finally have a (very) large open world that you can make Tanks, Cars, Trucks, and more and use them to annihilate your foes with. There are some very tiny water areas if you really want to build ships. Of course there's a large♥♥♥♥♥area for your aviation vehicles as well.These are all the custom campaigns.BuildingThere are two ways to build. Using your keyboard or using your mouse and WASD. The game recommends you using the keyboard method but I like using the mouse more as I am used to it from other building games.You have a wide arsenal of blocks and other♥♥♥♥♥♥to use on your vehicle that you are building. You can make a simple, wooden raft or Pirate Ship or you could make a mix of metal blocks and lighter blocks to make a huge♥♥♥♥♥Battleship or something like that.The building is very easy for me to use. You can make a frame of the bottom of a ship and press a simple little keyboard button that fills in the frame automatically for you with whatever block you have selected currently. You can also make both sides of your ship easily with the mirror option. You can also paint your vehicle in any colors you want.This game makes building easy and simple.GameplaySo you finished making (or spawned in) a vehicle. Congrats. Now you gotta see if that♥♥♥♥♥♥is seaworthy. You can use the vehicle creator and spawn some enemies in and see how your vehicle does. If it ♥♥♥♥s up, then try improving it or make a new vehicle from scratch. If it's victorious (multiple times perhaps?), then try the campaigns. You can spawn in your ship (or make a new one) in the campaigns but they will cost materials.Playing in campaign mode is survival mode or something like that. You make♥♥♥♥♥♥to kill other♥♥♥♥♥♥and take their♥♥♥♥♥♥that can be used to make more♥♥♥♥♥♥that kills other♥♥♥♥♥♥ Or you could just make some Fortresses in material areas that can drill out materials that you can use to make stuff with.This is gameplay for now. I might continue on it later.Conclusion and TLDRRating ScaleNuclear Waste♥♥♥♥♥♥MehOkGoodHey! That's pretty good.AmazingFlawless.This game is Amazing to me. A lot, and I mean a whole damn lot, of this game is top notch  and perfect. The reason I don't say it's flawless and say it's amazing instead is because some stuff can be annoying and can get you to start screaming at your monitor.HOWEVER, if you are a pretty chill gamer dude or Dudette who loves building, then this game would probably be Flawless for you.

content:

Early Access Review
								Heavily active community, a link below to the official forums!  http://www.fromthedepthsgame.com/forum/index.php*****FOR THOSE WHO DONT READ GOOD*****http://www.fromthedepthsgame.com/forum/showthread.php?tid=3149Check out the link above and you can watch for yourself what this game is all about when it comes to pushing the limits and coming up with ideas. The game is TECHNICALLY in alpha right now, but I personally would never have guessed it's in alpha from playing it.  IMO it's more complete then alot of released games these days and the developer Nick is a comlete boss.  (The only developer of any game i've ever played where I know their name lol)I'm only 70 hours (purchased 2 weeks ago) in and have another 70 to go easily before I can even begin to call myself a guru at this game.  Learning the basics really isn't that hard and literally the only limit is your imagination.  Earlier today I literally made a boat around a drill for ramming and it worked.  But then I thought...  What if the ENTIRE drill rotated while it drilled?  Took me another 3 hours but...  oh.. my... god...EDIT:  Sittin at over 800 hours now, and I'm still...  not a guru compared to some masters out there!  It was worth it when I originally wrote this review, and it's completely worth it now.

content:
Posted: March 31
Early Access Review
								This game takes a while to get a hang of most of the components in the game such as cannons, missiles, lasers and so on. Once you get past this stage of the game, you can get right into making some form of highly unstable derp gun that spends most of its time upside down as you don't quite understand the physics about weight distribution and you completely forget that the recoil for the cannon is over 9,000.Otherwise, this game is really good. You can spend countless hours making a vehicle that is absolutely amazing with no sign of getting bored. Once you have done that you can either take it into the games campaign or take it online and discover that pretty much everyone builds better than you do and that the ship is holier than the Catholic Church.However, due to the complexity of the game, some of the components are difficult to get to grips with, such as lua sctipts, making planes/helicopters and even making efficient cannons and lasers. The game does come with tutorials but they do not cover everything just the main things such as how to make an A.I, how to make an engine and so on.I would definitely recommend this game as it is so much fun, even when you have no idea about what you are doing and keep blowing yourself up because you forgot to put fuel in your missile.

								Oh my god this game is fun if you're an engineery type like me.Make whatever you make in Minecraft, except it actually moves. And shoots! And has bad AI! But at least there is AI so you can have fleet battles.The vehicle building is really well designed in terms of controls. Feels like a basic CAD program, except a little less crashy.The campaign is a little long for me. I can't stick with it long enough to get through the Deepwater Guard, but that doesn't matter! I love the building part of this game. number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is, by far, the most complex exciting RTS block-building/sandbox game that I've ever run across in all my years.Imagine warcraft, but you build and design your units, block by block, even down to the missiles (and soon even the bullets!)You think "woah, like how, as in there's heavy cannons and gatling guns and such?"No, I mean you can make one or the other, with the same "custom cannon" blocks.  multi-block functionality to the extreme.Now, as you can imagine, trying to fit the controls for an RTS game, alongside a sandbox game, paired with an engineering game, things can get a bit hairy when it comes to the GUI.Some people see the variety of buttons/menus and freak out and immediately hate the game because its beyond their ability to spend more than ten minutes trying to figure something out. If you actually read up on some guides or ask the community for help in understanding things, you'll quickly realize that the GUI has to be the way that it is, to allow for the complexity this game strives for.Please, don't be afraid of the buttons :-DIf you're having trouble understanding anything, just ask the community for help,  we love to tell our "OH now i get it!" moments :-DUpdate ->  There's now even a "complexity" slider, to help guide new players in understanding what blocks topay attention to when they're first starting out, in addition to new in-game tutorials and guides, as well as two different control modes.   The developer, as mentioned in almost every other review, literally listens to the community, brings home the exact type of bacon the community wants.Oh, did i mention theres a "world Editor" now? meaning you can create your own worlds/factions/campaigns/missions and (eventually) share them on steam? :D

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Score now: 9/10  Potential score: 10/10Best early access I have ever encountered. Ever. I write this as my first decent attempt at a campaign fortress is slowly being ripped appart by the AI after disabling my weapons systems. I'm not even angry - just impressed that there is so much depth in this sandbox/strategy/vehicle builder game. Block by block construction is both simple and leads to intricate detail possibilities for construction. I agree with other reviews - research & planning is essential for this game if you want to enjoy it - and ends up being part of the fun.There are numerous strategies that can be employed for the fleet & ship based fights - naval & air vehicles need to be allow for in this game. It lends itself toward letting the AI do everything in controlling ships/weapons however it is possible for the player to use both. I haven't tested out the fleet systems properly yet but going by the AI it looks to work fantastic - seriously the AI kicked my where it hurts with a pincer movement - then from above- seriously who attacks you from directly above????Any lack of documentation is made up for by an incredibly supportive and involved community - the developer has obviously gone to much lengths to ensure that all learning styles are accounted for.Replayability:*If you are like me and love tweaking those designs just that *little bit more* and getting satisfaction from a good system, I can see it proving hours and hours of additional time.*The current campaign is great for getting a feel for construction techniques and tactics to use in your own creations*Not really a story based game - but why would you think that is what you are playing forPros*Lasers*Really, really big guns*Customisable missile systems*Smart/programable systems - seriously takes hours just to scratch the surface.*Amazing tactical/strategic possibilities - I have not seen a game I would rate higher in this regard (I would love to see some tutorials on the map systems & maybe some more depth on campaign for this reason)*Very customisable interfaceCons:*Steep learning curve*Requires a level of sophisication & engineering mindset to truly appreciate it. (Think minecraft bashing creeps with a sword to using automated traps to farm them) Not truly a con but may be a consideration for gifting.*Some of the interfaces such as battle seem buggy (the intent is well documented but can be confusing when starting up)**Very customisable interface - makes it difficult to remember what key map to press for certain situations (take this as an advisement if considering how much time you want to invest rather than a con.Well recommended and cannot see what comes next as it develops. I only hope that the community gets behind it and allows it to continue to develop to its amazing potential.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								(Game is still in ALPHA. So, many things I dislike are most likely to be changed or be fixed)TL;DR- This game is the best game I have ever plated, and I have played A LOT. This game is ideal for all who seek an origional sandbox or construction game, and caters to the imaginations of the engineering-minded.  I give it my highest recommendation.This game....At first it is, honestly, kinda bad;-It has an extremely steep learning curve, perhaps the steepest I have ever seen in ANY game. It took me around 2 days to learn the very basics, although to be fair there are a lot more online and in-game tutorials now than when I started playing.-The game is visually not altogether that impressive. -The game is extremely cpu intensive, and runs on a single core, meaning slower PCs will suffer, especially when there are lots of craft spawned, or lost of shells and missiles flying.That being said, this game quickly became my favourite game of all time, catering to exactly what I want in a game: A vehicle based sandbox construction and combat game with block destruction, in which near enough every aspect of what you might want to build is customisable. If you can get past the initial learning curve (which is long and steep, but not tedious), you will be greeted by an absolute gem of a game supported by a single developer (Nick) whom is perhaps one of the best game developers I have ever encountered; He listens to the community like no other, and even adds user design submissions to the base game's campaign. Speaking of which, the game features an ever-increasing number of campaigns, varying in length and difficulty. The first campaign (in my opinion, the best) features you, the player, trying to conquer the games fictional planet of Neter. In which, you'll face numerous ofher factions on a large map, with enemies varying from tanks to ships to planes to submarines, and even spacecraft, all of whih hwere designed by the community.The building/ designing aspects of the game realy are nailed. Construction, once you know the system, is quick and easy, and has few limitations. The sheer number of blocks to choose from in the build menu is also astounding, with both more available on the workshop, and more planned for future updates.The multiplayer aspect of the game is also excellent fun, having seen a bit of tlc recently, bringing greater stability, and better support for more players. In multiplayer, you can pretty much do anything you could in singleplayer, including building/ designing craft, playing through any of the campaigns, using mods, and several of ter gamemodes.There are a few additions and changes I would like to ee implemented into the game, although I'm sure these will arrive at some point in the form of a mod or an update anyway:-AI; While the AI has seen some improvements, there are a few errors and bugs here and there that still need ironing out.-More blocks, namely 8m blocks (beams, slopes, or otherwise): there are several situations where I have felt that an 8m block would be welcome, such as when blending a curve to a straight line, i.e at the bow of a ship. Also, larger or customisable propellers: the game currently features 1x1 and 3x3 propeller blocks, but they are either out of place or simply inadequate on many sedigns.In conclusion, Fron the Depths is a fantastic game with it's  foundations solid enough for it to become even better with time. If you're looking for a game that's very origional in it's design and how it plays, or are simply a fan of sandbox games or games where you like to blow stuff up, I cannot recommend this game enough, especially considering the price... If I had to score it, i'd give it about a 9/10, due to, mainly, bugs.P.S. If anyone gets past the tutorials and still doesnt have a clue, just pm me and i'll try and help you... After all, the community is part of the fun of this game.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Have you ever heard of learning curves? Yeah, this has a learning wall.It's an incredibly hard game to get your head around. I strongly recommend watching an LP or lots of YT tutorials(TheBudkai's was good for me, although S1 will be very outdated now) if you want to play it.Once you understand this game, it's amazing. Gameplay is very rewarding, especially watching your designs destroy (or get destroyed by) your enemies' designs. Building vehicles, their defenses, their propulsion, their weapons, is extremely in-depth.You need a pretty beefy computer to get into the late-game main campaign or large vehicles, however there is a smaller campaign being worked on and the game runs perfectly fine with small vessels.The dev team are incredibly active, and clearly have an idea how the game will pan out.Honestly, the biggest con is that you'll probably end up on the NSA's watchlist for googling so much about military weaponry.

								This game is a shining example to all other Early Access games. If you like a game with so much depth that you'll spend a hundred hours in game before you learn how to use each little component correctly, and like to build huge awesome death machines, this game is for you.Also, the dude that works on this is dedicated, and updates are frequent. number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
Early Access Review
Great military voxel builderMore than a "game", this is a lego box for building military vehicles, from ships and submarines to planes and spaceships. The game is very deep and based on more or less realistic engeering of sorts, for example, engines and weapons systems are multi part set-ups with varying complexity.Not that the game lacks "action" at all, but you'll probably be disappointed if you expect a fast FPS like gameplay. There's a lot of combat, and you control your vehicle and weapons systems, but it's not about rapid reflexes aiming, it's more about the load out you have and how you use it.The game is still in Early Access, but there's constant updates.Be warned, there's a steep learning curve, and this plays more like a 3D modelling software than like minecraft.I appreciate the linux support.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								For a game still grounded in its development, I find it to be highly addictive and fun, though somewhat frustrating, but that said, frustration is all part of a game.The total creative freedom you have with the designer for the story mode and campaign is refreshing, but the modular aspects of putting your vehicle together can be daunting and requires sitting down and really tinkering around to find the right balance of armour, weaponry and other abilities. It is not just a pick up and play sort of game.There are negatives naturally, the story mode isn't much good and with the game constantly being updated/developed, it does have stability issues. Nothing that wont be fixed in due course naturally.In conclusion for this short review, I rate it 4 stars out of five, a great game to lose yourself in for a couple of hours.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is my story of this game so far. I've owned the game for a very long time but never bothered to play the campaign since it confused me at the time. Well, i started playing it recently and know how to work most of the HUD in the campaign. this is my story of my struggle against the deep water guard.I started off int he starting base doing the usual. Making the crappy engine much more efficient, armoring up the supply room, etc etc. well i decided to take my huskie ( my fast scouting ship ) out to find some deep water guard. i unfortunately  ran into their main force near the resource zone and tried to retreat. I failed and my huskie was a goner. i knew they would send that force to me so i build a rocket launcher that held 8 laser guided rockets and waited. Thankfully they only sent one plane and my rockets quickly dealt with it. I had more confidence and decided to build a semi expensive ( crystal wise) ship that i knew would help. I eventually built up a 6 ship fleet and decided to bring the fight to them. Short story short, i got slaughtered. i only had enough resources to build 2 ships. My small rocket plane and my rocket cruiser. i decided i would build another huskie and go scout some place since i had nothing else to do. ( i grabbed the resource zone that i mentioned earlier) i found 3 ships. They had a plunderer and 2 atlases coming for me. i decided  to lure them to my base and they destroyed both my fortresses. i reloaded my last save and decided to try taking out the plunder by destroying the ammo barrels. i rode my huskie into battle with a overpowering determination and i boarded the plunderer. i quickly punched my way to the core and destroyed it. i cheered in triumph and noticed my repair tentacles were repairing the ship, i panicked and checked the map only to realize that i captured the ship. I laughed and realized the ships gun systems were down till the core i destroyed came back to repair. i noticed the ship had plenty of repair bots and decided to man the guns myself till they were repaired. i started shooting the atlases with little affect. things were looking bad, with the ship being constantly hit by the atlases i thought i was doomed. Then, all of a sudden all the guns pointed the enemy balloon crafts and blew them out of the sky with little effort. i rode my newly captured ship back to base in excitement and knew, that the tides have turned against  the deep water guard.100/10. ill never regret buying this game.

Early Access Review
								The list shows more CONS than PROS, but I guess in the end the game is recommendable.I give this game 7/10.PROS- Freedom to build (space) ships, planes, submarines and land vehicles.- Lot of possibilities if you know how to program the AI.- Worth your time and creativity.- Fun to put designs to the test.CONS- Rather slow development.- Physics are a bit strange sometimes. That's okay for most people, but I like to design historical planes with realistic sizes and proportions.- Steap learning curve.- UI is a bit messy and unattractive, or at least very unpolished.- Needs high-end computer.- Multiplayer could be better.

content:

Early Access Review
								Absolutely phenomenal game. The beauty of it is that it is only in the alpha stages, yet it is already in incredible form. Granted, there is a large learning curve, but what is the point of a game if not to challenge you. Once you have learned the basics, the campaign is sensational. It can be set to any level of difficulty, from novice to expert. It will run on practically any computer at smooth fps even when encountering huge battles. I can only recommend this game, and for the price it is a definite "bang for your buck". Also, I would like to give credit to the devs and community members for creating such a fantastic game. Hope to see more progression in the coming months!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25
Early Access Review
								Tried to get into it two times, finished a few tutorials but it didn't catched me. One review reads "Once you hit 200 hours, everything starts to get really fun as you understand the fundamentals of this game." I do not doubt that. Also that you can have fun before you hit a month of 24/7-gaming. But the beginning is really slow. When you only spent 1-3hrs every session you probably need a week before the gameplay sucks you in. There is some gamification within the tutorials but it wasn't enough to keep me on track several hours before being able to do the most basic stuff. Don't get me wrong: if you are ready to invest the time it will(*) pay back. And 20€ for a game were you can dump hundreds of hours in is a good deal. I'd payed more for less and was happy. (*) very low play time compared to others so this is an assumption. But reading the other reviews I tend to believe that. I do not regret the deal and I will come back and try it again ... two or three times ... maybe four. Also, maybe the starting phase will be improved as the game improves. Do not skip this game just because of this review. Just be warned: you'll have to spend some time before it's fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great game, decent amount of depth (no puns please) and i love the keyboard based building style, cant see why no one thought of it before, makes things so much tidier and faster once you get it down. That will be the theme for this game, should you decide to play it. Getting it down. You will spend every minute of playing this game getting something down. You will learn how to build an engine. How to build a ship. Realise both your ship and engine suck so hard, they should be called The Dyson Mk I. You will re-learn how to build an engine. You will put that engine into a new ship. You will build a cannon. Your cannon wont work. You will rage. You will learn how to build a cannon properly. You will realise now that this is the ultimate learning curve simulator of all time. You will play. All day. E'rry Day. Occassionally, you may speak to your family and be reminded that they seem like nice people. One day, you may get down the life-work-FTD balance. But it wont be any day in the next fortnight. The learning curve is real and its called From The Depths. 10/10 would re-design ship 15 times before having nervous breakdown and coming back tomorrow.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								I don't do alot of reviews but FTD is one of my favorite games right now.First we are gonna start with the good parts of the gamePros: (Ill break these down in a little)Its ComplicatedSomething new to do everytime you launch it. Updates pretty often. Amazing Cusomization of weapons, ships, and even engines. Lets Break It Down.The engines and weapon system in the game are complicated. im not going to lie, To this day I still am finding new combos to use with my Turrets and MisslesSomething new to do everytime you launch it, By this I mean that you can always build new things, Try new gamemodes and just have something new to build every time you launch it. One day you could build a speedboat and the next a Huge battleship or even a jet or bomber. Its honestly one of the most user dynamic games ive seen. Updates, Updates for this game are well done and well announced. He posts the features of each update on steam and on their fourms. He also asks the community what they would like to see. Its a small dev team and the rate of their updates makes Dayz Standalone look abandoned. *The last point i addressed in the first two points*Now, To the cons. This game's multiplayer requires Godly internet. The multiplayer isnt optimized as well as lets say Minecraft or Space Engineers. But I digress. Bugs. This game isnt perfect it has its share of bugs but thats expected from an Early Access game.I personally enjoy the game alot and I am starting to play it alot more just because of the recent new updates. The Idea of the game is great! And the way they are going with it looks very  promising on the fact that you can literally make a Giant♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and send it flying at enemys with a nuke, If thats your kinda game play. Anyways. I really suggest this for people who like Space Engineers and Scrap mechanics. It has great water physics and alot of complication to its gameplay.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 11
Early Access Review
								There is something about this game that makes it great, somthing bigger, more rewarding, more incredible than just about any other game, you play CoD for 50 hours, and what do you get for it? some pretty skins for a gun? Not exactly a motivator,           but this game, it gives you that somthing special-- special like I've never seen before in any game. That feeling is true, genuine acomplishment, I learned that with my very first ship, lovingly named the lancer, it was a sleek heavy hitter, based on elysium's frigate-- smashed every DWG ship in the game, and a quick adjustment to the missiles to use EMP destroyed every OW ship in the game, I loved it, it was my baby, every ship after that was just the same, there isn't a single other game that can match that feeling, I even learned Lua code just to optimize my missiles! don't get me wrong, there are a litany of issues with this game, not the least of which is messing with the AI, but other than a few quality of acomplishment (life) issues, this is an amazing game, one I cannot shower enough praise upon.P.S--I've had this game for a while now, and I can assure you, I've played more than 60-some odd hours, and it's been an excellent experience. I still remember when I first got the game, and had been inspired to get it by people like EnterElysium, (watching their videos was invaluable to helping me with the harsh learning curve involved with picking this game up).

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Oh yeah. This is the real deal. This is what would happen if you threw some random guy into a mostly water planet, and throw in some other factions that (may) try to kill him, and to protect himself, he has to build boats, but he is clueless.The first few attempts the guy makes, his ship is too slow, flips, sinks, and ends up a sinking mosaic.The next few attempts he has to thwart pirates so he makes a decent, tiny little boat that destroys one, two, three blocks and then it gets blown up by a missile. Thankfully the starter fortress is a godsend and saves him from a buttkicking.A lot of attempts pass and somehow he makes a... plane? That kills one of the easy pirate ships with an atom bomb Kamikaze design! Yay!A few more attempts and he makes an average medium ship with a balanced... well, everything! It gives even the pirate designs a run for their money with a shield that bounces off most projectiles and missiles.*Spongebob time card*3 days laterHe finally manages to conquer Neter with his awesome reusable Kamikaze design somehow because the plane's diving at the enemy so fast, the turrets can't catch up!From humble beginnings (a crappy raft) to conqueror! (awesome kamikaze design)My experience so far;1st campaign (a little hard difficulty): A disaster in every way possible. Couldn't attack fast enough to do anything, and it ended in defeat with no resources left, so repair was impossible.Multiplayer (average difficulty): Learned about shipbuilding, engines, cannons, not so much missiles, and the fact that other people are better than me. Ended when I accidentally smushed too many ships together and crashed the game for the both of us.Another multiplayer session (average difficulty): Much shorter, learned about balloons, flying, etc. Ended when the game host just decided to quit.2nd campaign (very easy difficulty): A success so far, first upgraded the starter fortress, then made a mess of balloons that could somehow go to 3100m above the air (3.1km!) that saved ME from a buttkicking by just living, so that I could drop down as me and explode the enemies. 2 moderately difficult designs that got butchered just by this one plank of wood with 2 antennas attached to it for scouting, LOTS OF BALLOONS, and NO WEAPONS. Reminds me of the movie Up... then, just today, I made a breakthrough and made a working AI (well, who knows it hasn't been tested... yet) for the starting_rib with 2 crappy cannons with the minimal gauge and just 2 barrels!A wonderful experience. And a worthy substitute for the entire public education system if used correctly, in my opinion. It has all the strains and benefits of learning in a fun package! Imagine of the public schools were replaced with From the Depths schools, good lord, that would (prooooooooooooobably) never happen.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Build fully functional and fully customiztable warships, aircraft, spaceships, naval and land bases, submarines, coastal defenses, then send them to battle under AI control, or pilot them yourself.And if you think that default AI does not cut it, you can code your own AI for your vehicles in LUA. Name one other game where you can program your units in an actual programming language without leaving the game. I'll wait.The most innovative game in last 5 years.Still under heavy development, updates come often (weekly/monthly).Learning curve to build things from scratch might be steep, but you can load, study and use/pilot all builtin designs in the campaign.10/10, this is hot stuff.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's complicated. You need to learn a lot, You need to watch/read tutorials, you need to think a lot, you need to refine your designs a lot... You're going to fail a lot. But once you get good it's so damn satisfying that Dark Souls seems like a casual game in comparison! The moment when you manage to hit that damn little annoying flyer or when your massive self designed guns blow a football field sized hole into the ship you feared before... That moment Is PRICELESS! You are proud of what you built, but you know there are bigger and scarier things out there. If this sounds like something you would enjoy, this game is for you. I barely played anything else since I bought this and I love it! There are more than enough good and easy tutorials out there to learn so don't be scared of the learning curve. If you like building stuff and you like explosions and cool ships/planes/subs/airships/stuff you should really try this game! :)

content:

								Bought the key for this game on another game selling site for 7 bucks less than here.  Learning to use the construction editor in this game is a bit of a challenge but not that bad.  And once you learn it, constructing things in this game is far easier and QUICKER than any other similar building game that I have!  Especially if you take the extra time to learn how to edit using the keyboard method as opposed to using the mouse method.  In a very short time, Ive constructed quite a large and stable hull complete with power train installed.  Next Ill focus on making the top side of the ship look cool.  Later Ill get into experimenting with my own engine builds and the like(right now Im using one of the games pre-fab engines).  If you are creative, like to design and build cool looking things that you can then test for functionality, and even get in battles with what you've created to see how it holds up, then this game is definitely a must have for you.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								From the Depths is an extremely satisfying game. It is the perfect blend of all my favorite sandbox games. However, it is very complex, from designing your very own engine, to getting the thrust to weight ratio perfect, all the way to creating artifficial intelligence to control your weapons that you created.Pros: There is so much variety in this game, anything you want to do, you can.Ample amounts of tutorials are at your fingertips, as a beginner I had no troubles learning how everything worked.For an alpha game, it is suprising how optimized it is. I have not dropped below 60 fps once, even with large vehicle battles surrounding me.You can create any sized vehicle as long as you design it correctly. From 4 x 4 rafts, to 300+ x 300+ Airships.All of the controls and graphics are 100% customizable, so you can have the perfect game experience.The developers have been great at constantly updating this game, I am certain this won't be the same "sell & run" experience that we get with so many early access games. (DayZ, 7 Days to Die, etc.)Cons:The multiplayer is not yet developed, but the developers say they will be coming out with a fully functional multiplayer.To the faint of heart, the building system might be difficult to understand.Do not let the complicated mechanics of this game get you down, this is a near perfect game for me, and it has only been out for around a single month. Give this game a shot, for $20 you can't get anything better. Final Rating: 9/10 Note: This will be 10/10 with the finished multiplayer.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Have you ever designed a kick♥♥♥♥♥sailboat in Minecraft and wish you could take to the seas with it? Have you ever thought Kerbals were too peaceful? Have you ever wanted to design a plane that used cannons as a means of movement? Me neither, but in From the Depths, YOU CAN!From the Depths is a sandbox physics game with some rts elements thrown in for good measure. Build a ship, watch it sink. Build a better ship, one that moves! ....Then watch it get blown up. Build a gun, then build a ship around it! This is, in essence, what FtD is all aboot.In career mode you can take your designs and put them to the test. Capture resource nodes, battle pirates, and build your empire. Switch from game view to map view and position your fleet. Instead of rolling the dice when two ships meet, go back into physics mode and battle your enemy head on. You can manually control your vehicles and bases, or you can use the modular AI pieces and build an AI to do it for you.Speaking of modular, this game features modular engines, cannons, lasers, missiles, etc. Instead of placing a gun block where you want a gun, you can build your cannon from many modules that altar how the gun works. Range, reload time, damage, armor penetration, explosive rounds, accuracy, etc.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game runs in the vein of others such as kerbal space program, starmade and space engineers. The difference being it is heavily focused on combat and fleets of units rather than a single craft. It has a steep learning curve so it can be daunting at first although there are quite a few videos and guides out there to help you on the more complicated things. The satisfaction from getting your fleet afloat and firing a hail of cannon shells and missile streaking towards the enemy is akin to glee as you watch the enemy fleet explode into little bits.Somewhere between a simulator, rts and a fps all rolled into one, its not for everyone, but for those with a creative streak its a highly addictive mix. For those with less patience they can always use the vehicles created by others from the workshop or FTD forums to get straight into the action.Once the co-op campaign is finished I doubt there will be any other game I'd rather play than From The Depths for a long time

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								From the Depths (FtD) is a game I highly recommend to people who like a learning curve in their games. This is a kind of game where you can show off your skill and power to your friends because you put in the time and effort to master the game. If you are a lazy person who likes playing games like Call of Duty just because they are easy, don't get this game. The game itself is a pretty interesting sandbox game where you can build ships, fortresses, planes, and even land vehicles. Most of the game revolves around the ships (hence the name, From the Depths) which all have main components like engines, propellers, rudders, AI cores, weapons systems, and etc. Each of these components will need to be learned individually and will function together to make your ship. The game allows for a lot of customization with its parts.  I think that this game really shows what you can be capable from learning from a game. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested.-TheNileCroc07[EDIT] By the way, the achievement of completing the first tutorial is broken for me. If anybody else has this problem, please tell me in the comments. Also, its still cool [11/23/2016]

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								This block based, build anything you like combat simulator is better than sliced bread with peanut butter and jelly. I mention peanut butter and jelly because this game isn't just the bread, but comes with a metric s**t ton of hidden features that will amaze the armchair war machine engineer for days, weeks and months. From Age of Sail frigates to Space Battleship Yamato, build every darn war machine you've ever dreamed of in childhood and make them dominate subsurface, sea, air, land, and space battles with your arsenal of custom designed guns, lasers and missile systems that are near fully customizable. Anything is possible, prepare to be amazed by the hundreds of example ships packaged in the singleplayer missions, they're absolutely dangerous and creative, from submarine rams to paddle boats to flying fortresses and laser armed behemoths that ascend far beyond human engineering. And all that from a small selection of Minecraft style blocks!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you like Minecraft, Robocraft or any of those types of building games then this is probably a game you would enjoy. Building is similar to both, with more options and different types of blocks available. I have several hundred hours on both Robocraft and Minecraft, but prefer this game in terms of creativity and open endedness. There are no blocks to unlock, credits to earn, and all features are available from the onset. In the campaign, building is limited by resources, which you gather in zones or by defeating enemies. In sandbox mode, building is unlimited and design generated there can  be built in the campaign. Since it is still in alpha stage, changes are continually coming out and not all in game features have been implemented. It is primarily single player, and the campaign mode works but again as an alpha, it can change as updates come out which can be pretty frequent as the developer is VERY active. The world it takes place on is mostly water and the game's focus is primarily water based ship building and combat, however aircraft, submarines, balloon craft and, to a limited extent, even spacecraft are possible. Land based craft are in the works and ground based structures are possible. There is currently 4 types of weapons available: projectile (cannons, machine guns, electromagnetic gauss), missiles, energy based (lasers and particle cannons) and simple types like rams and drills. Most have different parts to make them configurable for different effects and potency. The only downside to this game is the learning curve is VERY steep for some of the more in depth or advanced functions and the enemy can be very difficult in the later stages of the campaign and the multiplayer aspect is limited. Fortunately, the game difficulty can be tweaked and the campaign is optional. You can just build in sandbox mode and pit your designs against each other (or the built in designs) if you choose. The Steam Workshop also has very many designs from the community (many are exceptional and are even in the game itself) and the user interface is very easy to use and vehicles and structures are  easy to install and can be used in the campaign or sandbox. I have not experimented with multiplayer at all, so I can't  comment on what it entails or how well it functions. Overall this is a fun builder type game in which I have spent over 2000 hours on and continually come back to. I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								From the Depths (FtD) is a game I highly recommend to people who like a learning curve in their games. This is a kind of game where you can show off your skill and power to your friends because you put in the time and effort to master the game. If you are a lazy person who likes playing games like Call of Duty just because they are easy, don't get this game. The game itself is a pretty interesting sandbox game where you can build ships, fortresses, planes, and even land vehicles. Most of the game revolves around the ships (hence the name, From the Depths) which all have main components like engines, propellers, rudders, AI cores, weapons systems, and etc. Each of these components will need to be learned individually and will function together to make your ship. The game allows for a lot of customization with its parts.  I think that this game really shows what you can be capable from learning from a game. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested.-TheNileCroc07[EDIT] By the way, the achievement of completing the first tutorial is broken for me. If anybody else has this problem, please tell me in the comments. Also, its still cool [11/23/2016]

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Quite a good block-based building game. Although the game's genre is focused on naval battles, you can build ground vehicles if you so wish. You can create various weaponry for different roles: Flak cannons for your battleships; CRAM cannons for your artillery; or LUA-guided missiles for Air-to-Air, Air-to-Ground or vice-versa. There are wheel blocks for land-based vehicles, but they are highly neglected, and I hope they are worked on soon; as you can create some stunning tanks with various shell types that will surely catch the interests of many War Thunder players, such as myself.Pros:A vast selection of parts ranging from lightweight metal alloys and ERA armour to LUA script for AI mainframes and various cannon types for both beginners and professionals.Stable multiplayer capability, although some bugs should be ironed out, such as the lack of Prefabs and host-only barrel-number selection for advanced cannons.Cons:You need a good graphics card to run this game over 30 fps at 1080p. I had around 15 on 720p with my old GT 620 (came with my prebuilt computer), now I get 60fps on 1080p at high.All-in-all a fun build game for Land, Air, and Naval vehicles.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Alright. If you are not into really long reviews then this is not for you. I am just going to explain all the pros and cons to this game with detail.To start off with: The game is very fun depending on how much time you are willing to spend outside of the action. What I mean is that if you want constant action then you are not going to enjoy this game. This game is about spending time building a creation and updating all the issues about it and making it look good until you are proud of it. As I have already said: If you want constant action then don't get this game. Have patience.I really love this game because I find the battles fun when I use my new creations. The AI is rather challenging but sometimes there are a few issues. This can be the enemy fighting a fight despite the fact they will loose it without a doubt. It just slows the game down. I would rather it were so that the AI regroups into a larger fleet or scraps small ships to make large ships. But nonetheless all the factions are challenging at times.The tutorials are a little confusing to get the hang of at the start. But I first thought advanced cannons were impossible to make when they were introduced and within a day I got the hang of them and now I can build them without any issues. If you need serious help then watch videos made by lathrix/lathland.The very few issues I have about the game is that the game is not amazingly optimised. What I mean by this is that if I wanted to fight a battle against the Damascus (steel striders main base) I can barely run the game. Yet I can run most ships rather well. Another problem I have with this game is that the updates tend to take a while to come out. You might have the odd patch every now and then but even that is annoyingly slow. But at the same time, when updates do come out they tend to be good. The latest update is the steam engine and I think that it is really cool. I personally love the animations of that but hell, other games can thrash that.Furthermore the AI factions are... Well don't do much. They attack you sure but that is about it. When two factions start off at war with each other you should be able to see them fighting. And they never really have proper diplomacy either. You cannot plan with them to make an attack somewhere. You cannot go into their land. At the moment there is no point in becoming allies with someone.My last problem is the storyline. Whilst the game is fun it is also a bit confusing. The whole talk about the White Flayers betraying the Steel Empire and cutting off their power ect, Does not make sense to me. This is truly because the only thing close to an actual person is the npc... And what I mean by the npc is a floating robot with 1 shotting machine guns on either side. Furthermore you never see cities. That is my one huge problem with the storyline. There is talk of power supplies as I mentioned earlier and all that good stuff. But there is nothing there... The closest thing to a possible city are the lake towns (which are tiny) and the main base. The game needs to be improved in that aspect. Overall I love this game anyway, the game is fun and I rarely have any bugs with this game. Though again it does require patience and a lot of learning.
