number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								From the first time you begin crafting your own vehicle -- varying from seagoing vessels, to aircraft, to spaceborne vehicles, with the promise of land-based vehicles on the way -- it's clear that From the Depths takes the mechanics of crafting your own personal vehicle to an extent that most other games haven't dared. Without naming any names, this isn't a game where you get predefined hulls with a drag-and-drop parts list to min/max stats; instead, you have to build the vehicle from the ground (or keel, as it were) up, making sure to provide it with an engine, an AI system that needs to be wired into the weaponry, and the weaponry itself. And even weapons are completely crafted -- the more powerful or accurate you want it to be, the more resources and room it takes up, forcing players to find the perfect balance between making their ultimate gun(s) or missile launcher(s) and being able to fit it on their hull.The lego-like simplicity of building your ultimate war machine is offset by a few pragmatic concerns you need to observe -- key above all is a physics system requiring balance as a mandatory part of design. Tempting though it may be to make your ship completely out of steel for maximum armor, it will also sink like a brick, maneuver like one, and cost an arm and a leg. And symmetry of design is necessary for the same reason -- making a spaceship that's got a Millennium Falcon-esque vibe to it will lead to tears when you realize that it has an off-center balance.Criticisms for this game, from my perspective, revolve mainly around a few important points. First of all is that, beyond the sandbox building, there isn't much to be seen from a gameplay perspective (YET, if this game's hype doesn't rapidly exceed the creators' abilities). The campaign, such as it is, is an ill-explained board game type strategy game, where you move your fleet around and capture resources. You drop into a fight against enemy ships/aircraft, defeat them, move on. Beyond forcing the player to maintain resource caps, it has no real sense of depth at this stage in development. The other is that, while in some extents the building is great, it falls flat in the departments of variety and (despite praising it before) complexity. There are all of 5 basic block types, and turrets have an unfortunate tendency to look the same, no matter the size, number of barrels, or parent vessel. And while it's neat to have to attach weapons to your AI's mainframe through 'wiring', said wiring comes in the form of specific connector blocks -- forcing you either to build turret mounts bigger and bulkier than you intended to protect these vulnerable pieces (without which your AI can't fire the weapons), or you leave them exposed to enemy counterbattery.How might these issues be corrected? I'm not even gonna play armchair dev and try to say, definitively, what the fixes might be, but I can offer ideas:1.) Allow research and/or 'backwards-engineering' in the campaign. Lock certain pieces (the 'extra' parts that can be attached to an engine to increase its capabilities, i.e. superchargers) and make it possible to either research their usage or capture the technology when fighting enemies. Ditto for varieties of blocks beyond wood.2.) Turn connector pieces into 'wired blocks', with armor available based on base material just like normal building blocks, and in exchange an escalating price scale.Is From the Depths worth it at this point in the cycle? Well, it depends on whether you really enjoy building stuff. If this is your cup of tea, you can sink hours into the 'game' as it stands at the moment. If you (like me) desire a balance between sandboxing and kicking over the castles in the sandbox a few minutes later, the game is far too underdeveloped at this stage... and anyone looking for an action-packed experience is in for a bit of regret.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Game definitely is aimed to the audience, who love voxel, sand box, experimenting and engineering games types, but yet with demanding learning curve. It may appear at beginning this game is difficult to handle, but once you get into it, it is so much fun. There is plenty of tutorials available for new and old comer, on the official forum http://fromthedepthsgame.com/forum/ on Youtube, Steam and what is interesting, in game itself.So what you can do? Well actually A-Lot...1. You can play in creative mode, building your own designs, structures, fortress, vehicles (submarines, naval ships, air ships, space ships, or any of mix of them and more)2. You can play campaign, fight against AI driven factions (player made vehicles), in form of RTS, or/and FPS, while you can develop your own designs and forces, as long you got enough resources.3. Test your own designs against your, or other players' designs. 4. Making your designs to behave, as desired, which may be challenging.5. Design your own weapon systems, both offensive and defensive.6. Setup your vehicles and weapon system AI behaviours.7. Experiment with anything, you got access to.8. Making "block" art.9. And whatever else your imagination allow to ..10. Download and share your designs with the community, on Steam and main forum.11. Share and gain experience with community12. Join player hosted tournaments and test your secret design against other contestants. Results are tend to be uploaded to youtube. For example by TheBudkai, but not only (youtube channel) https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLmkTaK7E7RJouOrgdGANTTna-_5J6fVYL13. On main forum, players opinion really matter. Players have great input, in which games is getting developed. Bugs are dealt very quickly.At some point you may face you know all, when suddenly facing enemy, with stuff, which you are never thought of. Then you may realise, you are barely hit iceberg tip of FTD possibilities :)So what more about my own experience? Oh well, I love this game, since I have gotten it in Feb 2014. Since then FTD is still in Early Access, so it is something to keep in mind. But this means, it is constantly changing, adding more and more fascinating features. Always something new to learn. Cannot get bored, if such games is what you are looking for. I play mainly creative mode, testing game's possibilities, my imaginations  and applying my childhood dreams :)Examples http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197998578301/myworkshopfiles/So what you may need to be aware of, before getting in FTD?1. High learning curve is expected. 2 hours of play, will not give you full FTD experience.2. Imagination is your main limitation.3. I know many players wait for player vs player battles, but unfortunately multiplayer is disabled atm., as it is completely reworked at the current, to handle players better. It will be possible to run also multiplayer campaign, which sound really cool. I have been running few multiplayer events, before this mode has been disabled and they were so much fun, with smaller and bigger vehicles. Some example is here:


YouTube™ Video: From The Depths - Alpha Multiplayer Mass Handling Testing 

			Views: 2,813		

			It contains best and funniest moments of the Multiplayer events from the period of February to March of 2015. Number of people have participated in alpha testing, so I would like to thank you...		

I am waiting, like you may also do, for multi return. This should be soon I hope, with much greater possibilities :)4. Unfortunately, bigger designs and battles, require better PC. So don't expect Bismarck, or Yamato ships run smooth on the low end machine. But running smaller battles, with smaller vehicles run smooth and they can be so much fun. So you don't need high spec machine to enjoy FTD.And there is much more cool things, I can not think about now and I could write ...

Early Access Review
								This game is phenomenal. If you love creating your own, ships, planes or tanks and taking them into satisfying combat where you tear through your opponents machines piece by piece this is a game for you.You can go into so much detail in your designs, from designing your own misslies to fine tuning how your machine's AI works, to deciding where every inch of reactive or heavy armor goes. I could go on for hours but you get the point. If you want to recreate your favourite military vehicles or fantasy craft this game has pretty much got you covered. The options are immense.The campaign is addictive, often involving different factions, each with their own strategies and designs. Some have "stiched together" machines that are made up of the hull parts of their foes and others have marauding mobile fortresses for units. How well you survive is all in how good your designs are. Nearly 600 hours into it and I still find myself coming back for more, much less ever completing the campaigns myself, all ways going back into the design mode to whip up another machine to bring into fray heheh...There is one thing however I hope they improve on. This game has quite a learning curve to overcome. While I think the current tutorials are decent, they can still be improved. I also feel that the build menu interface could also be improved to feel less overwhelming to newcomers. Improving the UI perhaps?That being said, all in all, this game is still amazing and i have never been able enjoy any other "build em up and shoot em down" game as much as I have enjoyed this one. This game goes further and beyond to offer freedom in creation and in depth gameplay. It thoroughly deserves it's place as one of the best games of it's kind.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								From the first time you begin crafting your own vehicle -- varying from seagoing vessels, to aircraft, to spaceborne vehicles, with the promise of land-based vehicles on the way -- it's clear that From the Depths takes the mechanics of crafting your own personal vehicle to an extent that most other games haven't dared. Without naming any names, this isn't a game where you get predefined hulls with a drag-and-drop parts list to min/max stats; instead, you have to build the vehicle from the ground (or keel, as it were) up, making sure to provide it with an engine, an AI system that needs to be wired into the weaponry, and the weaponry itself. And even weapons are completely crafted -- the more powerful or accurate you want it to be, the more resources and room it takes up, forcing players to find the perfect balance between making their ultimate gun(s) or missile launcher(s) and being able to fit it on their hull.The lego-like simplicity of building your ultimate war machine is offset by a few pragmatic concerns you need to observe -- key above all is a physics system requiring balance as a mandatory part of design. Tempting though it may be to make your ship completely out of steel for maximum armor, it will also sink like a brick, maneuver like one, and cost an arm and a leg. And symmetry of design is necessary for the same reason -- making a spaceship that's got a Millennium Falcon-esque vibe to it will lead to tears when you realize that it has an off-center balance.Criticisms for this game, from my perspective, revolve mainly around a few important points. First of all is that, beyond the sandbox building, there isn't much to be seen from a gameplay perspective (YET, if this game's hype doesn't rapidly exceed the creators' abilities). The campaign, such as it is, is an ill-explained board game type strategy game, where you move your fleet around and capture resources. You drop into a fight against enemy ships/aircraft, defeat them, move on. Beyond forcing the player to maintain resource caps, it has no real sense of depth at this stage in development. The other is that, while in some extents the building is great, it falls flat in the departments of variety and (despite praising it before) complexity. There are all of 5 basic block types, and turrets have an unfortunate tendency to look the same, no matter the size, number of barrels, or parent vessel. And while it's neat to have to attach weapons to your AI's mainframe through 'wiring', said wiring comes in the form of specific connector blocks -- forcing you either to build turret mounts bigger and bulkier than you intended to protect these vulnerable pieces (without which your AI can't fire the weapons), or you leave them exposed to enemy counterbattery.How might these issues be corrected? I'm not even gonna play armchair dev and try to say, definitively, what the fixes might be, but I can offer ideas:1.) Allow research and/or 'backwards-engineering' in the campaign. Lock certain pieces (the 'extra' parts that can be attached to an engine to increase its capabilities, i.e. superchargers) and make it possible to either research their usage or capture the technology when fighting enemies. Ditto for varieties of blocks beyond wood.2.) Turn connector pieces into 'wired blocks', with armor available based on base material just like normal building blocks, and in exchange an escalating price scale.Is From the Depths worth it at this point in the cycle? Well, it depends on whether you really enjoy building stuff. If this is your cup of tea, you can sink hours into the 'game' as it stands at the moment. If you (like me) desire a balance between sandboxing and kicking over the castles in the sandbox a few minutes later, the game is far too underdeveloped at this stage... and anyone looking for an action-packed experience is in for a bit of regret.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Game definitely is aimed to the audience, who love voxel, sand box, experimenting and engineering games types, but yet with demanding learning curve. It may appear at beginning this game is difficult to handle, but once you get into it, it is so much fun. There is plenty of tutorials available for new and old comer, on the official forum http://fromthedepthsgame.com/forum/ on Youtube, Steam and what is interesting, in game itself.So what you can do? Well actually A-Lot...1. You can play in creative mode, building your own designs, structures, fortress, vehicles (submarines, naval ships, air ships, space ships, or any of mix of them and more)2. You can play campaign, fight against AI driven factions (player made vehicles), in form of RTS, or/and FPS, while you can develop your own designs and forces, as long you got enough resources.3. Test your own designs against your, or other players' designs. 4. Making your designs to behave, as desired, which may be challenging.5. Design your own weapon systems, both offensive and defensive.6. Setup your vehicles and weapon system AI behaviours.7. Experiment with anything, you got access to.8. Making "block" art.9. And whatever else your imagination allow to ..10. Download and share your designs with the community, on Steam and main forum.11. Share and gain experience with community12. Join player hosted tournaments and test your secret design against other contestants. Results are tend to be uploaded to youtube. For example by TheBudkai, but not only (youtube channel) https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLmkTaK7E7RJouOrgdGANTTna-_5J6fVYL13. On main forum, players opinion really matter. Players have great input, in which games is getting developed. Bugs are dealt very quickly.At some point you may face you know all, when suddenly facing enemy, with stuff, which you are never thought of. Then you may realise, you are barely hit iceberg tip of FTD possibilities :)So what more about my own experience? Oh well, I love this game, since I have gotten it in Feb 2014. Since then FTD is still in Early Access, so it is something to keep in mind. But this means, it is constantly changing, adding more and more fascinating features. Always something new to learn. Cannot get bored, if such games is what you are looking for. I play mainly creative mode, testing game's possibilities, my imaginations  and applying my childhood dreams :)Examples http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197998578301/myworkshopfiles/So what you may need to be aware of, before getting in FTD?1. High learning curve is expected. 2 hours of play, will not give you full FTD experience.2. Imagination is your main limitation.3. I know many players wait for player vs player battles, but unfortunately multiplayer is disabled atm., as it is completely reworked at the current, to handle players better. It will be possible to run also multiplayer campaign, which sound really cool. I have been running few multiplayer events, before this mode has been disabled and they were so much fun, with smaller and bigger vehicles. Some example is here:


YouTube™ Video: From The Depths - Alpha Multiplayer Mass Handling Testing 

			Views: 2,813		

			It contains best and funniest moments of the Multiplayer events from the period of February to March of 2015. Number of people have participated in alpha testing, so I would like to thank you...		

I am waiting, like you may also do, for multi return. This should be soon I hope, with much greater possibilities :)4. Unfortunately, bigger designs and battles, require better PC. So don't expect Bismarck, or Yamato ships run smooth on the low end machine. But running smaller battles, with smaller vehicles run smooth and they can be so much fun. So you don't need high spec machine to enjoy FTD.And there is much more cool things, I can not think about now and I could write ...

								I'm pretty new to Steam, So many people would probobly ignore this review.That out of the way I give Ftd 10/10From the Depths is why I joined the Steam community. (As Nick, The Awesome dev behind this marvel, Moved it to Steam)The Amazing thing about this game is there are HUNDREDS of blocks and modules, each with there respective purpose and resource cost. content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Absolutely fantastic. 10/10. Early access done right.From the Depths, despite its blocky appearance, is a startlingly original game. From the construction features to the customizable combat AI, almost everything in From the Depths is innovative, exciting, and easy to use. In practice, many games in the construction genre tend to fall flat in certain areas. Unlike these, From the Depths is already well optimized, intuitive, and fun. From the Depths construction mechanic is unique, allowing extremely complex ideas to be easily realized. Unlike space engineers and many similar construction games, FTD's construction system is fluid, polished, and robust. Creating complex vehicles such as airships and battleships is easy enough- play the game, familiarize yourself with the mechanics, and boom! There you have it. That's all the experience you need to build something cool in From the Depths. Building something that works really well, however, is more difficult. The good news is, you'll never runout of ideas because From the Depth's extremely in-depth armor and weapons mechanics allow for hundreds of viable strategies.  Hollow armor designed to absorb enemy damage and insulate the core systems? Check. A floating reactor, relying on its powerful shields to rain death from above? Check. A wooden sailboat? Check. Several hundred wooden sailboats? Double check. Combat itself is no less impressive. The AI works surprisingly well out of the box. Because vehicles in From the Depths rely on many individual systems to continue working, combat in From the Depths is always dynamic and interesting. Aircraft usually rely on their speed to outrun danger, casting their lot on large engines and light armor. Landing a hit on an aircraft's jets is often enough to send them into a tailspin. Knock out the engines, and the battle's already won. Target a craft's radar and sensors, and leave a battleship blind. If you're brave enough, it's possible to go one step further and knock out a ship's master AI control. Target the propellers with torpedoes, and leave your enemies paralyzed. The possibilities are quite literally endless. When played In first person, From the Depths can become a fantastic roll-playing game. Ignoring the campaign, From the Depths is a fantastic sandbox. Ignoring the construction, From the Depths is a damn good action-RPG.What I'm trying to get across here is that From the Depths is fun. Like, really fun. Everything works, and the price is right.Do yourself a favor and buy it.

Early Access Review
								Well what can i say about this game, mmmm not much bad to be honest, dont get me wrong its not 100% perfect but if you like construction games this one is a dam good catch, not just for the price but the content also.The construction on this game has a very good depth to it, from building engines to your own needs to creating your own guns and lasers. i have only really made boats and flyers on this game but loved every minute creating and sinking ships and other strange flying and submersable contraptions. The combat system takes some getting used to, let me try to explain...: basicly you start with a base in campaign mode and a crappy small ship, so you need to get your fleets going asap and consider a base but its the combat you need to understand in this, you build a fleet or in my case in campaign i make just one beast of a ship and start to capture the map (i cant remamber the name of the 1st map but its huge), each zone has a number rateing which determins the strength of the fleet guarding it, you enter the sqaure the fleet spawns in and you battle it out, if you win the number vanishes and you move around the map looking for bases, but be warned if you pass into a sqaure owned by somebody friendly your rateing starts to drop and that side will declare war on you and thats how you try to get around the campaign mode, but you will need wit and stratedgy to survive or in my case really big BIG ships. its when you enter combat it gets strange though, when the fight starts for me my ships so big only 2 or 3 enemy ships will show and the others will be wire frame boxs on standby, when you destroy the ships you see the wire frome boxs turn into ships and start to attack, so for me fleet battles with my beast ships become more like survival mode, at first i will admit i didnt like this system but once i got to grips with it began to love the how the f$&k did my ship survuve that crap holy....., and some bases you just cant hit head on or your fleet/ship will very quickly become large holes. theres numerous ways to conquer campaign mode but how or what you build is up to you completly, make an armada of subs, ships aircraft and even space craft its left to you how to destroy the enemy.the constructer is quite a complex place even with the large number of tutorials and i WARN you here there is a large learning curve so expect to be watching lots of you tube videos to learn how some things work. once you get past the basics before you know it you will be makeing all sorts of crazy ideas and mad weapons, the creators hard but works very well once you learn whats what.over all i have loved this game from the start and would recommend it to any creative mind and construction nut, i havn't tryed story yet im still in campaign lol and developing more machines, but for the money this game is well worth the learning curve, just show it some patience and have you tube and google on stand by lol, any hows good luck if you get this game i hope you enjoy it half as much as i have 10/10.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is awesome. I don't think there is any other game out there where you can design a cannon that can punch through the armour of a warship, then add a fuze that makes the shell explode inside the target ship for lots of damage, then mount that cannon on a turret on an airship, aircraft, or just a regular old cruiser. Then design a gatling gun to take out aircraft, build a laser system to shoot down incoming missiles, and then switch gears and build a submarine that launches torpedos loaded with EMP charges that zap through metal armour to take out the electronics controlling turrets and weapons, or the ship itself.The best part is that everything is built out of blocks that interact with each other so that the effect of the damage on subsystems can be interesting as well e.g. if an explosion takes out a chunk of your engine, the effect varies whether it manages to break the crankshaft in two, takes out exhaust piping, etc.This game requires a lot of patience though, the learning curve is steep. My very first ship would flip over the moment it hit the water. That said if you like building and designing it is well worth it. 233 hours in and still having a lot of fun with this game. I think that stands for itself.P.S. There are some really useful guides on the various systems in the game on the official forum, I suggest taking a look once you've gotten your feet wet. Looking at designs there was a great way to get inspiration for hull shapes and weapon systems as well. Also, if you're like me, I suggest looking at some of the engine collections on the Steam workshop, there are some well made and optimized engines e.g. KuramaFox's unified engine raft. I like to pick a pre-made design that suits my needs (high-efficiency, high-power, or small size?) for my ships on so I can focus on other things, like fine tuning cannons or designing torpedoes or a laser system. OTOH you might find that you enjoy building and tuning engines ...there's a lot of content in this game.Lastly, it helps to start small. Try building small boats and airships and work your way up from there.

								FtD is simply amazing.  It blends Minecraft with EvE with Robocraft and gives you the freedom to build like very few wannabe "sandbox" games actually deliver on.  Planes, boats, subs, spacecraft...all wrapped up with a good physics engine and in Voxel style.All this comes with a price - it makes Dwarf Fortress's learning curve look like an ice skating rink and will obliterate your computer's processing power even on a top gaming rig (at highest settings).However, if you are willing to put in the time (and have the hardware), I'm sure you could spend literally thousands of hours on this - and that's just it's state now in Alpha.  An early access that, for once, is worth more than the price tag...and by a huge margin!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was told by a good friend of mine to get From the Depths, and I never even heard of the game at the time, so I took a gamble and purchased the game. That gamble certainly paid off after messing around for a couple hours.From the Depths is by far the best Early Access sandbox game I have played so far. There are tons of features to choose from, and the possibilies are endless. I can see myself spending hours playing this game and still have a good time. This game has TONS of potential to be a really good sandbox game, and I can not wait until the full release of this game. The graphics may not be the greatest thing, and the UI and HUD could use some work too, but I can't say too much because it's still in Early Access.Final Score: 8/10A great sandbox game with tons of potential.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Like many other people, I initially assumed this was just another minecraft clone when I first saw it. Oh how wrong I was. When I first got it, after viewing a few youtube videos, I tried building my first ship. As you may know from reading the other comments on this game, it's learning curve is more like a cliff, and I started playing before a proper tutorial system had been implemented. So, my first ship barely floated. Not wanting to give up, I removed its weapons, and reverse engineered another ship I had seen on youtube to get it to work. Finally, after about 3 days of experimenting, I finally got I working, and watched as it destroyed just about everything the starting faction could throw at it. I still use that ship in my campiagns, hours of tweaking, testing and modifing mean its one of the most cost effective vehicles I have, and I have built dozens of variants.From The Depths has become my favorite game by far, and even after hundreds of hours, I am still finding new things to do, from submarines to spaceships, and has a very dedicated team of developers, who are seemingly always working on one thing or another. It does have a few shortfalls, such as its fairly basic sound effects, but all together it is a very good game, and is only going to get better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								FtD is simply amazing.  It blends Minecraft with EvE with Robocraft and gives you the freedom to build like very few wannabe "sandbox" games actually deliver on.  Planes, boats, subs, spacecraft...all wrapped up with a good physics engine and in Voxel style.All this comes with a price - it makes Dwarf Fortress's learning curve look like an ice skating rink and will obliterate your computer's processing power even on a top gaming rig (at highest settings).However, if you are willing to put in the time (and have the hardware), I'm sure you could spend literally thousands of hours on this - and that's just it's state now in Alpha.  An early access that, for once, is worth more than the price tag...and by a huge margin!

Early Access Review
								This game is the sheer definition of the term "Just 5 more minutes" I may not have many hours into this game but from what I can tell so far it has a LOT going for it. It has quite of a learning curve to master with alot of things but that's the fun thing about this game. It challenges you to evolve and adapt because I will tell you from experience enemies will get harder and its the most infuriating thing losing a ship because of a simple armor flaw. This game has made me smile, and made me wanna throw my keyboard out the window.PROS:+Boat physics+Very rewarding gameplay+CANNONS OUT THE WAZOO+Many different types of weaponsto dispatch your foes+Never stops challenging you to do bigger and better+VERY ADDICTINGCONS:-Learning curve can be abit much if your not willing toput the time in and learn-Ship balancing can be a tad annoying sometimes if you don't knowwtf your doing-It will eat your life, your dog, your family, it will consume everything you'veever loved in life and make you it's ♥♥♥♥♥. (It's addicting as hell.)CONCLUSION:              This game is the single thing that allows me to express my love for battleships and naval power in that regard.If you like building ships and being able to control every little thing about how a ship behaves, build cannons that fityour specific needs, or wanna have fun building a metal box armed with frag missiles, PLEASE BUY THIS GAME. 9/10

content:

Early Access Review
								I've put a decent chunk of time into this game and I would recommend it to anyone who read the description and found it even a little bit interesting.The vehicle designer, where the vast majority of my game time has been spent, is superb. There's a lot of complexity that can be drawn out of it, but it's simple enough for most new players and in a solid hour or so you'll have most of the core mechanics down I'd say. Take a look at the workshop and you'll see just how varied and detailed the designs can be. The combat is a lot of fun, though very large battles are total processor hogs and you will get slowdown.There's a great community, I recommend heading over to the forums and lurk around for a bit to get a better idea of things if you're on the fence about it.Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								My take on From the Depths	First, allow me to come out and say this, the developers of this game are on the verge of something big in my opinion. This game is truly special in three ways.1. It balances the complexity with the playability.	This is probably the thing I love most about this game. Nothing is all in one piece. Everything from canons, to engines, to AIs must be built by the player, and can be built in any way that the player sees fit. However, at the same time the game is very comprehensive. At first the player may get completely lost in the complexity, but the wide range of tutorials allows for a quick understanding of the games mechanics, and allows the player to get in the game rather quickly.2. It merges sandbox gameplay with strategic gameplay.	This game feels as though it is a cross between Minecraft and Command and Conquer. You command the vehicles that you built, and with eight different factions to fight, your strategies and vehicles change constantly to combat your foes strengths, and exploit their weaknesses. Everything you do or build is a strategic choice, which is what primarily makes this game so unique.3. There is plenty of room for creativity.	Although the game is widely based on strategy, the block-based building allows for an infinite amount of possibilities as to what the player can create. There are nearly no restrictions on what you can or can’t build...so go ahead, build that flying unicorn you’ve always dreamed of!	With qualities like these, the game is bound for greatness. If you (the developers) can maintain these three key traits, then you will likely create an extremely successful game.

content:

Early Access Review
								First, let me get this out of the way:The tutorials work, but they're ATROCIOUS.Quizzes?? I hate how if you get an answer wrong, like a real first-timer would, you miss out on experience. Also, quizzes! In a game! The tutorials that show you how systems work by building the model are alright but the camera control sucks in that too, try and look around AND click next.. you'll end up losing your view every time. Aside from those the game is unlike any other in the level of customizing and systems that can all work together! I love how I can do all this stuff.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I don't like long reviews, so I'm going to keep it nice, short, and simple:Pros-1) Fun; I love to build a random ship and just sail around islands with it.2) Ultimate customization; You can customize almost anything in this game.3) Multiplayer; Very fun to have battles with your friends in Montana-class battleships.4) Vehicles; From ships to planes, tanks and more, you can build just about anything that gets you moving or you take for shelter.Cons-1) Graphics; It's in Alpha, so there will of course be better graphics soon.2) Visible character in first person; This one is a really small one, just annoying. I put it here so it's just not one con for the game.Over all, I give this game a 9/10 because it is just what I want from a game about building things.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Very intriguing so far.Unlike most games nowadays, you actually have to learn how to play this game before actually playing it. Luckily, there's a wealth of in-game resources to teach you, including: step-by-step demos, in-game tutorial sessions, and quizzes after each section. Yup. Quizzes. You get EXP for getting questions right.And that's all justified, because FtD is a very complicated and deep game that gives you a ton of flexible tools to play with. Far more difficult to learn than anything like Space Engineers, so if that was too cerebral for you--avoid FtD.I'm still doing tutorials and learning how to play at the time of writing this (5hrs), and I'll write more as I go.EDIT: I still really don't understand how to 'play' the game. Still recommending, just go into it knowing that it's got a very steep learning curve. 2 steep 4 me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Definately ranks in the top three best games that I have ever played, the key based building system is intuitive, the campaign is fun, and the soundtrack is great. On top of that the community is responsive, and only has one or two trolls. Plus the devloper is constantly active and updates the game regularly. And while it does have quite a learning curve, it's justified by the fact that there is just SOOO much you can do, want to build a duck shaped spaceship powered by the recoil of a 2000mm cannon? you can do that, want to build a super battleship armed with railguns that grows legs and walks? you can do that too. 9001/10 would buy again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								Complex and awesome.This one is a treat for anyone who likes to sink endless hours into creating and improving all kinds of vehicles. I've already spent more than 60 hours in the editor, had tremendous fun and didn't even start the campaign yet. I guess it will be quite difficult to balance game conent properly as there are so many degrees of freedom but the game would worth it if there was just a sandbox mode. With so many possibilities there comes a learning curve, but it's never overwhelming and more a 'hard to master' thing. The basic features can be learned quickly and it's quite satisfying to get your first vehicles working properly. The interface and tools are quite well thought out; even huge vehicles can be edited quite comfortably thanks to things like prefabricated parts, mirrors and flood fill. Performance is quite alright even on an older rig and i managed to crash the game only once.Already one of my all-time-favourites (in more than 25 years of gaming) - definitely recommended for anyone into this sort of game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let me level with you. This game has a learning curve, and a somewhat steep one. But if you're like me and you're never happy with your somehow-floating-somehow-able-to-survive-metal-rectangles you'll eventually feel on top of the world, like the campaign of Neter and it's sprawling seas have nothing that could match you. You'll build magnificent, beautiful war machines that are equal parts art and lethal design. You'll tweak your ships thousands of times and go through hundreds of iterations until you feel like you can stop and move on to the next one, and you'll spend days on that one too. Then an update will come out, and you have to rebuild your whole 20+ ship fleet and restart your 30+ hour campaign file.10/10 Nick, I love you.

Early Access Review
								The level of customization in this game is staggering. You craft each hull, each weapon, each engine block by block to get exactly the performace you want out of your ship. And then you get to ride it into battle and test your design against warships, submarines, airships, spaceships, planes, fortresses, and any other kind of craft you can imagine. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dont normally write reviews, this game deserves it. Hours in game speaks for itself.  Currently 322 hours in-game, which is more than 95% of the games in my library. I think I bought this gaen for full price at 19.99 but it is currently on sale for like $4 or something. At $4 that means $1 for 80 hours of entertainment.Simple math says I have really gotten my moneys worth, and its true. One of the most fun games I think I have ever played. I have at least 100 games in my library I paid $40+ for and didnt play for more than 20 hrs.If you have an OCD personality that loves to figure out how complicated systems work, this game will entertain you for weeks.For the amount of money this game costs, there is incredible depth to the game system design that most games do not approach including games with tens of millions of dollars of development budget.This is made by a small indie developer that deserves and has earned my patronage, and imo deserves yours as well.Pros:*Vehicle design lab lets you build and test your designs against a library of enemies I have collected so I can see how various defensive/offensive systems work*Very complex weapon systems that allow you to fine tune almost any aspect of behavior*Layers of offensive and defensive systems, not every weapon works in every situation and likewise not every defensive system will save you from every weapon*Physics based so if you are building a ship, sub, aircraft or spacecraft you have to balance your mass, deal with drag surfaces, pitch, roll, and yaw, and figure out how to balance power requirements, propulsion, and attitude thrust*Some cool sci-fi ish things like lasers, ion cannon, warp drives, rail guns*Customizeable AI behaviors so you can turn them on or off to suit your needs, make a few drones and set them on auto while you manage your feel or build something new*Supply resources that can be set in global or local mode - you can choose if you want to make your game harder by have resources localized so you cant just insta build a huge asset far from your supply lines without bringing those supplies there - you have to protect your supply assets*Watching 60 VLS missles, cannons, lasers, and all manner of weaponry firing simultaneously is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic*Much moreCons:*Small team so development takes time, I personally think with more resources this game, which is already worth far more than is being charged for it, could be truly amazing*Multiplayer is limited to a few people where one person hosts the server and is pretty jankyu right now in campaign mode, lots of save corruption and at times the players get de-synched from the server and really wierd♥♥♥♥♥♥happens - if these guys can fix the multiplayer though omg badass

Early Access Review
								FTD .. what can i say .. i suppose the best way i would describe it is .. hmm its kinda like a RTS that you can make your own units with .. And when i say that i don't just mean stick generic turret A on ship base D and that is your ship .. oh no oh very much no..You have to design EVERYTHING in your vessel .. from its hull block by block to its engines, guns, defences EVERYTHING.. Game is a little technical at first but there are plenty of videos and forum's to look at for help or insperation. The community is one of the best i have ever come across in my 25 year + of playing video games and the developer is active as hell and is in constant communication with the community.In short is FTD worth it .. hell yes if you like the design and building of your own death dealing monster machines of doom 11/10 easy,  game is  smart  ( see what i did there nick ;) )

								Buy this if you:- are into Sandbox Games - are into Physics-based Games - have a lot of time (see playhours in other reviews)- have at least a middle class PC (bc graphics arn't optimized)- don't mind those fairly simple graphics- are really into digging and exploring gameplay mechanics (you could easily get a diploma when you build really big ships, airplanes or even Spaceships)- have a good failure tolerance as you need some time to get things work properly---> simply look at the hours spent on this game on some reviews and THEN compare it to it's price (with sale it's only 3,99€ so go get it)Things that are♥♥♥♥♥♥or at least bothering (now and in my honest opnion):-AI from ships is very .... dumb ._. --> they keep crashing into eachother; the other AI's arn't very better (with the Land-AI beeing an exception here as i currently didn't used it) wich makes some battle with many same vehicles ... well .... *insert insult here*- the sounds are okayyy but thats it- veeeryy complex (look up the number of blocks and then immediatly bookmark the wiki)- likes to crash from time to time (well it's Early Acces and produced by a two-man-army)- the menus are not beautifal but very functional (again, my opinion)If you are interested, then go get it, totally worth it's price!

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game will brutally beat you over the head with its learning curve until you are lying helpless and bereft of hair on your keyboard. You will cry, you will scratch your head, you will watch tens of hours of youtube tutorials and let's plays, you will burn out google's servers trying to find a solution to your very specific niche problem. I assure you, your efforts are futile.BUTIf you put in the effort, if you make the commitment, if you can see how much potential this game really has, your blood, your sweat, and your tears will be rewarded in ways no words can describe. Ever orbited your first probe in Kerbal Space Program? Ever completed the entire Besiege campaign with a single design? Ever survived your first winter in Don't Starve? Ever beaten a long standing record in Super Hexagon? These are the feelings of elation you will receive when your first little ship stays afloat and is balanced, when it takes its first little strides all on its AI driven own, when it takes control of that gun and uses it effectively against a target, when you win your first battle in the campaign.These and many more glorious moments will be yours, friend.If you have the time, the will and the intellect, this game is worth every bitcoin.

								A wonderful game. If you can crawl past the steep learning curve this game has, you will have a blast and have nearly infinite replayable value. Developer and forms are active, and the game is getting new updates often. I have high hopes for this game in the future, with it's many diffrent multiplayer modes, dynamic caimpain, and level designer where you can put together a living world where the factions (consitting of the ships that you made and put together)  will go around creating bases, fleet and baracades to win over the map. You can play the ships manually making it a action game, or put AI on them and turn it into a stratigic skrimish where you send multiple fleet at once to engage the enemy. Constinting of airplanes, boat, subs, spaceships, and many other possable builds (hopefully land based vehicles in the future) I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not just-another-build-and-fight, this actually does a pretty good job in the physics department.Basically you can design a land, sea, air and/or spacevehicle (literally all 4 of em at once is quite the challenge), move it around and fight other players, or have AI control it and play it as though it were an RTS.Resource collection, build and supply vehicles, fight, design your own guns, engines and all that, all thats missing is what some would call atmospherics, dynamic fluids, pipes, electrical grids and the likes, but that may just destroy this whole concept...Sorry, just missing that in todays games, too much focus on multiplayer at the expense of engineering aspects...but thats just my personal.At the moment it is still in alpha and it's noticable; It demands a lot from ones computer unless you limit yourself to the editor or a campaign. Doing missions is quite impossible for me at the moment. Since some technology can only be unlocked in missions there are some things I simply cannot use. Great concept, reasonable implementation, but at the moment has some serious performance issues which will (hopefully) be resolved in the next couple of updates. As always, looking forward to seeing more on this project.On a sidenote, I may have been somewhat inconsistant in my recommendations about this specific game. I am sorry for that, it may create confusion and some people may judge me for that, and that is fine. I write these reviews based on my experiences with the project it involves, and in this case I have had faith in the development of this project, lost it, and now regained it.I maintain quite a few reviews, and usually after playing the game it involves for a while. For those who have seen my library it would not take much to understand why it can take a long time before I return to a previous review and check if it still applies. I do check them occasionally, but rarely find myself rewriting or editing one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is awesome. I don't think there is any other game out there where you can design a cannon that can punch through the armour of a warship, then add a fuze that makes the shell explode inside the target ship for lots of damage, then mount that cannon on a turret on an airship, aircraft, or just a regular old cruiser. Then design a gatling gun to take out aircraft, build a laser system to shoot down incoming missiles, and then switch gears and build a submarine that launches torpedos loaded with EMP charges that zap through metal armour to take out the electronics controlling turrets and weapons, or the ship itself.The best part is that everything is built out of blocks that interact with each other so that the effect of the damage on subsystems can be interesting as well e.g. if an explosion takes out a chunk of your engine, the effect varies whether it manages to break the crankshaft in two, takes out exhaust piping, etc.This game requires a lot of patience though, the learning curve is steep. My very first ship would flip over the moment it hit the water. That said if you like building and designing it is well worth it. 233 hours in and still having a lot of fun with this game. I think that stands for itself.P.S. There are some really useful guides on the various systems in the game on the official forum, I suggest taking a look once you've gotten your feet wet. Looking at designs there was a great way to get inspiration for hull shapes and weapon systems as well. Also, if you're like me, I suggest looking at some of the engine collections on the Steam workshop, there are some well made and optimized engines e.g. KuramaFox's unified engine raft. I like to pick a pre-made design that suits my needs (high-efficiency, high-power, or small size?) for my ships on so I can focus on other things, like fine tuning cannons or designing torpedoes or a laser system. OTOH you might find that you enjoy building and tuning engines ...there's a lot of content in this game.Lastly, it helps to start small. Try building small boats and airships and work your way up from there.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								My take on From the Depths	First, allow me to come out and say this, the developers of this game are on the verge of something big in my opinion. This game is truly special in three ways.1. It balances the complexity with the playability.	This is probably the thing I love most about this game. Nothing is all in one piece. Everything from canons, to engines, to AIs must be built by the player, and can be built in any way that the player sees fit. However, at the same time the game is very comprehensive. At first the player may get completely lost in the complexity, but the wide range of tutorials allows for a quick understanding of the games mechanics, and allows the player to get in the game rather quickly.2. It merges sandbox gameplay with strategic gameplay.	This game feels as though it is a cross between Minecraft and Command and Conquer. You command the vehicles that you built, and with eight different factions to fight, your strategies and vehicles change constantly to combat your foes strengths, and exploit their weaknesses. Everything you do or build is a strategic choice, which is what primarily makes this game so unique.3. There is plenty of room for creativity.	Although the game is widely based on strategy, the block-based building allows for an infinite amount of possibilities as to what the player can create. There are nearly no restrictions on what you can or can’t build...so go ahead, build that flying unicorn you’ve always dreamed of!	With qualities like these, the game is bound for greatness. If you (the developers) can maintain these three key traits, then you will likely create an extremely successful game.

								So today I thought that I would write another review, and I thought I would do it on a game that I recently have really quite enjoyed, From The Depths. This game is for sure complex when first starting out on it and it has a large learning curve, but once it is mastered, it is a hella lot of fun. Basics of it is building your own vehicle, such as a boat, airship, plane, submarine, almost anything you want and then it gets raided by AI armies. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								For me, the quality and value of an Early Access game is represented primarily by two things: the state of the current build and the level of involvement of the dev(s) within the community. The latter I believe is the foundation of a healthy community for pretty much all indie games.♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off and unpassionate devs tend to result in a community with a black cloud lingering above it. I think these aspects are about 50/50% as far as importance to me, with either not being fulfilled to some degree usually being a dealbreaker for me. The software usually stands up to the test, but in cases where the devs are not involved with the community or updates come at barely a trickle or seem non-existant, I usually expect that there will be no or a poor community and and that can ultimately lead to an EA game which feels like it ever reaching beta, let alone a release build which the majority of players will be happy with, starts to become more and more of a longshot (i.e. Blockscape, Castle Story, Spacebase DF-9).I've managed to sample every voxel sandbox game I can get my hands on and for a time now, my favorites have been Space Engineers and 7 Days To Die. They're both great games with great devs and communities. That was, until I found From The Depths. What is missing from Space Engineers (albeit is on the way), currently, are things to do WITH the ships and stations you've built (a campaign) and a block-based AI system and AI factions to assign ships to so you can fight, create fleets, etc. Well, those are the things this game has in spades. The AI isn't perfect yet, but I must say it was very impressive to see how diverse and powerful the options for configuring the AI actually are and just how very functional it is already. Other than an issue with aircraft occasionally colliding or hanging up wings with other craft in their own fleet, I haven't seen anything else wrong with the AI at all. The tools you need to build incredibly complex, functional, and automated vehicles are all there. You are limited only by the block count your PC can display and your own imagination.The learning curve doesn't feel terribly steep either relative to the rather deep complexity provided by the sheer number of building options you have. The game has a very well-designed tutorial system accessible from right in the relevant block selection tabs. These tutorial vignettes show you a quick reference of how to block out each of a vehicle's subsystems, such as engines, aircraft, spin blocks and rotor blades (for helicopters), turrets, custom cannons and missles, etc., so you should rarely feel confused as to how to go about implementing each in your own designs. It's really very easy to pick up, hard to put back down, and difficult to master. I also cannot speak highly enough about what I have seen from the game's creator Nick Smart either. Normally, I'd say that a game like this on Early Access is a gamble on what may be potential shovelware and probably not worth the risk except in rare cases, but I feel this game really is one of those rarities. I was really shocked by how communicative, helpful and just overall the presence he has on the official forums. After a cursory skim of the forums, I was genuinely convinced that he loves this game and it is apparent that it is so much more than just a job/paycheck to him. I would dare say that he *gasp* actually plays his own game. I have yet to come across a single instance in which he responded negatively to a request or inquiry. Surprisingly, he is very much a yes man who is at the same time capable of following through. If you have a good idea that is even mildly popular among the other forum members and it is possible to implement, it is probably going to actually end up in the game over the course of the next build or three. I simply can't assign enough value to that.There are currently three game modes:> Vehicle Designer - The creative mode of the game. This is where most people will probably spend the bulk of their time. You can use all blocks save the couple advanced ones which must be unlocked (see Story Mode below) and have unlimited resources at your disposal. Here you can save and load any designs you've built as well as any of the massive number of designs you can download off the Steam Workshop. There are also a nice selection of designs that are used by the campaign factions and you can load them up in here to play around with/reverse engineer them as well. Spectating or participating in AI battles is possible by loading the designs and assigning them to one of the enemy factions. Every design is contained in a data.txt file that you can easily share with others without using the Steam Workshop at all.> Story Mode - Each of the enemy factions has it's own set of story missions which are unique scenarios in which you are given a task to complete (i.e. destroy a ship) and an RP (resource point) limit that you can spend to create the craft(s) to complete the task. There are currently 4 advanced block types to unlock by completing their respective missions, so new players will probably want to at least complete those 4 to unlock those blocks for use in the Campaign. Each mission has it's own default fleet, which you can (and should) customize to your liking, however, you can scrap the defaults altogether and use the RP to build a completely new design from scratch if you so choose. There are currently only a handful of Story Mode missions available, but the UI shows a lot of space for more beneath the existing ones, so I'm going to assume that many more are planned for the future. Though not very plentiful, these are highly replayable since there are just so many ways you could go about it. > Campaign - In this mode, you start out with a single Skyfortress (a floating structure/base) parked over a lone Resource Zone and one of the several enemy factions is hostile towards you. Hitting the [M] key will delight you with a strategic map of the entire planet, which shows all the other Resource Zones, enemies' bases and fleet locations, as well as all of the planet's landmasses. You are not given any set goals or required to do anything, although the one faction who is hostile will start sending fleets your way in due time to try and wipe you out, so building a vehicle with weapons to defend yourself and/or outfitting your Skyfortress with some long range weapons would be wise. The other non-hostile factions will not try to attack you until provoked, so the safest (probably intended) method of progression is to whittle each faction down one at time until you control the entire map, but that is up to you, you could also declare war on all of them if you are fond of a difficult challenge and are not terribly frightened of watery graves.To address the issue of performance being affected by how many blocks are in play at a given time, the game features a rather clever method of solving it. Each of your fleets can be in one of two states: either in play (visble and fully interactable) or pulled from play. When pulled, fleets are not rendered or affected by physics, but can still be moved using the strategic map, and in the case of skyfortresses, can still collect resources if parked in an RZ. Enemy fleets are always pulled from play until you engage them by moving one of your fleets into range (there's a large cyan ring around each fleet to indicate this range) or they move within range of one of your fleets on their own. If all fleets are pulled, you have available two additional timescale options from within the map: 4x and 10x. This addresses the issue of a very slow fleet needing to move great distances and it not really being too fun to sit and watch at 1x. The campaign has three different difficulty sliders, each of which affects either the enemies or economy so you can fine tune the campaign to be as easy or hard as you'd like.Overall, I am blown away by just how addictive this game is.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Absolutely fantastic game. Nothing bad to say about it except that it needs some optimisations, as it can get very laggy very quickly, especially with very large battles (I'm looking at you, Onyx Watch trade fleets). But otherwise it is completely amazing, in every respect: excellent sandbox play where you really can build whatever the hell you want and the best part is that it actually matters what you build - you need to pay real attention to aero- and hydro-dynamics, center of mass, center of thrust, buoyancy, weight, size, and so forth before even beginning with the weapons aspect. This may make it sound boring but trust me, the building system is utterly engrossing and before you know it hours upon hours of your time will have been spent making something that turns out to work spectacularly badly. And you'll keep coming back for more, because when the program you wrote in-game fires the missiles that you built and designed in game from the launcher that you designed (mounted on the ship that you built), and guides them perfectly into the ammunition storage of an enemy jet streaking overhead... it's so very very worth it.TL;DR: BUY IT BUY IT BUY IT BUY IT

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has an awesome amount of freedom and fidelity with every build. You want to build a to-scale Bismark? Go ahead. How about a Man of War from the age of sail, but with a massive two-tone laser? Why not? Apache Attack Helicopter? Check. A massive airship, the likes of which the world has never seen, that remains aloft using hundreds of thrusters? Yep. Now tanks, racecars, and mobile bunkers are a reality as well.The fact that this game is still in alpha blows my mind. The idea that there will continue to be more and more content added to this already wonderfully deep and complex game is fantastic.Don't let the complexity put you off. Building a raft bristling with homing missles, for example, is quite simple and effective. And who doesn't like to obliterate their foes with swarms of missiles streaking through the sky?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Updating this review...Pros:- Player feedback is asked for and listened to- They're adding player mods that are deemed good into the game, accelerating the development by letting YOU participate in it.- Customizability^4- Actively developed - Coop / vs with people you invite- Great tutorialsCons: Some graphics things:- No graphic transitions between land, water and vehicles. You know... Eye candy that pretends to be physics.- Inventory is just text, no fancy images (icons)- I'd like to see some permanent effects on the terrain if/when I crash a flying fortress into it. (EDIT: Turns out the code for terrain damage already exists, but it's turned off. Dev response was about new components taking priority. Can't blame.).Don't get scared off by "hard to learn" reviews. Your in-game failures don't make you angry because there are no serious consequences. And if you DO get angry, you get to know the reason and the solution for it. There's no grinding for days to get what you want. Your progress is not limited by the hours you put into the game. This also means that if you don't progress at all, the game won't punish you. For example, I went into designer mode, built my boat, spawned some enemy ships, got obliterated in seconds, sunk my character to the bottom of the sea and spawned some planes and submarines of a third fraction to destroy the one that killed my ship. I could respawn my ship at any time but I enjoyed watching their combat with camera detached from my character! There are A LOT of other designs you can watch do battle. Or spawn them as your own and reverse-engineer some things :DYou can also go and do different story missions and scenarios. You can set the difficulty EXACTLY the way you want it. Ever bothered you that enemies on "hard" do more damage than you with the same weapons? You can tone that down or even turn the odds in your favor. You think that salvaging enemies is unfair? Make vehicles worth less or no resources when destroyed. Etc.The game is Alpha. Might get more expensive upon release. It doesn't have a demo version so I waited for it to come on a big discount. Bought it on 80% off and I have a great time with it. Worth the full price. Might buy it again if I convince a friend to play it someday.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is PHENOMINAL, I get on it once a week or more if i have an idea to build. In this game you can build ships, oil rigs, island bases, aircraft, and submarines, atleast so far you can but i dont know what the devs are planning on doing with it. If you are creative, this game is for you, if you aren't creative like, like me, this game is for you, if you want to build a big *** space laser of death, THIS GAME IS FOR YOU. There are no limits on what you can build in this game, it's kind of like minecraft except that you can sail the boats you make. Now, after getting the good things out of the way, let us discuss the bad, this game requires a marginally good pc to run some of the big builds, so one of my friends i got the game for could not play so I was slightly saddened. The ai in this game is kind of hard to make function or atleast, thats my experience. That is my review on this amazing game and i hope to continue playing for many many hours.

								Dont get this game if your not willing to climb the learning curve.This game is the best block-based vehicle game i have seen so far. Even though it has blocks (no circles for the charm of it), it is still a creative way for designers, hobbyists, and engineers to indulge in their imagnation. content:

Early Access Review
								While this game may be very frustrating at times and is kinda hard to learn, it is worth it when you make your first working plane, laser, cannon, whatever. It has ridiculous customization, so you could if you wanted to, have a giant boat that looks like a sheep fighting a submarine that looks like pikatchu that spawns miniature goat subs.The campaigns people make can provide a challenge, too. Don't get too mad if it crashes... it does that alot.From the Depths has a very friendly community. In all the time I've been on the forums, very few arguments really arose... and most of them were really stupid. They will usually help out with a problem that you have... unless they really can't figure what you did.This may sound like me rambling on, but don't just sit there, questioning your life, and if you should buy the game. Do what Shia Labeouf would want, "Just Do It!"    Not sorry at all.It is a really rewarding game if you can be patient and can learn. (There are people who just hate this game to hate it. Seriously, look past the flaws. There aren't many developers for this game. If I remember correctly, some of the community members work on the game too.)This is getting a little long... well, boohoo. Just try the game out, it's really fun, as I've said like 10 times already. (A little exagerated on the number, but I really mean that you should get the game, person reading this review.)(P.S. My FTD Forum name is HerobrineofNotch. I'm not the kind of person who goes on everyday, even if I was, I wouldn't have the time.)Bye!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								From the Depths is perfect for people who want to build and test things for their own reasons and a lot less perfect for people who want a game with a clear objective or progression system.Nothing new here for a sandbox game; people complaining that there isn't anything to do, just because they didn't go LOOKING for something to do, forgot to take a look at the tags under the description of the game. If you DO go looking for things to do, you'll find that there are, in fact, meaningful things to do with your creations, such as:- Entering them into a tournament;- Playing through the campaign using them;- Playing through the story missions using them;- Creating a custom campaign filled with them.Not to mention the possibility of creating custom LUA AI code for the vehicles you make. There's potential for hundreds, no, thousands of hours of fun here. For only 20 euros at the time of writing, that's a much better deal than a thousand hours of film, a thousand hours of lecture/literature, a thousand hours of other games... you name it.Of course, to get so much out of the game, you'll need to do some work yourself, too. Not only will you have to look for things to do (tournaments, custom campaigns, etc.), but you will also have to learn to play the game. I must warn you: learning to create all the possible vehicle types and making them work well took me a good 200 hours, if not more. This means you have to be prepared to learn. And by learning, I mean learning through trial and error.The learning experience, however, is fun. That alone would be enough of a reason to recommend this game, but the best part of the game very definitely is this: building your creations, of whatever kind you choose*, for whatever purpose you choose**, at whatever time you choose: there's a great deal of freedom and a lot to do here.*Submarines, boats, helicopters, airplanes, hovercraft, spacecraft, fortresses, hydrofoil surface-skimmers, completely unrealistic flying behemoths, land vehicles with jet engines because wheels don't work yet (update: now they do, but steering is complicated)...**The campaign, story missions, custom campaigns, tournaments...

								This game is freaking awesome. Build pretty much any type of vehicle you want (though it is definitely geared towards ships) and send them to battle against an array of player made contraptions that will destroy your ship in 5 seconds.Once you climb the learning curve, the game gets really fun, and you can find yourself spending hours and hours designing stuff. content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								Started off by watching a bunch of tutorials online, which helped immensely in the long run, and started making random crap, just to mess around.  Then I started the campaign, and I had no idea what I was doing, so I started spawning in several planes to make an Air Force, which then failed me miserably.  I then decided to make ships that could carry way too many resources than necessary, and had missiles and AA guns on it only, and that was my main battleship for the longest time.  I appropriately named it the Scavenger, and moved on to make another air fleet, consisting of several vintage WWII aircraft.After a long and decisive battle with a Deepwater Guard Airship, I ended up losing all my planes, and I had to retreat to my slow♥♥♥♥♥Scavenger, which I was attempting to transport to the Warzone.  At the time, I never undershoot what it meant to pull all my forces out of play, so I would idiotically wait onboard the scavenger, till it finally reached the Gantry I had captured in the previous battle, and there the airship flew, too high for me to hijack, which was my tactic for the longest time, and still is.  After accumulating more air forces and retrofitting P-51s with laser guided missiles, I engaged the airship.After what seemed like a few minutes, the airship fell to the ocean, and I hijacked it and destroyed every last component on the damn airship.  I scrapped the ship and used the reassures to make a tall spotting tower, which aided me in discovering where I actually was on the map.After numerous engagements, I set my sight on what I thought was a military land installation, and I attacked with everything I had.  Long story short, I lost almost all my P-51s (which all crashed into the ground on their own, because I assume the AIs got drunk) to find out it was just a fishing village.  Go figure.After many more days of planning and attacking, I finally beat the Deepwater Guard (after making a carrier and War Ship), and decided to make the best and safest headquarters for my nation.  It took me forever, but I was satisfyingly awesome to walk around the halls of my very own Capitol in the end, with the flags of my nation flying proudly overhead,Long story short, this game has almost infinite possibilities when it comes to just doing whatever the hell you want.  I haven't even scratched the surface of it all yet, and it's exciting to figure out how to make new things, like lasers (which I actually don't know how to make yet), or even CRAM Cannons (Because Advanced Cannons are life).  I would definitely recommend this to anyone willing to learn how to play it, because it does have a huge learning curve, but that's not entirely bad, in fact, it's pretty much a part of life.  So consider this game to be a fun, yet important life lesson.I would play this for as long as I could, if life altogether would allow me to.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Professional tip: Always watch videos on a game before getting into it. Especially this one.From the Depths is a hard target indeed. Takes a lot of experimentation, trial and error. But as many people before me have already said, once that's all done and through, you will truly know what it means to be the architect of a nation's destruction.Fair warning, even after all this there's still a strange control scheme unique to this game which takes a while to get used to. Plus there's always the risk of framerate drops. If you're worried about whether this will run on your machine, it's probably best to wait for a full release. Even if you're not, it's likely a good idea to wait anyway because changes come thick and fast for the most part, and you probably don't want the irritation of having to get a refund because the game doesn't start for x reason.Still brave enough to have a go? Then sally forth, and let the gun porn rain down upon your face.

Early Access Review
								Nick Smart is a developer. He is a GAU-8 Minigun firing patches.Nick actually listens (AND IMPLEMENTS) what the community suggests - and most of the singleplayer content is community submitted.Nick is a good dev. All devs need to be like Nick.Ok all joking aside, From the Depths (hereafter FtD) is an incredibly complex and deep physics-based sand vehicle design and combat game. You can make floating castles or flying castles of metal and 2m guns that wreck♥♥♥♥♥♥more than Ralph can ever imagine doing. Almost every part of the game is customisable - from the engines (which can be tweaked by adding parts like cylinders, turbos, carbs, injectors, etc) - to every last bit of weapon, like how wide the spread from your high explosive fragmentation close in anti aircraft missile's frags are, down to the degree. And if you thing this is complex, you're ABSOLUTELY RIGHT!! FtD isn't for everybody. But if you've ever considered it, get it. Now's your chance. Don't wait. Don't hesitate. JUST DO IT!Pros:Fantastic CommunityFantastic DevExtreme depth (haha see what I did there; no, that was horrible) for hours and hours of enjoymentSO MANY dev patchesCons:Unity 4 - so for good performance one will need a processor with strong individual cores.Graphics a little rustic, but it's all up to taste GET IT NOW! WHY ARE YOU STILL READING THIS?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've spent over 300 hours in the first month after the purchase, so it's avery good investment for the given entertainment.I'll begin with the cons:- Beware for your social life...- This game is in no way finished, and considering that it's a one man work, it will continue to evolve for years.But, there are rumours of modding support that's coming in, and with the actual community I'm sure that will accelerate the development drastically.- The game is laggy with huge creations or when there are too many missiles, and I honestly don't think that will improve a lot, it's a simple matter of "people always want more", so if the game is optimized, people will make bigger creations and launch more missiles.- The game is complex and without the help of the forums and youtube tutorials it is not even possible to know where or how to begin.- I mean, the game is really complex, you've been warned...So, why did I spent over 300 hours in a month on this game?- After the first 15-20 hours, things begin to fall in and you understand the most important mechanisms.- I'm a builder, and this game is about building.- I like to have the possibility to create complex things, and this game is just that, you want to add a cannon? You have to build the cannon piece by piece, trying to find the balance you need for this specific cannon and this specific ship and I love it!- You can automate some actions/reactions (not enough for now, but the game is expanding month after month...).- I love ships.- I love submarines even more (and I did not even began to build one!!! I want it to be perfect so I continue to learn how to make better ships...).- The creator is dedicated to his work and he is very present on the forum (10.55 posts per day from him on the forum, and all that while working hard on the game).- The potential of this game is HUGE. So many things can be added that I know I will be disapointed because everything that is in my mind will not be included in the game (but with mod support... who knows...). Anyway you can only be disapointed by something you like, else you don't even care, and I definitly like this game.The point is, if you like legos, building war machine, destroying war machines or watching huge explosions and bits of vehicules falling appart, then why are you still reading this?? Buy the game, and play.Thanks to Nick Smart, the author of this game, you're wonderful!!
