content:
Posted: January 5
Early Access Review
								Note : THIS GAME IS ALPHA STAGE AS REPORTED BY DEVELOPER : This game is a physics simulator for engineers, but its fun.  The game is currently stable as of 2016 jan 03, it will likely not remain stable, and have many bumps before it even reaches bata.  That being said, you can simulate ships, planes, and space ships in the same instance, I hear it supports multi player.  This is a good way to learn the basics of ACAD, and other simulation software used in the real world, but its fun!  It already supports modding, but because its not really released mods break between updates (as they should for an alpha).There are some strange bugs, and I play on a M-Tech laptop (the most stable and fastest laptop built, and will smoke almost all desktops).   The community is very active for this game, and are helping to push its development.  I would imagine that lots of features have not been  added, and if the developer iis smart, has not even started performance tuning, and it plays well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's pretty hard to really 'review' this early access game.  I'll be honest with you, IMO this game seems like it's one of those that will just never -not- be early access.  But what is here in this game so far is simply fantastic.  I almost missed it, too.  One of my friends introduced this game to me.  At first, even then, I kind of just dismissed it.  I played a little and was kind of intimidated.  Almost a full year later, I tried again, and stuck with it.  Watched some Youtube videos and learned a lot.  Now it's one of my favorite games.There's really no other game like this on the market for now.  I guess it's more akin to something like Robocraft than anything else, just not as a lobby-based multiplayer game.  Oh, and there's a lot of water in this game.  Like, a lot.  Hence, the title.From the Depths isn't easy to get into.  Luckily, the developer's recently added a bit of a tutorial system that goes over a lot fo the mechanics in the game to help get you started.  There are a few Youtubers that have guides and walkthroughs as well.  If you're interested, I recommend looking up IreLAN Gaming's Youtube channel, there are a bunch of videos by him that explains a lot and does some interesting builds.Let me give an example of the complexity of this game for you.Take a metal block, add a propeller to it.  Doesn't work.  Propeller needs power.  Build an engine.  Oh wait...  that involves placing an engine block, placing crankshaft parts, putting pistons on the crankshaft.  That'll work and give you power, but you can get even more power by adding fuel injectors, or adding carburetors and slapping superchargers or turbochargers on 'em.  Don't forget to pipe the exhaust out to cool it all, if it gets too hot it'll lose effeciency at high loads and eventually stop working if it overheats.  There are radiators you can slap on, too.The engine isn't working?  Oh yeah, you'll need fuel.  Don't have fuel?  Have to get some oil.  Make a refinery to turn it into fuel.So!  Now we have an engine, with fuel, which is now powering the propeller.  But the metal block isn't very hydrodynamic, is it?  Turn that thing into an actual boat, because water and air resistance is a thing in this game.  Sloped and angled building materials are very important to minimize resistance in order to maximize speed.  Now the boat's top heavy and keeps flipping, so add a keel.  Now, to turn the boat you need a rudder.  Boat's getting a little heavy, add some more propellers.  Hell, add some wings to the ship, equip some jet thrusters to the back, and turn it into an airplane.  Hell, put some ion thrusters on various parts of the ship and now you can fly it into space and use it a a satellite or space ship.Seal up the hull, add some airpumps, use PID controller blocks to set the ship's AI to keep it at a certain level in the water, keep it from rolling or listing too much, and turn it into a submarine.  Add some wheels, drive it on land, call it a tank.Oh, wait, we haven't got into weapons or AI.  Well, this "review" is getting long enough as it is...The sheer 'Depth' of this game is fantastic.  It's easy to get into, mess around, and just keep building and building.  My first ship was a massive, terrible Frankenstein's monster of a ship that could hardly float.  My more recent ships have been sleek, fast, well armored, and pack a punch.  The iterative design is awesome.The game's being developed by a very small team, and there's really only one programmer working on it.  The love for the game is obvious, and he's always adding more to the game while improving what's already there.  The game is far from perfect, and the larger battles will slow down even powerful machines becuase of the sheer volume of what's being constantly calculated.  The game has some rough edges, and like I said before the UI is pretty rough, but it is getting better.  The game obviously isn't for everyone, it's very focused on the combat.Definitely worth the price, IMO.  Especially if it goes on sale.  Like now.  Steam Summer Sale.  Get it. $6.00.  Game's a steal for that much.P.S. From the Depths does have multiplayer.  It's not as stable as singleplayer, but it's nice to have.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I dont think i could reconmend this game enough. Currently one of my favorites. The learning curve is incredibly difficult and even after 200+ hours i still struggle with making effective aircraft and airships but this is also what makes this game good as there is still something you can learn after so many hours. The advanced cannons are amazing once you figure them out and with the planned updates the developer has I feel they will be quite balanced. The developer is incredibly commited and squashing bugs that are posted on the forums in matter of days. The community in my experience is also very positive and offers tips without putting your designs down. The AI to start with is incredibly easy to use and understand to make your ships work and then with the introduction of lua and PID controllers if you know what your doing you can make them more effective. If you pick up this game, expect to put time into it before you build something that doesnt get wrecked easily. my best tips i can give for starting out is pay attention to center of mass and try to have it below water line for ships. Learn the advanced cannons and watch irelan's and rugers tips for building them. Missles/torpedos for starting are also very good.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Think Space Engineers, but...different.That's the simplest way to describe this game. The concepts are "roughly" the same, but From the Depths (FTD) goes in an entirely unique direction. Most notably with AI. There's a bit of a learning curve, but its well worth it. If you like Space Engineers you should own this. As far as I can see this game in criminally overlooked. Its at an early stage, but there is a helluva lot of game here. There's story missions and even a sandbox campaign, assuming you can pull yourself away from the vehicle creator. There is quite a lot of stuff you can build too. Its really more than I want to get in to.Suffice to say that if this sort of "sanbox block-building" interests you, own it, simple as that, just own it. As for its early access development. Pretty sure this is a one man show (I think), so don't go expecting weekly updates. However, the developer does respond frequently and engages the community. Like I said there's a lot here already so its more than worth the price.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great game! I have spent nearly 30 hours on the game so far, and that is me just derping about in the builder menu! AI is good, although I have noticed that they always seem to shoot for the players robot, and with a bit of work that can be exploited, but that is me just nit picking as it is an alpha. Building in this game is very easy, once you get the hang of it. I was used to building games like Minecraft and Kerbal space program, so I was initially off put by the building interface. However, once I got the hang of it I could build rather complex boats with out too much work, it was that powerful. The ability to save chunks of craft, like turrets and engines you spent 7 minuets designing, then paste them later is an amazing tool that I have only seen in Kerbal Space program. My one real criticism is that this game, as befitting is complexity and depth, does have a bit of a learning cliff. Luckily there are good video tutorials online, including some made by the devs. I have seen betas and even full games that are less complete then this. And the fact that there have been 3 smallish but very useful updates in the last month,  makes this one of the best games of the year. TL:DR  amazing game once you get into it.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is basically like what would happen if Minecraft and Kerbal Space Program had a baby together, then gave it a giant railgun cannon to play with.The learning curve can be a bit daunting at first, unless you have a degree in physics and engineering. And the controls do take some getting used to. As an example, my first day was spent primarily learning what a ship's keel is, and why it's so important. Once you make it past the inital stumbling blocks (pun intended) though, this game ends up being a tremendous amount of fun. The sheer scale and depth of what you can create in this game is astounding, and it's still in early access!Also cannons. Really, really big cannons. Lots of really, really big cannons.Plus lasers, and missiles, and laser missiles, and missle lasers, and a faction of giant floating robot clown heads. I highly recommend this game!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								From the Depths-	Not many games allow for such in depth vehicle customization and versatility as From the Depths. In this world of endless possibilities you are placed inside the body of a very creative protagonist robot named "Rambot" who is given a roll dependant of his situation. There is multiple campaigns to play through, all vary in difficulty, story, enviroments, and enemies. Along side the story mode, there is the vehicle designer where you are able to create and test your various inventions. Starting to feel lonely? Yes!? Well, there is also a multiplayer mode where you can play exclusive gamemodes with your pals!-	From the Depths has limitless creation possibilities. If you can think of any Helicopter, Jet, Boat, Battleship, Submarine, Tank, or Fortress, chances are that you can build it, and have it be piloted by an AI, or yourself alternativly. Along with being able to create your own monstrosities, which they probably will be at first, you can also build *almost* 1:1 scale replicas of any real vehicle. With the wide variaty of 400 different blocks, many different materials, and millions of different gun creation possiblities.-	With being able to create anything you can imagine, there are also very many ways to put your inventions to the test! With the 4 campaigns to play through, there are hundreds of thousands of hours of content to be played, though it must be noted that the campaign modes can be buggy and unplayable on occasion. With that being said, there are various enviroments to explore. "Neater" is the most complete planet with a very large and complex story driven campaign where you must defeat all of the opposing forces and grow your army of Artificial Inteligence controlled vehicles. You will face very many different factions that have their own building style and stories alike. This campaign may take hundreds of hours to complete, it is all dependant on how fast you learn to create effective combat machines, and manage resources.-	There is also a very incomplete multiplayer mode where you can play with as many friends as you'd like... or handle! There are very many party modes to play such as; Tower defence. In the Tower Defence mode, you must hold down a tower from various enemies with limited resources, so you must think quick. You may also battle Artificial Intelligence controlled vehicles with your own vehicles with the company of others. Campaign mode is also availible to play with your friends if you'd like.-	From the Depths is truely a unique game with very a creative solution to the vehicle/voxel building game genere as a whole. With endless building possibilities, hundreds of different blocks, and lots of weaponry options. Not only is the game fun to play around with, it has an incredible amount of campaign and story content to explore and learn about, with many different worlds, and variety of enviroments. With more updates, From the Depths is slowly getting even better, with lots more interesting content being added monthly. The developer truely loves his game and cares about what the community has to say, taking any- and all advice and seeing if it would fit the game. After 280+ hours invested into the game as of writing this review, I can say I will be playing this game for many years to come!

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
Early Access Review
Overview                                                                                                                                                            Brilliant game, its not hugely expensive. Its fun, creative,interesting.  it still has some content to come, but in terms of current content, this game really does have some serious replay value. I've owned the game for a little while, and i will admit, most people will find the game every difficult at first, but after a while you can slowly get used to the complex mechanics and parts involved when building in from the depths. Building boats is surprisingly easy, as in, a slow , small, lightly armoured, lightly armed cruiser. But as you play you can really build glorious things. Im now starting to make space platforms, and slightly more advanced vehicles. WeaponsAlas, some of my favourite parts of from the depths. Unlike most games on the market, you engineer your own weapons of destruction using complex and simple tools. Simple weapons are for those just starting, already made, work normally, all you need is ammo and some space, then you can branch out. Cram cannons are surprisingly simple for how powerful they are. launch explosive 50 pound shells, or build a piercing machine gun. Missiles, pretty much do what it says on the tin, plus a bit of what seeking and some fancy tricks. lasers, helpful for more than mayhem, anti-ballistic properties.advanced cannons, for , i quote "experienced people with too much time on their hands".  performanceit dosen't lag unless your doing something really bad. movement is smooth, so on.Not much else to say.  SummaryThis game is cheap, fun, open ended, imaginative and generally a fun experience for everyone.However, the in game tutorials on various blocks aren't great, its time consuming, On all game modes( non creative) its difficult, its very difficult to use certain parts in general. However if the campaign is hard, you can always sneakily change the price of a few objects in there in-built modding tools! Only time i have personally seen it in a game.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Probably one of the grandest most complex building game ever... built. You can design everything and anything in this game, from a little pirate ship, to a giant toothy beast of a battleship, where everything on it is designed by you. The propulsion system, the kind of armour used, the engine, the guns, the bullets the guns shoot, how the AI attacks opponents, wether it will be geared with detection systems or try to avoid detection all together. You could make a stealth submarine, with autocannons and torpedoes that crush the enemy from below in a massive attack. Or maybe you want a flying fortress, covered in armour, guns, and filled to the brim with high tech systems, lasers, particle cannons and warp drives. You could spend hours designing, testing, and perfecting your ship, perfecting it's weapons, optimising it's engines. Then you can pit them against other ships in massive fleet battles, where you can be tactical and take control if you want to. if not then the AI can handle it and you can watch the quite amazing destruction. 450 hours in and I'm only just getting to grips with Advanced cannons, how to make them as damaging and as compact as possible, how to up their fire rates and how to design shells so that they do what I want them to, I'm also only just learning how to make a truly glorious anti munitions defence system. (after much research into it, yes you need to basically do in game research yourself which is something you either love or hate)There is indeed a learning curve but it's not that difficult to overcome, but once you've worked out how to build an absolute monster of a ship by combining your new learnt skills, and then send it out on it's maiden voyage in the campaign mode, to conquer a faction, you'll feel accomplishment like no other. I'd say this is the best early access game on steam and you should definitely buy it at such a generous price, despite the staggering amount of content and replayability you'll get.

Product received for free
Early Access Review
								I made a tank, with a nuke and wings. It's flying tank that rams into♥♥♥♥♥♥and explodes. If you ant to put it into simple terms this game is minecraft, with guns and ships planes ect But i'm not going to give you a sum up like that I'm going to full you the FULL REPORT!Pros- Overall top quality build system- Fantastic battles- Historically accurate ships/planes and landcraft built into the game- 4 diffrent planets built itno the game- 2 diffrent building styles (mouse and keybord)- Can switch between an RTS and building style gameplay- Easy to learn controls for both keybord and mouse controlsCons- UI is very confuseing at first- Battles can lag ALOT if you dont have a beefy PC (Might just be me, procced with caution)- Ai ships can get stuck very easyI just want to talk about the cons lastly because i feel that is what needs to be adressed upfront. THE UI: I opened the game and was greeted with a UI start screen that looked like a god dam 4 year old threw all off the buttons on the screen. I think the devs may of done it this way to be either quick and done with it or they may of tried to make it easy and simple. BATTLE LAG: Let me state out my basic PC specs before i say anything so you know what i'm working withCPU: AMD 8 core CPU 3.50 GhzGPU: GTX 960RAM: 16 Gb DDR3 1333 MhzNow thats out of the way lets look at what they reccomend.Processor: Intel Quad Core i5 @ 2.5 GHz (or AMD equivalent) Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 460 / AMD Radeon HD 7800 series The reccomened specs may work on simple graphic setting but on nothing else. Orver all it's either me or the game.STUCK AI SHIPS: I found it very annoying that AI ships would simpley just beach themselfs from time to time and all my work gone to nothing becasuse of faulty programming.All in all this game still needs work but is in a playable state if have have a decent PC and can put up with bugs and glitches.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is NOT a minecraft clone.  It stands alone as a brilliant game in a very different genre.  If you ever enjoyed building legos as a child, you need this game.  If you ever loved designing ships in Master of Orion, you need this game.  Imagine if you built something with legos, programmed it, and then it began shooting at other legos, built by other people.The AI shines in this game.  I would never fire my own guns, though I have the option to, as the AI is simply a better shot.  Countless games that allow massive creative freedom lack any sort of 'challenge'.  Not so in FtD.  Enemy designs are hugely varied and hugely dangerous.  This game provides 4 singleplayer campaigns, resource limits and gathering, and multiple factions that can battle each other.  Designing a single turret can be very satisfying, and there is a lot of skill that goes into designing ships that are effective.Did I mention that you can build submarines, planes, functional helicopters, and even spacecraft?  And your spacecraft can shoot at planetbased targets?Now, the game is good, it's entirely worth the full cost, but it is alpha.  It's a very complete alpha, but there is clearly polishing still to do.  Optimization and balancing is needed, though the game is very playable and very fun currently.  Shield generators are OP at the moment, for example.  I am incredibly pleased to have bought this game, and I hope to see more people buying it, and a wonderful future for it.  The ships are both durable and fragile at times, with armor and materials playing a very realistic role.  Ships can be blown in half, but they can also take 10 minutes of solid pounding.  Everything is built into the game.  If a shell hits your ammo stores, it can gut the ship, or it can do very little if you designed to prevent a chain reaction.  Everything has tradeoffs.  The very AI that controls your ships is built on your ships, and pieces of it can be blown up.Unlike most early access games, this game would be worth the price even if it there was never another update.  I would be very sad if that happened, but I wouldn't want a refund, because I'd still want to be playing the game.  I can give no higher praise.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you enjoy building structures, vehicles, aircraft and watching them blow other creations to bits then this game is perfect.While I admit it is an Alpha, it has a LOT in it, but it does keep changing. Not to mention how complex things will seem to a new player; there's a lot to learn, but as with any challenge, it is great when you succeed -- and this game is no different.Purchased on a whim to get a few hours of gameplay with a friend I was dissapointed when the multiplayer didn't work properly for me ( this was a personal issue, and no-one else seems to get it, so don't worry ) I decided to try the AI campaigns out, just for a gander, and From The Depths quickly became in my list of most played games, at 300+ hours and still rapidly rising the challenge this game presents is formidablle for even the best of players, all the while being perfectly capable of overcoming it.There is a massive customizability in each ship, tank or whatever you create. I shouldn't realise say 'customize' as you get no set pieces, you get blocks, 1 meter, 2 meter or even 4 meter sloped glass blocks against Explosive Reactive Armor. Each has benefits that are detailed. They aren't simply placed on an 'armor' preset number, each block handles the fire it takes differently, being deflection, completely stopping a shell / missile all the way to being ethereal.The customization comes in the form of the weapons you use. There are currently four weapon types:CRAM Cannons: These are your artillery-type cannons. Although perfectly spammable by your choice, these cannons are commonly used as slow-firing but incredibly powerful area of effect devastators. And will more than easily create an explosion capable of tearing vessels in half.Advanced Cannons: These more modern-esc cannons are used as either Anti-Missile, or just Anti-Everything, you can set them up to destroy shields, penetrate armor and burst molten copper into a vessel, EMP areas or flat out blow things up. These can be gatling guns or massive 300mm + Destroyer cannons completely at your personal discretion.Missiles: Great for getting past shields these again, very extensive weapons can be used in a variety of ways, be it super-fast Anti-Air or Massive anti-capital torpedoes.Lasers: Never really delved into these personally, but they haven't been left out the by the developer, this weapon system can do serious damage and are just as useful as the others.Speaking of developers you can see just how active and knowledgable the developer is in the scene of creating games by looking at the From The Depths forum, where you can see updates, suggestions ( Which are not negletected) , other players builds from typical modern-like creations to vehicle representations of the Kraken.All in all a VERY diverse game about blowing things up and creating what's on your mind. After 3000+ hours in Minecraft 'cause I'm a scrub I thought I'd never want to build anything again, From The Depths taught me other-wise.

								There is a very steep learning curve, however there's plenty of guides (both in-game and online) to help you get started. Once you've got the hang of it there's few limits to what you can try to build. You have complete design control of your vehicle from the number of engine exhausts to the length of a gun's shells.  The game is regularly updated with new content, improvements and bugfixes, and the workship is filled with a lot of excellent stuff that's worth checking out. Definetly recommend picking this up.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								A gem, if you like building vehicles. I tend to mainly build ships, but you can also build subs, planes, helicopters, floating fortresses etc.You have to balance weight, lift, resources and power.  Made that ship too top heavy? It will roll over. Filled the ship with lead? It will sink. You design the ammo the guns use. Want penetration? Want it to explode after penetrating 3m of steel? Want HEAT capability? You can have all that and moreIf you like the designing ships (and things), you'll spend hours upon hours in the designer. I've spent more time in the designer than in the campaign.I recommend this game, even if you have trouble with logic and spatial awareness; You can train your brain to an extent.

content:
Posted: February 13
Early Access Review
								What is this game? It's the ultimate naval ship building game that just so happens to have excellent aircraft and ground vehicle construction as well. Everything is considered with this game, drag, buoyancy, center of gravity, everything comes together to either make or break your designs. And that can be a serious problem for people who don't have the mindset for this type of game. And I'm not talking stupid people I mean the kind of people who could probably be engineers if they wanted to should play this game. Everything is complex, and not in the stupid way. Every part has a role, every component has a job and it's up to you to use them to produce truly devastating weapons to crush your enemies. Do you want to make a 10 barreled 500mm cannon? Go for it, have fun finding a ship that'll use it but you can do it! Want to recreate the USS Missouri or the German Bismarck? You can do it. Want to recreate the Space Battleship Yamato? You can do it. Complete with giant laser cannon and all.This game also has a really robust and active steam workshop community which is a huge plus in my book. The UI needs work though. If you do buy this game, please please please don't write it off because of the UI. Because once you learn the quirks it's not bad to work with. So do I recommend it? Absolutely.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Been a whille since I've played,the best piece of advice i have for this game is Just. Don't. Rush.Take it slow, this game has a bigger learning curve than ... well... everything else like it.The parts are complex and have to fit right, you have to manage Weight, Size, Shape, Weight distribution,  Boyancy, both Aero and Fluid dynamics,  and on top of that, Speed Vs Location, recoil, turret weight, lift, momentum, resources, and so much more....It is essentially "Science the Game.", more so than space engineers, or any Sci-fi build and survive. As for those of you who claim "Minecraft", Well guess what. . . . GET OVER YOURSELF! Minecraft wishes it had all of this in it.Yeah, it's based on blocks. do you see Steve runnin' around?  Can you build a 4K block wide and 10K block long air ship that has 400 missiles on 3 different platforms that all have different explosion types? No. No you dont, and cant.It's not Minecraft, dont compare it to minecraft.  Thats like compareing GTA:V to Saints-Row IV.Similar games, H U G E differences.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is neither an easy nor forgiving sandbox, but if you make a point to stick with it and learn the fundamentals of the game the rewards worth it.   As I write this review it is still an early access game but shows promise as it continues to grow and expand.   If you think it is fun putting your creations into a skirmsh  with various opponents and see how they thrive or fail inspiring you to improve on your designs or create better ones from scratch.   You'll have to learn all you can at making efficient and effective designs if you want to surive and not break the resource bank.   Making vehicles that compliment each other and work together is crucial and challenging and expect to spend lots of hours learning by doing.When starting out I'd recommend watching videos on youtube and understanding how things fit together it's not very intuitive and there are some thing you simply need to know before you set out.  The In-game tutorial is helpful as a leap off point but you'll still want to study others designs either on the workshop or those placed by the developers in game to get get an idea of 'how do they make this work?' and go from there. Test and retest, trial and error is key here, don't expect to master things in a day or a week even, there are so many possibilities and generally if you can think it you can build it, the big question usually is if you should.The only gripe I had is that he interface/controls take a lot of getting used to and feel clunky to me, but you can remap keys and such to something more to your liking but there is still room for improvement and as it is still in development I am sure it willl there have already been strides in this regard so I have high hopes for it.This game may not be for everyone but if you like sandboxes to play in this certainly fits the genre and is worth a look.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Been a whille since I've played,the best piece of advice i have for this game is Just. Don't. Rush.Take it slow, this game has a bigger learning curve than ... well... everything else like it.The parts are complex and have to fit right, you have to manage Weight, Size, Shape, Weight distribution,  Boyancy, both Aero and Fluid dynamics,  and on top of that, Speed Vs Location, recoil, turret weight, lift, momentum, resources, and so much more....It is essentially "Science the Game.", more so than space engineers, or any Sci-fi build and survive. As for those of you who claim "Minecraft", Well guess what. . . . GET OVER YOURSELF! Minecraft wishes it had all of this in it.Yeah, it's based on blocks. do you see Steve runnin' around?  Can you build a 4K block wide and 10K block long air ship that has 400 missiles on 3 different platforms that all have different explosion types? No. No you dont, and cant.It's not Minecraft, dont compare it to minecraft.  Thats like compareing GTA:V to Saints-Row IV.Similar games, H U G E differences.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								From the Depths is an extremely complicated game. I have played what I consider a large amount and yet I struggle to play this game. It requires you to learn so many things to be decent. That's what I love about this game so much. It makes everything you do feel like an accomplishment. I started playing this game a really long time ago. I would build my tiny little raft and sail around until I got bored because I didn't know what else to do, so I quit. After a few years I returned to the game and I realized all that I had missed. It was an incredible game. Everytime I play From the Depths I learn a new mechanic or a new trick for combat.Also, From the Depths recieves a constant amount of updates, and fairly large ones at that. You will always be able to find something to do in this marvelous game.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								I normally don't write reviews for games because it often isn't worth the invested time but here I am going to make an exception.The reason that I am writing this review is because I have noticed that the developers of this game are truely dedicated to this product, the game is constantly being updated and new (meaningful!) features keep getting added.Now besides how noble developers are from that aspect, that does not sadly guarantee a good game, in this case however it truely does!From the depths is a great game in which you build ships, fleets and even (space)planes to assure your dominance of the seas, it's a game that lets your imagination run wild as long as you know how to play it. The game sports decent physics and has great battles, did I mention elements of strategy gaming?There is however one big 'problem' that this game has, it is a big time investment, it has a steep learning curve and perfecting your ships is going to take a while. Now don't worry, there are tutorials (bit of an understatement) that will guide you all the way to the hardest mechanics, just don't expect something light when you play this game.All in all I wouldn't recommend this game for players with a short attention span, but if you have enough time, like being challenged, like battleships and love customization in games, then this one is a must buy!

Posted: August 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								It is a very good game, but the current update has broken so much, and I can tell that im not the only one worried about the way the game is going. Currently moving ships that are out of play very often puts them at the same point, making it impossible to use either without spawning and destroying both. Along with updates that just make the game more tedious and less streamlined, I can not recommend a purchase in the current state. The previous  update was fine, this one is a steep downgrade.To clarify, I purchased this game on a different account, and I have roughly 30-40 hours total in the game. Wait for fixes or a really good sale before buying.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game takes learning. There's no denying that, you have to learn how to play the game before you can have fun.However, when you do it's a surpsingly amusing game to get sunk into. The problem i find in the long run, is that the single player at least is very shallow. You don't find yourself doing much other then building big things and wrecking stuff. and if you can do that, whats the point of going further? This is not, however to say i didn't have a huge amount of fun seeing how large a gun i could fit onto the chassis of a shipThe game is reccomended, but i really really needs the Dev's to look at the control system (which is difficult for newer players) and work on getting the multiplayer functionality going. Once that's working, it has the potential to be a great game! (take the main kind of mission setup, lower it to a single screen and go from there?)Edit:The Singleplayer has been Largley updated from since i last played, with a larger set of ships and more AI in relation to what you do. It's not so easy to buy nations off now. It's looking bleedin good!

								I got this game while on vacation. In 2 days I have played for 15 hours. Early Access Review
								FtD player criteria quiz:1. Are you patient?2. Are you willing to learn the mechanics of the game?3. Do you have a reasonable understanding of physics?4. Can you get your head around different control schemes easily?5. Do you think the navy is cool?6. Are you a pyromaniac who will put HE ammo in everything?7. Are you a megalomaniac who will put 2 metre CRAM cannons on everything to make up for the fact that you can't actually build an advanced cannon (or even a stable ship)?8. Do you think Particle Accelerator cannons are what the world needs?If yes to more than 6 of these then From the Depths is for you my friend.If not then go back to Roblox u cheeky skrub

content:

Early Access Review
								Anyone who has no experience with this game calls it a "Minecraft Clone", and in the fact that it uses a Voxel style building system, it is...... But in reality, Minecraft wishes it was this cool...A full, in depth campaign; Multiplayer, both co-op and VS; great optimization with much more on the way; amazing gameplay and creativity elements; amazing sounds and music--and it's in Alpha. Developer is in touch with the community and constantly talking about and releasing new updates and patches. This game is one of the best on Steam.As far as creative games go, this one is by far my favorite.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's pretty damn hard to get started if you want any kind of working machinery. Once you understand it a bit better and get used to it, you can make some crazy contraptions.I'm being kind of traditional (lazy?) and sticking to ships for the moment. Going crazy with those missile launchers, tho.So much fun to see 10 or 20 them fire in series and strike a target.Now, something I disliked a lot was the fact that you need to level up in practice mode before you can enter the campaign. I guess it serves the purpose of making sure you know how to fight, and it's good that you don't have to do a tutorial every time you do the campaign, but the learning tools seem a bit crazy to me (a 1+hour youtube video? Really?)Now, there are also text and interactive tutorials, however the interactive ones kinda zip by so fast that I had to re-do the AI training a few times in order to figure out how to automate a gun.So far, sandboxing is a lot of fun. I'd rather the freaking flying units to be a little easier to understand, tho.----An incredibly, INFURIATING part of the game is that, when your stuff is in combat, EVERYTHING ELSE GETS PHASED OUT. This includes your repair dock entering combat while it's repairing your combat ship.Guess what happens? Your dock goes into combat while your combat ship phases out, entering a 500 second cooldown. If your dock has a minimum amount of guns, YOU'RE SCREWED.Another frustrating thing that seems to happen is that the AI seems to have first pick in the spawn order.Meaning that, if you have set a limit value of 20,000, the AI can spawn ships worth those 20,000, or more -using the entire match's unit value- and you will have second pick to the spawn table and it's very likely you'll be stuck with one unit facing an entire enemy fleet.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								TL:DRThis is a VERY nice game, I highly suggest putting atleast 5 hours or so into it to get to know the mechanics.I do not even know where to start, this game is so huge, so I will start with how amazing the customization system is.In other games, you might have a cannon, and it does a fixed amount of damage and has a fixed range, on here, guns are made from placing several diffrent blocks to determine it's stats. Is the gun a small machine gun that fires fast? Is the gun a massive ship cannon that fires a massive shell that explodes? Or maybe it fires AP rounds?The list goes on.The same goes with engines, is it a small, fuel conservative engine? Or maybe it guzzles fuel but has massive power?Oh, and do not even get me started with the laser and jet engine customization. Oh, did I mention you can customize your AI?The game also simulates ship armor. Maybe your armor is really thick but unsloped. Maybe you have lighter armor that slopes to bounce lighter shells?The game is amazing, there is no way I could ever explain this entire game.Overall, the pros and cons are:Pros:- high amounts of customization- powerful ship editor- planes, boats, subs, spacecraft, and soon to be ground forces.- basic multiplayerCons:- complex mechanics, but easy to learn.

Early Access Review
								☻Design and build your own vehicle, however you want.☻Realistic physics – every block destroyed or added affects the vehicle’s functionality, physics and control.☻Test your design in a wide range of multiplayer adversarial and co-op modes.☻Use the spoils of war to unlock new equipment.☻Randomly generated world with weather, monsters and terrain for each game.☻The sky’s the limit – cannons, lasers, mines, bombs, missiles, torpedoes, propellers, rudders, jet engines, wings, hydrofoils, hot air balloons, anchors, fire control computers, and loads more.☻Design custom weaponry and missiles by combining payloads, thrusters, navigation units, fuel pods and more, to deliver a truly bespoke weapon.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is a very strange game. It seems to worship complexity as and end in itself, over and above playability in any normal sense. While it promises much, it's really unpolished, and the defense that it's in alpha is weak given how long it's been in alpha.I bought it at $4 US, and while I have played it a lot, much of that time was hoping the experience would improve, and it just doesn't. Even at $4 I wouldn't recommend it, at full price don't even think about it.Do not buy unless you like painfully complex games that require serious amounts of time investment just to get to beginner level. The 'campaigns' demonstrate that unles you are willing to spend hundreds of hours on designing your vehicles, you'll get owned by the opposition. So you *must* use either the pre-sdesigned ships, or steal the enemies. All good except the main point of buying something like this is to build your own ships..  Desperately needs some common sense in the deevelopment area, and a campaign designed for beginnners who want to enjoy making their own awful craft.  Developer is active, but doesn't seem to have a real vision of where the game is headed, so it is likely to be permantly alpha. It has a cult following, that's part of the proble I think, too much attention on their wants rather than making the game accessible to a wider audience.I really wanted to like it, but in the end had to walk away from playing it as you just end up frustrated at uneccessary complexity.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I can seriously recomend this game to anyone I meet, whether you like action ar creation. The action side to this game is slow when you're in the campaign mode, but once you start up the designer thats when it gets fun. Now keep in mind, you have to build a boat first. Once you've made a boat or found one from the Workshop just press X and you now have a GUI letting you spawn in any enemy you want. After you've played around with the designer and decided to open up the campaign you now have a large challenge infront of you. The campaign mode is amazing, that about sums it up. The building mechanics are a bit confusing at first. but after you've mastered them its very fluent. So, to sum this up, this game is creative, fun, and challenging.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Alright, I decided I should re-Review this game by now.This game, is a physics based Block building game, But No, this is -not- a minecraft clone, You are building war vessels, and structures, to fight the enemy forces of various sides, to try to control the planet.That is a simple way to put the campaign mode, the physics do their job, but I am looking forward to the Unity 5 Update so it will help make it run even smoother in large battles.Ground vehicles are 'slightly' in, There are wheels but not fully in yet.This game does require some brainpower though to make effective creations, or things that will fly or sail at a good speed, with how the physics work, Though the only problem I see is missiles like to 'fall out of the air' when out of fuel, rather then glide along, But this is I believe going to be fixed when they work on missiles more.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								First of all, please note that this game is in pre-alpha development. A lot of the main features are still under heavy development, and changing a lot. Only buy this game at this stage if it's something you don't mind.Why do I rate it then? Because it was well worth my 20 euro's dispite the alpha status. All of my clocked time I was enjoying the game, dispite visible alpha status here and there.Thanks to that I've gotten involved in the community, where the dev actually listens to the community, and responds to most sensible threads. Another great thing about the current development cycle is that players are involved in shaping and filling out the NPC factions. Not lazy design, but a great feature! Build something awesome and mean, and it might make it into the enemies.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has absolutely blown me away. I'll admit it's difficult to learn at first, but well worth it. I can't get over how much there is to this game and it is still only in Alpha. I absolutely can not wait for more features. This game just makes sense. Most creating games there is no reason for building a fortress or a ship or anything. This game gives you a reason, and the better your creations are the easier life is for you. I love the fact that you don't have to spend all day contantly repairing or building the same thing over and over. You design a ship or a part, copy and paste. Improve it, save over it. Repeat. I think the only thing this game needs now is a research tree. So much fun, and so much potential for more already!

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game with almost 600 hours. For the price I can definitely say even if I stopped playing today it was well worth the money.When I first played the game, I was rather overwhelmed by the UI and how the game worked. To the point I got a refund. (I know silly right but nerd rage is a powerful thing). Pros - Well clearly the freedom you have in which to build things. From flying monstrosities that bring love in the form of rainbow colored lasers. Subs that shoot missiles and torpedos or harpoons, because dragging someone under the water is fun. Satalites rain now large amounts of cannonfire (cannons being given and update and now you can build even more fun artilary gun pieces, or railguns) :DBoats that fire hundreds of missiles, lasers, guns, and bring love and peace to all that resist, resistance is loosely classified. Oh and there are the death fortresses. There is a campaign mode, while not the greatest, it can be pretty fun to test out your designs against other armies. The campaign mode is a mixture of RTS and arcade boat / flying game. Where you might control a single vehicle entirely (or let the ai control the guns), while having the rest of the fleet controlled by the AI. The biggest pro how ever, and which likely kept me with the game for so long, is the epic community. while somewhat small everyone is so helpful, often willing to look at your designs and help you fix problems. Give tips, and tricks. There are many more improvements in the making so I am looking forward to seeing what comes in the future.Cons -Remember this is alpha so hopefully these problems with be fixed in the future. FPS and crashing. By far the biggest and worst thing of the game, it does not like large fleets, Up to around 25000 blocks the game works fine with some slow downs. But after that you can expect the game to come to a grinding halt, followed by crashing randomly. This can be highly annoying especially in campaign mode when you have to fight an enemy fleet that has many vehicles. Too many missiles and bullets willl also bring down the FPS.The other problem is AI. While you can deal with it, especially if you work out how to use LUA code, and or the automated controllers. (I use the automated controllers to do a lot of different things to over come the limitations of the AI). While you can make subs, and spaceships, there is no proper AI which can make setting up fully AI controlled Subs and spaceships rather hard and frustrating. So yeah I highly recommend this game. and am rather glad I over came my earlier frustration to give this game a second go. The learning curve is steep, as in clith like steep. But there is so much you can do, and once you learn the basics From the Depths (heh) of this game It becomes great fun. I just wish I could learn to build more restrained but hey I like explosions and rainbow deathray lasers.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								I should have written this earlier, this game deserves it.From the Depths is a voxel based vehicular combat game, in which you create your own weapons of war and pit them against AI. Currently, there are three campaigns. Neter, Dangerous Waters, and Glao. In Neter and Glao you can make your own ships and are competing with AI factions to win territory. Dangerous Waters however is a World War 2 based campaign in which you can spawn in ready-made vessels based on WW2 designs. Dangerous Waters is completely community run, from what I know. Neter and Dangerous Waters are very large, where Glao is geared toward newer players and is far smaller. Personally, I prefer Neter over all of them. The real meat of the game is the vehicle construction. Any form of vessel you can think of, you can make. Boat, submarine, plane, spaceship, a flying death chicken... the list continues. All* weapons are custom made by you, the player. Configured to perform whatever task you wish. Anything from lasers to missiles to the humble cannon can be employed to bring swift death to your enemies. The newest addition to the weapon roster is the Particle Cannon, in which anything on the recieving end can be penetrated, smashed, shocked or exploded. Not particularly in that order.*There is a class of weapon called "Simple Weapons" which are basic single block cannons and lasers. They are cheap, spammable, and suck. Don't use them.The combat is a combination between how much damage you can deal, and how much damage you can take. Big ships are going to be large targets, literally and figuratively. The AI usually goes after the larger ships first. There are counters to every weapon, aside from the Particle Cannon. Cannons are easily countered by shields. Missiles are countered by the various anti-missile systems and anything underwater. And Lasers are countered by the water (partially), and by deployable smoke. Usually, you will want to hook up the majority of your weapons to AI, as a robot will always be better than a human brain... That usually just leaves navigation to you, however that can also be plugged into the AI.There is an indevelopment Story Mode in which you take part in several of the factions. They serve as a bit of a tutorial, I find. Although, there is an official interactive tutorial going over all the features of the game.Adventure Mode is a recent addition that I have not explored much into. It revolves around scavenging other ships that you find on the open sea in order to not be scavenged yourself. I think...Multiplayer is available. I myself have only participated in the cooperative campaign mode of Neter with some friends, however I believe there is a PvP mode. Unsure if it is a competion to see who can construct the best ship in the shortest time, or if it is just a brawl between ships you have made previously against other players' ships.Overall, FtD is a fantastic game. The freedom given by the contruction system is wonderful, and the combat is really fun. Except when you get absolutely pounded by ships far above what you were planning on fighting... Looking at you White Flayers.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
 From the Depths is a game centered about building your own vehicles in Naval Warfare.  Be it a Frigate armed with a deadly swarm of Missiles, an airship with 500mm High explosive Cannons made out of steel, a Hovertank that shoots destructive Lasers capable of piercing armor and destroying the opponent from the inside, or perhaps even a plain WW2 styled bomber, the choice is up to you.The learning  Wall  curve may seem absurd and time consuming at first, but trust me, it will be worth it. There are so many different possibilities you can create in this game. One thing i can recommend is watching YouTubers (ex. ireLAN, Lathland) if you're stuck without any direction on what to do first. And do not forget about the guides, ignoring them would be huge mistake.Buy this game if you like:+ Building your own fleet piece by piece+ Slow paced gameplay+ Letting your Creativity looseDon't buy this game if you prefer:- Fast paced gameplay- Quick, Casual action- Jumping straight into the game, so to speak

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								(This is an overhauled review, but my opinion about this game is unchanged in the least bit. If you love to build, get it.)I've been playing From the Depths for a very long time, and actually, I now assist with some of the game-building mechanics for one of the factions. For the sake of keeping things simple, I'll post below the positives and (few) negatives.Pros: - One of the most diverse building games out there. Seriously, there is very little that can even compare to From the Depths. You can build anything from a 30 block ballooncraft to 120000 block behemoths. (I don't advise trying to build something 120k blocks though. lol) - Customization is now part of the game in that you can create your own campaign with your own designs, or simply just modify the current campaign. This adds to the diversity of the game. - Graphically, it's not a bad game in the least bit, especially with high graphics. - Overall, there are not many bugs in the game due to members testing the game in a development branch, where most issues are resolved before stable patches are released. - The main developer is very active and responsive to community members. A lot of upcoming changes are actually due to members of the forums requesting them.Cons: - Right now, the game is very CPU intensive due to the current way the game calculates the physics, resulting in FPS dropping on most computers. This is due to Unity's standard raycasting being rather poor in calculations for large-scale battles, but work is being done to change these calculations to improve gameplay immensely. - The learning curve for this game is quite steep at first. A lot of things won't make sense, but then again, with time, this is overcome. If you ever have trouble, just consult the forums and we'd be happy to help!...that's about it for cons. If you love building and enjoying things explode, then what are you waiting for? Buy this game, enjoy it as your dream creations come to life!

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game... If you own Kerbal, imagine like you're trying to build a boat in Kerbal, a game about constructing space ships and space planes. This game is basically that, trying to construct boats in a game about spaceships. Seriously though, it's not an easy game, but it sure is fun. All of my hours thus far have just been in the vehicle builder, trying to build an small efficient boat is hard enough, once you get that part somewhat down, you need to account for weapons and protection, which is another whole learning curve in itself. I haven't even gotten into multiplayer or even any campaign or story yet, only because I'm still learning how to build.. You need to build the engines, the boats to use these sucessfully, and even build your own weapons. But it sure as hell keeps you hooked. You can even build sky/land/sea fortresses, planes, helicopers and all, which I can't even imagine because I still struggle with boats.. Maybe one day.tl;dr: If you like games that allow a huge amount of creativity, and that have a challenge/learning curve, and you like games with 100% freedom, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is one of a kind! 9/10Yes the learning curve is HUGE. I mean huge. You need patience for this game, but once you get going it is incredibly fun and addicting. The building is complex, but that makes it all the better in battle. Pros- Epic battles- Good upgrade system- Very complex. yet still intuitive- Coop- PvP- Tons of content- Unlimited possibilities- Decent graphics- Developers seem on the ballCons- The movement of your character is a little buggy, but workable.- Overall polish (it is still open access thought)- Not too much of a con, but I would like to see some more rounded pieces- Multiplayer is awesome and has the potential to be great, but if you do not know someone, then you may have a difficult time finding a game- A ranking system for PvP that is not too advanced, but very basic could seriously add some brownie points (once game is finished)- Not too much on the explainations (you can get by, but it is nothing like a tutorial)- The sound is ok and workable, but is dull sometimes and repetitive.- No epic background music during battles.If you like buiding games and/or may have some friends who would want to play with you, this game is great. Just give it a few hours if you do get it.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								40 Hours into the game and Im already building ships that can kill multiple bulwarks by itself. When everyone else struggles to even set up a cannon.In all seriousness. Its a great game. It runs well with ordinary computers. Building is fun but time consuming. Most of my builds take a few hours or more to complete. My HoverCraft the Auxius has had around 5 hours of work put into it. And it still needs improvement. There are unlimited ways to make your vehicle. As there is LUA terminals for scripting (If you know how). And multiple vehicle types. Aircraft, Submarines, Helicopters, Battleships, Space craft, You name it. You can do it (Except for land vehicles). Everything you have to build from scratch. AI, Guns, Engine, ect. This is what I find the funnest thing about FTD. Being able to design the guns the way YOU want them. If you want them to shoot incredibly fast. You can do that. If you want to make one that shoots shells that could obliterate an entire ship in just a few shots, you can do that. But physics still apply. A large gun on a small hull can and will make your ship top heavy. That with the dynamic wave system. Can really 'rock' your ship. Campaign is fun. But hard at first. So I reccomend playing around in the creative session of the game and grab the ropes. Farther in the campaign you begin to come across hard battles. The ships you nerf because you think they are too overpowered will get killed pretty quickly. The Onyx Watch is such. They use no shields. But their ships are heavily armed and bulky. Meaning they can eat damage and deal even more back.Oh. Also, watch out for the flying squirrels. They can eradicate your most armored ship easily.Either way. This game is very addictive once you learn how to play. I rate this a 9.5/10.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Like KSP for gun fiends.Build a boat. Add an engine, propellers and rudders.Then add guns. Lots of guns. Try to fight an enemy, lose miserably.Do the whole thing again, this time, do a little better.And when you finally feel like you've gotten somewhere, you have to build planes, submarines and spacecraft.Serilously: This is a lot of fun. You're building vehicles (be it boat, plane, submarine or spacecraft), and completing story missions and campaigns. The story missions are a bit tutorial-ish, and rather fun (although difficult). In the campaigns, you wage a dynamic war against other factions, competing for resources and building ever larger craft.If you like building and testing things, this is the game for you!Pros:- Fun building- Fun gun building (Missiles, cannons, grenade launchers, lasers, all built part-by-part from constituent blocks)- Already lots of campaign content (37 tutorials, about 8 different story mission categories each containing about 5 missions)Cons:- Complicated, lots of things to learn- UI requires some getting used to, but is efficient enough (Lots of key controls)

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								40 Hours into the game and Im already building ships that can kill multiple bulwarks by itself. When everyone else struggles to even set up a cannon.In all seriousness. Its a great game. It runs well with ordinary computers. Building is fun but time consuming. Most of my builds take a few hours or more to complete. My HoverCraft the Auxius has had around 5 hours of work put into it. And it still needs improvement. There are unlimited ways to make your vehicle. As there is LUA terminals for scripting (If you know how). And multiple vehicle types. Aircraft, Submarines, Helicopters, Battleships, Space craft, You name it. You can do it (Except for land vehicles). Everything you have to build from scratch. AI, Guns, Engine, ect. This is what I find the funnest thing about FTD. Being able to design the guns the way YOU want them. If you want them to shoot incredibly fast. You can do that. If you want to make one that shoots shells that could obliterate an entire ship in just a few shots, you can do that. But physics still apply. A large gun on a small hull can and will make your ship top heavy. That with the dynamic wave system. Can really 'rock' your ship. Campaign is fun. But hard at first. So I reccomend playing around in the creative session of the game and grab the ropes. Farther in the campaign you begin to come across hard battles. The ships you nerf because you think they are too overpowered will get killed pretty quickly. The Onyx Watch is such. They use no shields. But their ships are heavily armed and bulky. Meaning they can eat damage and deal even more back.Oh. Also, watch out for the flying squirrels. They can eradicate your most armored ship easily.Either way. This game is very addictive once you learn how to play. I rate this a 9.5/10.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								From the Depths is the elephant you're going to want to eat with a fork.  I'm going to be blunt:  I like this gameOn the surface it looks like just another block building game that you can manuever the vehicles.  But under the natural and approachable way the keyboard building mode works, you'll build ships of any and all possible configuration, you will arm these ships, with sensor arrays, lasers, defense lasers, long range missles.  tactical warheads, harpoons, torpedoes, torpedoes that launch into the atmosphere to splash into the ocean miles away to start hunting enemy ships, that you can't see.  -  That's just boats -  I spend six hours last night, messing around with the different size rockets that I can make to see what a certain combination of things would do...  I have 49 Hours of Game time, and I'm just barely scratching the surface.  Then you have Subs - Flying Boats - Planes - Planes that can launch from water - Blimps - Planes that can be blimps - Aircraft carriers that can fly and launch their own AI controled planes..... and helocopters.  Weapons platforms - Refuling stations - long range sensors - ICBM's. How about that you also have above all this, a starship orbiting?  Yeah, you built that too.  Installed mainframe AI's.  And after you do all that fun, you go to war, where you command from a centralized command station, from any of your assets you have built, on a planet you designed, maybe with races you designed.....  For $20 bucks.Yeah, I like this game.  and it works.  and it's ALPHA.and the Dev is very involved.Yeah, I like this game.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								I definetly recommend this game, it's developers are active and good to the community, the game itself has a lot to it, 8 factions who all are memorable, especially Deep Water Guard and Onyx Watch (from my experience). The main concept of this game is that you are a little cute robot, all by yourself, and you have to make and build ships and destroy the 8 factions. The story itself is pretty vauge, but the lore is very nice and detailed (except for Steel Strider's lore, they are just the government, Barack Obama probably leads them.) By default you start out against the Deep Water Guard, pirates who want to kill you and pillage the little resources you have at the start, they are typically the longest faction to defeat, as they attack you when you are building up your forces, and they have a nice mix of every ship, and some fleets they build are devestating, a Moray, Barracuda, and Plunderer in a fleet together is almost complete death.Pros:Good developersIncredible ReplayabilityRarely LagsYou really use your imaginiationYou can build pretty much anything, from submarines to huge airshipsThere is multiplayer, but it isn't incredible at the momentSteam Workshop integrationLore is incredibleCommunity is incredibleMany more that I can't think of right nowCons:Tends to crash a lotDoesn't autosave (yet)It's quite complex and difficult to learnA lot of Trail and Error, especially with air vehiclesSome more that I can't think of right now

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								To be honest, this game doesnt suit everyone's taste. It suits mine because I am patient and I can persevere to learn how things work.Unlimited gameplay potential.Pros:Cool art style.Build mode is clumsy for beginners but if you learn the featured that used to bug you, you enjoy.Giant battleships hurling death at eachother.Lasers, 2 types of cannons, missiles and drills.Lots of blocks to build with.VERY long campaign - Im 4 hours into mine and I'm NOT EVEN SEEING THE END.Submarines to spaceships, everything in between.Building a bad ship can be done quickly, making a good one takes time and thought.Cons:Very hard to learn. I almost abandoned it within 6 hours of getting it because I couldnt get my head around how the rotation system works. I was using G when I should really have been holding tab and pressing WASD.AI can be a bit dull, mostly with aircraft.3 complex weapon systems you need to learn to be able to fight effectively.Engines are complex and designing them(well) takes ages. I recommend making 4 sizes and making them into prefabs.EDIT:The new combination of all resources into just 1 "material" does seem like a (love-heart)ing terrible idea, and removes the point of having to haul a resource you are lacking on to a base, eg the lack of oil at some resource pointsTL;DR:Good once you're into it but learning it is as hard as throwing a feather 5 metres.Try throwing a feather 5 metres.Go on,Do it.I'm talking to you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I gotta say, i used to like building games. Hell, I spent most of my life on Sketchup. But this Physics based masterpiece makes me happy inside, and reinstigated my love for Design. I spend a good 10 hours over the course of a week, just building, testing and finally creating my beautiful (in my mind, i like modern day [WW2 till now] craft. Sea, air or Otherwise) vehicles in the campaign to see if they can withstand the challenges of other creators (with vastly more design talent then I) with their Unique blends. Like the DWG with their sloppy designs that, although messy, have the tendency to do ridiculous things. Or the Steel Striders, and trust me on this, you better be prepared for them, my first (technically second) runthrough, I walked through the DWG like they were a Revolving door, the steel striders were like the door deciding to spin the opposite direction, and me catching it straight in the nose and balls. After the slaughter, I took what I could of the SS Vehicles and did some reverse engineering (Another big thing to do if your garbage at design, like i was early game) After that fateful day, there has been nothing but improvement. You can only get better in this game, you just got put some effort in and soon enough you might be clocking hours on a craft that CS:GO Players only wish they could acheive before attempting to saw their Monitor in half. All in All, A lovely physics based Freeform/RPG/Design/RTS Game that will only continue to impress. Just, Please, for the love of all that could be deemed holy in the world, PUT IN SOME EFFORT! Seriously, if i see another "Too hard, refund please" Comment, i might have to leave a link here for Dark Souls...And while your here, Watch Robbaz on Youtube :DYou can thank me later...

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I seriously forgot games could be this addicting.After playing around 150 hours of XCOM, my other favorite game, I needed something to break the monotony. Sure, wasting aliens is fun, but you can only blast so many little grey faces off before you need to do something else, and that's where From the Depths came in. I was browsing my cue, and all of a sudden, this weird, obscure indie game called "From the Depths" shows up. Now, it just so happens that I was looking for a replacement to the game Battleship Craft on iPhone, which was removed from the market. When I looked further into this game and found out what it was all about, I was smitten before I even played it. Building stuff? Check. Total control over all your designs? Check. Actual sloped blocks that you can make inclines with (take notes minecraft)? Check. Cool campaign? Check. Destryoing stuff, massive explosions included? Check. Building a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Halo frigate and using it to bring the hammer of doom down upon my puny and utterly overwhelmed enemies? CHECK. I'm pretty sure I'll be playing this game until I stop breathing (and if I'm lucky, they'll have perfected human immortality by this point.)

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								With over 180 hours as I write this, I figured I should give it a review (I'll update it when the full version comes out). The game has a massive learning curve, but it's a lot of fun once you learn it. The new tracking system is ineresting, and realistic, but annoying. I figure you need about 20+ hours of gameplay, several youtube tutorials and steam guides. The weapons are easy enough to grasp, once you understand them. The game is the most fun towards the end of the campaigns and the sandbox mode, where you have near unlimited resources to fuel an overly powerful war machine. The large explosions are always fun to watch, especially one of the HMS Ragnorak turrets, although it is rare (on the workshop, creation by Robbaz). Well worth the time and money, especially if you got it on sale. I would highly reccomend this. Have fun!IGN 7.8/10 Too much water

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								10/10Whether you like blowing stuff up, watching things blow up, getting blown up, or blowing your own stuff up, this game is for you.If you like building, killing, or even the logistics of controlling your 200+ forces around a map for no other reason than to hopefully murder everything in your path, this game is for you.  You can build huge rockets, and accidentally kill your whole fleet (Who needs Identify Friend/Foe addons anyways?).You can build space lazers, and begin FIRIN YER OWN LAZAAAAR!You can make particle cannons, and watch holes get ripped right through ships.Oh look, shields!  Slap them everywhere!  Oh crap now my boat needs 30x it's current engine HorsePower...Fly a jet!...Crash a jet!Go nuts and build a huge cube with a tiny gun on top!Build the deathstar!Completely customize your weapon shells so you can literally flip a boat around 100000 times the size of the bullet that hit it.  (Graviton ram shell).You can build a completely over-powered boat with one absolutely huuuuuuuge turret on top that can fire at 3 bullets per second!Put saw blades on the bottom of your boat and run other ships over -- Who needs turrets?Put tactical nukes on the tip of your ship and ram people to death with it!Get rekt MANY times!All in all, fun game.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								What is it: From The Depths (abbreviated FTD in the future) conceptually is fairly simple. Create your own vehicles and wage war against other player's and/or AI controlled opponents in either scenario play, sandbox or a 'Grand Campaign' setting.This is where it gets interesting. Creating your vehicles isn't a monumental task by any means but it requires a deeper understanding of the mechanics than might be apparent at first glance. Engines are designed block by block and vary in power output and fuel usage. Weight of your vehicle plays a vital role as most engagments are sea/air based and you can't have a boat that bobs and weaves in the water, you'd never be able to hit anything!Basic learning curve is right around 5 hours with no handholding by the game itself. there are some pretty basic tutorials to get you going but by this time you should be able to make a small raft and make it move about with some simple guns on it.Novice learning begins about the 10 hour mark where you've probably completed your first custom cannon and missle arrays and can make a solid ship that doesn't flip over when making a hard turn in rough waves. From here its all about refinement. You won't know how good you are until you match up against some of the big AI ships in the game and even those can be dealt with in clever and inexpensive ways.Multiplayer is foreign to me. I haven't spent any time there yet in my 20+ hours and don't anticipate to do so in the near future.Singleplayer is a blast if yet unrefined. The planned updates are very promising and what the developer has already delivered on is well worth your $20 if you can stick with it, watch/read a couple of tutorials and enjoy figuring things out on your own. once your first completely AI driven ships moves to take out an enemy fleet and succeeds, you'll be hooked.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am enjoying the game very much. The freedom to build and fight your own vehicles is amazing, and it works beautifully for an Alpha game. I do have some suggestions though:1) In creative mode, WSAD should always control horizontal plane and♥♥♥♥♥♥and space the vertical plane regardless of which way you are facing. The current method is unweildy.2) Please, please, please: Instead of having our characters be miniature helicopters that slide and bounce around, just give us humanoid avatars subject to gravity so we can walk around.3) Enemies should preferably be fastened to the deck for the most part. Hovering character melee/close quarters firearm combat is not fun.Obviously this is an alpha and glitches and mechanics problems are to be expected, but these are my biggest gripes. Overall, great game! I highly reccommend it.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I seriously forgot games could be this addicting.After playing around 150 hours of XCOM, my other favorite game, I needed something to break the monotony. Sure, wasting aliens is fun, but you can only blast so many little grey faces off before you need to do something else, and that's where From the Depths came in. I was browsing my cue, and all of a sudden, this weird, obscure indie game called "From the Depths" shows up. Now, it just so happens that I was looking for a replacement to the game Battleship Craft on iPhone, which was removed from the market. When I looked further into this game and found out what it was all about, I was smitten before I even played it. Building stuff? Check. Total control over all your designs? Check. Actual sloped blocks that you can make inclines with (take notes minecraft)? Check. Cool campaign? Check. Destryoing stuff, massive explosions included? Check. Building a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Halo frigate and using it to bring the hammer of doom down upon my puny and utterly overwhelmed enemies? CHECK. I'm pretty sure I'll be playing this game until I stop breathing (and if I'm lucky, they'll have perfected human immortality by this point.)
