content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am not going to have this review be anything more than a review of the features I have experienced, namely the construction mode, piloting a boat and the controls in general. I'm going to start with the construction mode which I feel is the strongest part of the game. In the construction mode the controls are great, they work very well once you learn them which was annoying at start but once I learned what I was doing it got less irritating. There's a huge learning curve involved in this game but numerous online videos and ingame turtorials assist in this matter. My only real grievance with the construction mode is that forward, left, right and backwards are all relevant to the camera instead of being fixed. I personally do not consider this a weak point of the game mearly a different feature that appeals to different people depending upon who you are. The only final issue I have with the building mode is how you can'thave blocks levitate in mid air which I would have found very useful at it'd let me place down "borders" for my vehicle. One other issue I have with the game is the inability to move blocks around after you place them down or select more than one block at a time. To sum this pargraph up the building mod is good and has a very strong series of core mechanics, if with a difficult and often annoying learning curve as well as a few control issues and lack of helpful features here and there. The controls are great for piloting boats, not sure if they work for aeroplanes or the other vehicles as my personal lack of enjoyment with the game drove me off it before I got to that point, but when it comes to using turrets on rotating bases I found the only way I could decently aim was to stand on them which resulted in the turret being shot at an me getting knocked off, all the while I was being shot at. Personally I believe just removing the robot you played as would be easier for the game. When you're in the building mode this removal of the robot figure would simply place you as a disembodied camera. And when controlling vehciles being a disembodied camera wouldn't be useful I admit but a feature that "locks" you to the vehicle looking over it in a third person angle would be much easier. The final point I have to make regarding vehicle controls relates to the weapons and how they are only controlled if you're close to them, at least that was how the means of controlling them seemed. This system of only being able to control vehicles you're robot is standing on or close to sounds a little silly to me, after all you could easily get seperated from your vehicle due to incoming attacks. Over all I give From the Depths a personal 6/10 and I would recomended it if games of this nature are your cup of tea. +Creative and interesting concept.+Good mechanics are sound+Entertaining creating/building system-Intimidating learning curve-Feels unpolished in some areas-Weapons can be difficult to use.

								One of the most amazing games I've come across on steam from an Indie games developer. Nick Smart - the creator, is beyond talented when it comes to game design - mechanics that have so much depth! His extraordinary superpower to churn out amazing, fresh, community driven, and well concieved ideas into great features faster than a team of highly trained keyboard-mashing programmer-bots is astounding!10/10 would bang on first date.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								With over 180 hours as I write this, I figured I should give it a review (I'll update it when the full version comes out). The game has a massive learning curve, but it's a lot of fun once you learn it. The new tracking system is ineresting, and realistic, but annoying. I figure you need about 20+ hours of gameplay, several youtube tutorials and steam guides. The weapons are easy enough to grasp, once you understand them. The game is the most fun towards the end of the campaigns and the sandbox mode, where you have near unlimited resources to fuel an overly powerful war machine. The large explosions are always fun to watch, especially one of the HMS Ragnorak turrets, although it is rare (on the workshop, creation by Robbaz). Well worth the time and money, especially if you got it on sale. I would highly reccomend this. Have fun!IGN 7.8/10 Too much water

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								10/10Whether you like blowing stuff up, watching things blow up, getting blown up, or blowing your own stuff up, this game is for you.If you like building, killing, or even the logistics of controlling your 200+ forces around a map for no other reason than to hopefully murder everything in your path, this game is for you.  You can build huge rockets, and accidentally kill your whole fleet (Who needs Identify Friend/Foe addons anyways?).You can build space lazers, and begin FIRIN YER OWN LAZAAAAR!You can make particle cannons, and watch holes get ripped right through ships.Oh look, shields!  Slap them everywhere!  Oh crap now my boat needs 30x it's current engine HorsePower...Fly a jet!...Crash a jet!Go nuts and build a huge cube with a tiny gun on top!Build the deathstar!Completely customize your weapon shells so you can literally flip a boat around 100000 times the size of the bullet that hit it.  (Graviton ram shell).You can build a completely over-powered boat with one absolutely huuuuuuuge turret on top that can fire at 3 bullets per second!Put saw blades on the bottom of your boat and run other ships over -- Who needs turrets?Put tactical nukes on the tip of your ship and ram people to death with it!Get rekt MANY times!All in all, fun game.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has one of the most powerful vehicle designers I have ever seen. You can build ships planes and almost anything you can think of. My faveorite part is the weapons system. Instead of slapping on a fully funcional gun as most building games do it you have to build your weapons using a combination of blocks that each have diffrent effects on the final weapon. With one block set you can make the main guns of your battleship, the small AA guns and anything in between The game currently supports cannons missiles lasers and particle acclerators. Although the game is in early acess the developer is secretly a GAU-8 minigun that fires patches. In my opinion this is the best early acess I have played but it feels so complete that it could be a finished product

Early Access Review
								This game is totally worth the money... if you spend the time learning how to do anything. I have 1 tip, DO THE TUTORIAL. This game has a HUGE learning curve and can be very annoying. Starting out i recomend just capturing an enemy ship to learn its internals and basic layouts of its type. Making anything in this game is an art, if you make somthing with little thought and testing dont expect it to do much.Oh if you have friends you can play together, multiplayer is WAY BETTER than before, so if anyone said it was buggy or whatever its alot better now.The onlything this game needs is space exploration, it has space but its pretty empty right now (no pun intended)

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has shown me that indie games can be absolutely awesome.Maybe I'm just a fast learner, but after a bit of messing about I'm already making great things. And I'm still just messing about in the designer, building stuff without constraints and such. Which is beyond fun by the way.And you see all those ridiculously fancy pants thingos in the screenshots? I just want you to know that while all these things are huge complex things which probably took whoever made em days on end painstakingly working everything out to the very last block, they're things you and I can make too. I get the odd sensation when I'm playing From the Depths that, yes, anything is possible.Unlike Minecraft, you've got way, way, waaaay more block shapes to choose from. There COULD be a few more shapes, but I'd say that'd just be going overboard, as it is I'm perfectly happy with it. I can make good looking boats, planes, helicopters, anything with what I've been given. In addition, you've got blocks that MOVE. As in, you point your mouse, a tiny spin block points to where your mouse is pointing.Unlike Garry's Mod, you have far more freedom with your weapons and materials. You don't have to hunt through the prop list to find exactly what you need, no, it's always right there in front of you, ready to be grabbed. And it's actually fun killing stuff. Obviously less physics based than Gmod, but, well, you're never really going to want to pull out a catapult to fight a boat when you could fire a cannon instead. Or a laser. Or a missile. It's fun killing stuff.And unlike Robocraft, this game is not actually♥♥♥♥♥♥ It's satisfying to kill things. When things lose blocks, they get blown off and float around for a while before disappearing. When you hit something with a really really big cannon, and it does a lot of damage, it really feels like it. There's no stupid block limits or anything. Unless you build something outside of the designer, which I have not done, since the designer gives me all I need: materials, and infinite space.Seriously, I know this looks like just another block-based building game, but it's the one that I've been waiting for (metaphorically). I wasn't expecting this even to be good. But it is. Just testing out my designs against enemy ships and planes is beyond exhilarating.If you've got $20 to spend, pick this game up. It's eyebrow-raisingly expensive for an indie game, but I'm saying it's well worth it at present.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								From the depths... what can I say.Its like minecraft if you like building block on block but with more block variety.It has moving vehicles that you decide how to build.It has complexities I am still discovering after 200 hours.Ok so thats some of what it has.ProsStill getting new bits every now and thenStuff usually worksThere is no right way to build somethingThere is AI, primitive enough but it does its jobConsMultiplayer still needs work, alot of workThe game takes forever to load (ignore that 20 second load time unless you have an SSD). This has been improved but still not greatThe menu is a little confusing at times but has improvedFeatures in single player do not work in multiplayer (death ray, lots of hydrofoils etc)Do I recommend it?Hell yea. Its everything missing from other creative block games and you can blow up your friends.Tip:If you want to repair fast, get a second vehicle dedicated to repairing to repair you. Repair bots are too slow

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Started off well, the devs actually listened to what changes the majority of the community suggested. Unfortunately, a very vocal minority has taken over and turned the game into a job just to play. You have to do way, way to much problem solving and tweaking to build any ship thats worth while, which has made the designs in the workshop rather genaric and carbon copied. At one point they had hundreds of unique and amazing crafts, now its mostly the same designs with slight variation. The store page has some of these original and unique crafts in the preview images, but they no longer work with the new mechanics or, because of rule/item changes, have become incredibly under powered to the point of obsolescence.I had a few friends who used to play or were interested in FTD, but every one of them has quite siteing the sheer amount of time wasted trying to work around all the needlessly intricut mechanics that take hours to build, trouble shoot, tune, and finally impliment almost any ship. Especially in the later parts/challenges of the game. 6-8 hours of build time for 10-40 minutes (depending on the battle/enemy faced) of fun sucks.It started off as an interesting voxel war game and has become a mind numbing pile of frustrating mechanics and ugly ships whose community has become cancerous.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a VERY interesting game, and I don't really regret the purchase in any way shape or form.From The Depths may be discouraging at first from how complex it can be, and the learning curve can be moderately steep sometimes as you figure out some of the core mechanics, but in the long run, This is an excellent game.When you learn a new method, and master the design you're striving to create, it's a rewarding experience.Are you building a fleet of super light, affordable, mass produced ships, or floating castles that bring cannons the size of subway trains to bear? Will this design philosophy stand up to the test of battle? Only time will tell. Bugs pop up, and bugs quickly get fixed. Updates happen on a nearly weekly basis. Another thing about this game that I REALLY like is that the developer, Nick Smart, is really involved with the community on the forums. He's open the suggestion & constructive criticism, Which is the hallmark of a happy community & productive developer.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is absolutely brilliant in so many ways! I can remember way back when I was just a little kid playing G.I.-JOE's in the backyard. I didn't need the expensive, very cool toys that all of my friends had. Although the aircraft carrier was totally awesome, and the F-14 Tomcat was just bad a$$. I was perfectly fine using my mom's tupperware and various other types of household odds and ends to wage war behind the garage... All I needed was the little, flexible JOE's with cool nick-names. My imagination would take care of the rest!Years later I am 36 years old, work my a$$ off and find it very hard or difficult to lose myself in my imagination just as I did many years ago! That is why I love video games. They give me the opportunity to leave my job behind me, venture off to uncharted territories and save the world from a vile, discusting and viscious evil with capabilities far beyond our very own. From the Depths not only allows me to venture off into La La Land, but I get to create the vessil of which I use to get there! Should I fly, or should I sail? Should I use a submarine or should I use an extremely huge aircraft carrier? These are a couple of the thousands of questions that From the Depths lets me ask. Just as I did years ago with my moms tupperware, I can create virtually any type of vehicle that I want to create... I am being serious... What ever it is that you can dream up, From the Depths allows you to build it. I do have to say that building your dream machine is not a walk in the park... At least not on the beginning. When you first turn it on the game does seem very overwhelming... EXTREMELY OVERWHELMING!!! As long as you do not let the complexity of this little gem detour you from having fun you will gradually get the hang of it amd before you know it you are building your very own Battleship with a vast array of turrets, missle silos, gun bunkers, engine bays, controll rooms and anything else that you might find on a Battleship. Along with other goodies that you would only find in... Your Imagination!!! After you have created a fleet of multiple armed and dangerous multi-terratoried vehicles you may sick your vast army on your friend, or foes vast army. Simply put... This game is a build it yourself version of the game Battleship, Legos, and Minecraft all rolled into one.Although I highly recomend this game and that I truly believe that this game offers custimizable options unlike I have seen in any other game. Please note that it is complicated. It is not a game that you can just walk right in to. I have played it for only thirteen hours and I am still having trouble with it. But for me, the "Juice is worth the Squeeze"! Although it is complicated I am quickly getting the hang of it and having a blast while learning to do so... A BLAST! I just finished building a boat that I have been wanting ti build since I was in the 8th grade. I still have a hard time believing that something I sketched out nearly 23 years ago is right here in front of me plowing along as fast as a speed boat while I am blasting a set of guns that I custom designed myself. Oh I forgot to mention... You can also design your very own weapons which you can put on your custom designed vehicles.In conclusion I would like to say that if you are into building vehicles/forts/weapons, have a wild imagination and a srtong will to learn than this game is definately right up your alley. Everything you could ever want to build anything you want is right there in front of you on your screen. The learning curve is high as the Dev (there is only one... and he is great) has made ther game very easy to pick up as long as you have patience. Please do not let this game pass you up. It is a gem... A diamond in the rough that is still in it it's early stages (which is VERY hard to believe as good as the game runs) but is not far from being polished and placed on display!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14
Early Access Review
								I really want to like this game, it looks like fun and is right up my alley, but I have a few problems with it. Firstly is that I have put just over 3 hours into this game at this point and I am not even half-way done with the tutorial with is not a great first impression. I understand that the game is really indepth and you can do a wide variety of things once you get into the game but getting to that point is a slow and arduous process. If you are a person that just skips the tutorial and starts playing no problem then good for you, but I am not. Secondly, some of the tutorials are more like middleschool quizzes wich is a tad annoying in it's own right. And finaly, one of the tutorials is a little more interative than the others and requires you to build an engine (after eight tutorials of doing just that) which I did not have an easy time with because I accidentally hit the "fill" button while fixing the hull which caused me to take more time than usual which ment that NPCs spawned and attcked me whilst already trying to fix my ship and build an engine. I know that is something that you need to be able to do in the game itself, but I was unprepared for it and had to restart.All in all, looks fun, but the tutorial is a huge turn off for me which I would bupass except that I feel I need it and it levels your "character" which in turn gives you skills it looks like you need for the campaigns let alone multiplayer. Other people are not jokeing around when they say you will spend a week learning to play this game prior to ever actually playing it.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								While the gameplay is fun, the way that the menus and tutorials are written leaves me wondering who this game was made for. "Hamming keys"? "Rage quitting"? One of the tutorial quizzes asked whether a certain mission was "Too hard" or "Too easy". "Too hard" was counted as a wrong answer, with the admonishment of "nonsense" when clicked. The mission took me something like 5 tries to get it right, because the missiles wouldn't fly where I pointed them to. That's an acceptable bug in an alpha, but what's unacceptable is being told it isn't a problem at all. It leaves me unimpressed and not very hopeful that the final product will be any good.Beyond that, the options for gameplay are pretty limited, and again I have little to no hope for improvement in this area given the attitude of the developers, ie "if you don't like it, you're wrong." The gameplay options are1. Creative mode, where you can build anything you want with zero challenge and infinite resources. Bo-ring.2. Adventure mode, where you have resource limitations that force you to build using your head, but also are quickly overrun by waves of enemies that will quickly destroy you, even when the damage is set to 10%3. Campaign mode, which would seem promising: You start out with a large base that is both an excellent resource gatherer and has good defenses. But as soon as a battle begins (which cannot be canceled, despite there being an option for it--it is greyed out with no hint as to what enables it) your home base, and any ships you might have, turn into green rectangle outlines and are useless. You can't even stand on them and your little robot sinks. Selecting to end the battle automatically destroys your ships as "casualties", and then you have nothing.This game has a LOT of areas where it desperately needs improvements and bugfixes, but the die-hard fanbase seems bent on insisting that there's nothing wrong with it, at all, ever, and the devs seem to agree. Don't count on this game being worth your money.As a postscript, I've noticed that a lot of reviewers for this game have mentioned that the learning curve is too steep. I'm not going to discount or invalidate their opinions on the matter, since I'm sure the plurality of such reviews is indicative that there is a subset of gamers for which this game's mechanics will not be in the slightest bit intuitive. I, however, have extensive experience with some of the more finicky mods in Minecraft such as IndustrialCraft and Forestry, and therefore have that background in hooking up blocks correctly. The only hitch I ran into was learning that exhaust pipes are not omnidirectional and have to be oriented a certain way in order to attach. That said, despite fully understanding the building mechanics, and seeing a lot of potential for this game, I once again must say that I have no faith that this potential will be lived up to. Not only have I seen this attitude in the game's writing, the authors of positive reviews, and commenters on negative views, this review, despite being written out with great thought and care, is being marked as "not helpful", by who I can only assume are those die-hard fans feeling salty that anyone might say anything critical about a game they like. This is what is killing gaming.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Saw some interesting videos about the game and decided to give it a try.The game strongly suggests that you complete a series of tutorials that are intended to teach you the various aspects of the game. This is smart, since it would be kind to call the building controls clumsy, and they have a steep learning curve to gain any level of control. This is not helped by the tutorials and tooltips insisting on telling you the default control mappings and not using any re-mappings you may have done.I was a bit surprised at how fast the tutorial ramped up the difficulty, with a very early tutorial "Muddy Waters" giving you a very short time to repair a ship hull and build an engine before enemy ships blow your ship apart. I'm sure this is a trivial task for someone who has played the game for months and is an old hand at using the clumsy building controls to make numerous ships, but having only about 10 minutes to fight the controls to build anything is quite the challenge only a few tutorials in.Just two examples of clumsly build controls:  1) Placing and motion are relative to the camera, not an absolute coordinate system. So as you try and find a camera angle where you can see what you are doing in cramped locations your control direction keeps changing with respect to trying to place blocks on the ship.  2) The cursor keeps moving toward/away from the camera every time you place or remove a block (depending if you right or left click). So if I'm trying to place blocks horizontally I have to keep re-adjusting the place cursor back to the row I'm working on.I'm sure with enough time I could get used to how it behaved, except for the fact that you do not get an opportunity and are thrown into the timed build mission long before you have a chance to get used to the controls. It is literally the second time you build anything, and the first time was a "place the block I tell you here" sandbox mission.The alpha nature of the game is very evident in the help/tutorial sections: spelling errors, sentences that just sort of trail off and missing words are just some of the more obvious. I've also encountered strange graphical glitches like the water surface vanishing; sometimes it is there and looks nice and other times not.TL;DR The game shows some promise, but give it a pass until it gets out of alpha unless you like torturing yourself.(edit for spelling - thanks jordank321)

number of helpful: 1 of 9 people (11%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								When people say a game is hard, most people usually think,  I know it's going to take some time to get used to it, and I may not enjoy the struggles through the game, but in the end, I can succeed. (Don't take that as inspiration . . .)This game isn't hard. It's much higher.Whenever I play a game, or, ya know, do actual thinking work in real life, I can always see the most difficult part first.Starting. (As in the act of starting.)And there's too much work to start out. Vehicles aren't in play yet there's nothing telling you how to put it in play, two different top-down screens to control units (or something like that), EXTREMELY cluttered UI, and lack of polish. . . . That turned into a cons list. Oh well.If that didn't make you want to look away from this for quite a while, then keep reading. OHMYFSM, THE UI IS HORRIBLE. Mostly just the building UI. Whenever you want to build, you always have to have a block selected. But this will get in the way. FIX: Use keyboard controls. But that's not a complete fix; you must always have something selected. This just makes it stay the same size. This would be less of a problem if the art style was changed. Yeah, I like it, but it's just terrible for building. If you don't know what I mean, you can look at the screenshots.I actually went through all the tutorials. Some were great; interactive, able to make what you want, teaching you. Some were just manuals. Some were links to Steam manuals (I'm not joking on that. Seriously). Some were step-by-step building tutorials that taught you how to build something . . . if you paid attention . . . kinda. That means that they were just bad. The tutorials didn't really do anything, so YouTube guides were the answer. . . . They didn't help that much.I feel like this can be related to a Mount & Blade game. Starting out is still the hardest part. Once you have enough resources or large enough fleet (or army in this metaphor), it's a lot easier to actually do things.The game has a lot of potential. It's just that it needs polish, a lowering of difficulty, an art style change (or tweak) for building mode, and more polish. I don't really mind difficult games. But this difficulty (at least for starting out, the most important part) is so absurd. Even when the difficulty was as low as it could go. I can't recommend it.  Yet. I suggest waiting a few months or until it's out of Early Access before looking at this again.

								Look, I respect greatly what they were trying to do with this (and if I were making a similar game, I might've done it too), but they are just being too cutesy and complex with their mechanics. Now MAYBE it is justified, and MAYBE I'm just not 'putting in enough time to know it'- but I just chased around a ship in a tutorial mission for almost an hour trying to destroy it with missles that seemed very interested with flying off about a mile away from where I was looking. That's the kind of stuff that lets you know off the bat that it's definitely going to be a masterpiece. I understand that it is alpha, but this shouldn't be a game where the player should have to worry about whether or not the fate of their creations depends on the block they just placed. If you're looking for a fun game, leave this game alone. But if you seriously want to wade through all the technicalities and asterisks to achieve creating the machines and vehicles this game might offer, it's your money.

number of helpful: 13 of 35 people (37%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'll give this game another try when the sea sickness wears off.Where do I begin?  Ok, first, the lead dev seems to have some kind of thign against the normal intuitive controls used by games liek minecraft ot Robocraft.  That makes the controls for this game about as intuitive as compiling a linux kernal is to a happy emachine user.  First I tried the campaign.  I saw a youtube video from Robbaz and thought "that looks great".  So there I was not quite standign , but not quite floating on a cell shaded hull of a weird floating house on massive rollign swells of the ocean.  I dont' knwo what I pressed that disconnected me from the little robot body, but I wasn't in build mode, because I coudl switch into it.  The fly speed is set way high so strafing was disorienting as hell.  Up and down ofted plunged me into the ocean.  There were signs identifying systems, which was great!  But control indicators were awful.  I hopped into the little skiff.  I figured out how to start the engine.  Yay.  Then i figured out how to control it.  But the littel robot hopped in and I was still floating abouve the skiff.  The UHJK keys worked.  Thats a weird combination when you could just use asdw and a locked cameral.  Whatever, so I quickly accidentalyl drove the skiff off screen.  When i caught up I killed the engine manually, because who thinks to hit T+G to kill the engine.  I dunno about you but I have a single button brake in my car and I figure that is as intuitive as it comes.Clearly I wasn't ready for a campaign, so i quite out of that, which took a nausiating length of time readign white text on light sea blue background.I went into the vehicle designer thinking surely that would be somethign liek the Robocraft garage.  hoyl hell, that was worse.  I was suddenly on a 3X3 raft with the little robot and the waves were crazy.  Ok, so i built out some pontoons and it got more stable great.  The turtorial on engine building was awesome, but again not mouse friendly.  I felt like I was back to the old rubber ball mice I had to pick it up and reset it on the pad so many times.  The best is when a part would spawn for the tutorial, it woudl reset the view (damn thats disorienting), spawn in a cloud of black smoke, and spawn behind other parts so I could never tell what had just spawned.Long story short I flipped my skiff as soon as I tried to drive it.  That caused the build mode to flip to, but the little robot was still right way up and spinning.  so as I was tryign to fix my skiffs orientation, the world was spinnign and the waves were rolling.  I nearly got sick and said screw this.I want to be fair.  I love the idea of the custome engines.  I love the variety and the idea of buildign vehicles.  But this is over complicated, and does very little to help people enjoy it.  This dev needs to get in touch with the Freejam guys who do Robocraft, get his head fixed about controls and gui design, and maybe this idea can take off.Right now I'm wishing I hadn't spent $20 on this.  But I want this to be awesome enough that I'm not ready to ask for my money back.  I'll check back when the sea sick wears off.

number of helpful: 3 of 14 people (21%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Too bad. You died.That's what the most common thing about this game. At least after 7h of playing.But lets start over.The games starts by freezing in the loading screen for 1-2 minutes. After that you are greeted by an UI in need of improvement.So, I started with the ingame tutorials. I got through half of them (36). Except one mission, they were boring and only teach a little bit.In one mission, you just have to rebuild a battleship. With limitted resources you start rebuilding it. Then start over again since the pipes won't connect. The hollow pipes have directions in which gas can flow. Worst part? You get attacked by enemies during your repair. Only weapon you have are missiles you have no idea how to use them, they just seem to do random stuff. Lucky enough, I could repair my engine once again before I run out of resources and could continue the mission.After each tutorial mission you enter a quiz to get some XP. A lot of question were never explained in the tutorial, so you have to just guess. Some questions are wrong - probably confused by own phrasing with double-tripple negation. Also, there are opinion based questions. You don't share the opinion of the dev? Too bad, you fail!For my last 1-2h of gameplay, I started just a singleplayer map.After 10-20 minutes you are overrun by different enemies. I was attacked by submarines, without any knowledge how to defend. The tutorial said, there are torpedos, but never explained how to build them.Next try, I suddenly die. My character was hit by a laser out of nowhere. On the death screen I saw only a laserbeam from far away. The enemy was far beyond render distance.Try again, I engage an enemy ship, suddenly my ship vanish. No explosion, no detectable hits. Just disappears and I lose.Last try, I was hit by laserbeam again.Am I too slow?The FAQ of the game states, it aim at slower paced gamestyle.This promise is not delivered!This game has potential. Lots of it. But in current version, I cannot recommend it.

number of helpful: 60 of 137 people (44%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Huh.  I read a lot of the reviews and they are universally positive.  After seeing the screenshots, the game looks quite interesting.  The UI looks clunky, and the graphics aren't that good, but I was willing to give it a shot.And I gotta tell you, this game lost me pretty quick.The UI is worse than clunky: It is downright incomprehensible at times, and is a serious of confusing beveled rectangles that are sometimes buttons, sometimes radio controls and other times just static text.I had to alt-tab out of the game and look up hints on the forum on what to do or how to manipulate the UI, and these hints were sometimes very vague.  The graphics are jarring and mismatched, as if six different styles of art were crammed together.  (Or six different artists worked on the game.)  The audio is not very good, with the same 30 second sea sound effect looped over and over.  The build mode is clunky and difficult to figure out;  Creating just a simple craft required several hours of tweaking and messing about.The missions are many and varied, but at times it's impossible to figure out what you are supposed to be doing due to the minimal mission-objective UI.  Building the right sort of craft to complete each mission takes a while (due to aforementioned tweaking) and I lost patience trying to win each scenerio.The controls are atrocious.  It uses a lot of none-standard, none-intuitative key binds for critical functions, and it's difficult to play the game on a laptop because of this.There's a lot of depth to this game (ha!), considering how many building parts there and how they can be linked together to make all kinds of vehicles, but it's really just not very playable or enjoyable game to me.   Which is weird, because I read the reviews and people are absolutely raving about this game.  But to me. From the Depths feels like a very early prototype game, a proof-of-concept that needs a LOT of shine and polish before I would have considered it a public alpha.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great concept, horrible execution, not much fun. The controls are horrible, your fighting the camera constantly, the building is tedious, and the controls for that are miserable as well. Just trying to figure out how to build a simple boat that works is a three hour long process. The scheme of the game is all over the place, steampunk, future robot, and post apocalyptic, all mixed together, but not in a good way, more in a different artists having very different ideas. The water is invisble untill your under it. Its just so many little things that make this one big giant crap fest.  The tutorials are also confusing, but they give you plenty to choose from. Read about how to, watch someone else do it, and play through it yourself. However, they aren't very clear, more of click on this to add this now add this, place some of these, and there you go your a good Stanley! After you do them, your like but wait, what did I just do exactly? The controls, argggg the controls. There are some games where your pretty sure thats the difficulty is dealing with the terrible controls or fighting a terrible camera, well this gives you the power of both. Every time you place a block the screen kicks a block forward towards the cameras direction. Which can and will screw you over. Trying to change your creations is also a nightmare if you forgot to add a chair.   I know this is in EA so hopefully they will do something about the control scheme. Because you know half the point of this game is to build stuff to fight others with. So far building crap is so horrible and annoying that only the diehards are seriously building. And thats great, the world needs architects, I'm just not an engineer by trade and didn't read in the description that I should be.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is potentially a great game. The mechanics are wonderful. It runs very fast and smooth and i do love a good meta-strategic long-game.HOWEVER. beginning the game even with assistance of an experienced player is a long, frustrating and unrewarding experience.First you're going to have to get to grips with a very fast, hotkey based control system. -which is great - except you can't modify the keys to your liking so if you're intuitive and fast with another game or program you're going to have to UNLEARN all of that first.Right now i can't stop hitting E because i use it to pitch in a couple of other games (those games allow me to tune the controls when a button clashes) but FTD forces me into a tactical map view about once a minute.FOR THE LOVE OF BISCUITS WHY CANT I REMAP CONTROLS?Also you are in two places. you have an avatar for some reason. No idea why since it's invincible, doesnt do the construction and has such bizarre movement characteristics that you never want to be first person viewing.The second viewpoint is a sort of spectator-cam that moves at supersonic speed with a momentary blip on the directional key. -again adding to the feeling of being trapped in a clumsy, jerky body with no influence on surroundings.OK, putting all this aside you set about trying to learn the ropes 'cause it looks like fun once you know them. You have a few options:Vehicle Designer - infinite resources, virtually nothing to restrain you or drive your build. What am i building for? oh, the campaign. but i have no idea what works in campain. 'cause i'm here trying to get ready for campaign. SO i place blocks for an hour or two, get bored with how awful they look and exit to main menu.Campaign - i go to start campaign since many games use missions as a way to introduce game concepts - Offering microgoals to help the player understand mechanics and priorities - maybe this game will be like that. Nope. Just plopped on a raft in the middle of a hostile ocean with 5 factions at high development levels and minimal pointers on how to even begin to gather resources.Multiplayer - obviously a place you go once the new player skill-cliff is a distant nightmare. I can't offer you any reports on this.I'm glad i own this game because when it's done it could be wonderful but having to re-train my hands to use it simply because the devs won't let players remap controls spoils the experience enormously.TLDR: Great potential. Maybe awesome if you've been playing since day one and all the complexity got added underneath you but it's becoming inaccessible to new players. Too little reward for your time.

Early Access Review
								To be honest, I love this game but can't in good conscience recommend it right now.  Yes, it's early access.  Yes, I know the game will change.  Yes, I know that make tutorials hard.  None of that softens my stance that this isn't worth the time it takes to find out how to play.  Not learn how to play because there's nothing in the game that is useful in *telling* you what to do.  Throwing together a hull and propellers isn't hard, but once you get into building engines or weapons the built-in guides are so scanty that they are very little use.  Especially since some parts only connect in certain ways and there is no easy way to see what is connected without tracing the entire path.  And you need those long paths since the guide examples with one (or a few) of each part are useless in the real game.    Don't get me wrong, the guides are good.  It's the game that doesn't give me the info I want in a useful way.  There's no way to know the number of parts I need without building them.  I *think* it's the ratio between parts that's important, but there's no way to verify that.There are ways to find out what to do, but "Look for people playing the game on YouTube" is not a substitute for in game info.  Let's say you want your base to have a horizontally-rotating turret with a single gun in it to shoot aircraft; that sounds pretty cool!  *Open build menu* Hmm no turret listed.  Let's try custom cannons.  Nope.  Advanced cannons?  Also nope.  Misc tab? Nope^3.  As a noob you didn't go to  'New Object'->'Two axis turret'->'One Axis Turret'.  But let's say we found that and started construction.  We slap down the main piece and hook up the ammo boxes and other blocks to give us the explodey, armor piercing goodness that we want.  How much of each does your gun need?  Beats me.  Just slap things on&off and figure it out.  Finally, we need our gun to elevate to attack flyers.  Oh look, a block called Elevation Barrel!  How many do I need to hit 60-70 degrees?  Beats me.  You have to slap them on and then either scroll your way back to the firing piece block or just try out the gun to see if you put in enough.Figuring out how to play the game should be a choice of tradeoffs.  I should be asking myself "Is it worth the resources to have guns that elevates to 80 degrees or is 60 enough?", and not asking "How in the gently caress do I get a rapid firing gun that elevates to 60 degrees with alternating explosive and armor piercing shots!?"  The entirety of my issues with the game could be solved with a 'design wizard' that would let me see how the number of parts affects the final stats.  I'm fine with something that let's me see that I need x gauge increasers, y cooldown decreasers, and z recoil dampers.  I'll take it from there and work on fitting them in.  Without something like this, I find that I need to regularly stop playing the campaign mode and go into the designer to get a weapon I want.  I would much rather prefer trying to fit in the parts I know I need under the time pressure of an approaching enemy.Full disclosure:  I have still haven't gotten belt-fed autoloaders to connect properly(They work now!  Details below).Gun stats provided in game: -Max shell diameter: 0.020 -Gun has 1m ammo clip and loaderAmmo stats: -Shell diameter: 0.018 -Clip size required: 1mError message that gun cannot be loaded.Can you guess what the problem is?  If you guessed that the shell was too big to fit in the gun, you're right! (although it beats me how I should have known that)  I reduced the number of shell parts and now it all both fits and tears up the Onyx Watch flyers.If this was helpful, please stay tuned.  I'll happily update the review if things improve.

number of helpful: 29 of 75 people (39%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								!WARNING!This is a long review. The short version is this : The physics aren't right to the point where the AI is the only reliable pilot. Unless the physics are fixed, the game will be unplayable for me. I don't find it fun to design an amazing ship only to watch an AI have fun with it. Unless you are prepared to spend long hours trying to learn the mechanics of this game and brave the incredibly steep learning curve, I would recommend you waiting until the game is developed further. It has great potential, but very serious issues holding it back from being great.1. PhysicsA: BoatsB: Planes2. Tutorials and learning3. User Interface.4. Controls( Note that the other categories I can't cover due to character limits. So what if my review is 17,138 characters long? That's how many characters I need to sum up the experience! So I'll just cover the main issue. )	I've sunk a few hours into this game and I liked the concept. But I didn't realize what that concept really was. I came into this game expecting something like Starmade but with planes and boats. What I got was something very different.1. PhysicsThe main issue I have with this game is the physics. They just aren't right at all. The objects don't behave the way you would expect them to and the forces that act on objects don't seem right at all. Thrust of any kind on even a very heavy object don't seem proportionate. I will try to explain.	A: I first tried to make a boat. After long hours of fruitless experimentation, I found out that boats do not take into account account the amount of air inside of an enclosed space. I experimented on this concept and found that I could have two objects of the same weight but different volumes of air and they floated identically. So this tells me that the volume of air is not being calculated. The weight of the object seemed to be the only factor determining it's buoyancy. Both of these objects had air pumps, I should mention.Initially when I was making my first ship, I thought that it would be best if I start small and aim for a ship that could move quickly. The issue with making these small boats was: Whenever I would put a significant amount of thrust to the back side of the boat, the nose would rise up out of the water almost immediately and the boat would backflip in the air and land upside down in the water. So of course I tried moving the rotors to the front of the ship only to have the same issue. I got very frustrated and added immense amounts of lead blocks to the nose of the vessel and even with more weight than the entire hull of the ship, the nose would rise up out of the water and the boat would capsize. Naturally I gave up on the idea of a fast boat as it was clearly impossible for me. So I moved on to making a sturdy boat that might be able to withstand some punishment as I couldn't seem to move very quickly without capsizing. After a long time I made something that was barely buoyant but I was able to reach about 20 – 24 meters per second without the ship flipping. Even this was only possible with very close attention placed on the 'water drive'. If I pushed it to the maximum, even that would flip it. So I was able to get a ship that weighed 1251.51 go at about 20 - 24 meters per second, which was the fastest I had gone in the water without the ship flipping, but I could not get a ship that weighed 118.75 to go any faster than roughly 6 – 10 meters per second. And even at that speed it would flip. Even with this small victory, there were yet more problems. Now the issue was that I would roll over completely if I wanted to make an even relatively sharp turn. Your ship does not right itself well. Period. It does not act it's weight. What I mean by this is that everything is very 'floaty'. If for example my nose would climb out of the water and I would end up perpendicular to the water ( my ship's nose pointing directly up into the sky ) the ship's nose would fall back into the water at the same speed as the much smaller 118.75 weight ship. As for the rolling of the ship, the same thing is true. Now, if you want to use a cannon, oh boy, you had better hope you're not shooting broadside because if you do, you're rolling! The strange thing that I noticed is that you could be stock still in the water and if you try to turn, nothing happens. This makes sense as the rudder is the only thing turning you, assuming you don't have rotors on either side of the nose of your ship to try to turn you. ( Even those don't seem very effective in my experience.) Now if you get any kind of speed, your ship will start to roll if you try to turn it. It's not as though it's rolling from the force of your speed as it seems to start rolling at 1 meter per second. So you're moving it 1 meter per second and you can completely roll your ship belly up in the water. This does not work in reality. I have been on big ships. It doesn't happen. So it seems like instead of having true ship physics, it feels copy pasted from the plane physics. It's rolling the ship like a plane would with ailerons. So sharp turns in ships would only be possible if you were to use the rolling to your advantage and then attach rotors to the underside of the nose of the ship and the use that to turn yourself, again, like a plane might. But that's not feasible as your nose is likely to be out of the water, and if it isn't already, those rotors on the underside will solve that quite quickly.	B: The next thing were the planes. I struggled immensely with planes. It was nigh on impossible for me to get anything to fly that didn't  act as if it had twenty anvils attached to the tail. Every time I built a plane, it would pull up constantly. It was as though the joystick of the plane was pulled back at all times. I would have to try to push the nose of the plane down constantly just to stay level. It was infuriating. I eventually found something after hours of testing that would sort of work. It was a flat block shaped like a T with wings at the upper ends of the T. The weight almost didn't seem to matter as far as the constant rising problem; As I could make the entire T shape out of heavy metal and it wouldn't make a difference. It would, however, cause the plane to fall more quickly but did nothing to affect it's orientation. As soon as I tried building the T thicker, it would go back to the constant rising.So about the only thing I was able to make with any kind of success was a fortress. Yes, a massive floating piece of metal that barely moved.  With a gun.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you aren't understanding the tutorial 1hr in and aren't enjoying anything, refund it because it does not change at all. Best advice would be for a demo consisting solely of the tutorial and a free build mode to be released so that people can try before they buy. Game is overly complicated just for the sake of being so. The default controls make the dark souls mouse+keyboard controls look good, the tutorial makes you look at youtube videos to learn how to play rather than doing the job of a tutorial AND TEACHING YOU HOW TO PLAY. Seriously, kerbal space program is about sending stuff into space and does 1000x better at teaching the player how to play as well as makes it engaging, whereas this is a game about building things and making them fight other things and collecting resources. A game about rocket science is less complicated and more fun than a game about building stuff and blowing up other stuff.Suggestions:Make a proper tutorial that spends more time having you build things than it does giving you slideshows with bad camera angles and manual pages to read.Put the fixed tutorial and a free build mode up as a demo so that people don’t waste time and money on something they don’t like.Wouldn’t recommend this to anyone who likes building games unless they were looking for kerbal with added layers of complication and dark souls controls.

A game, which on the surface, looks interesting, unique and frankly deep in its options for creating voxel vehicles fall short a minute into its introduction. Do you want to relax and build? 								First off let me say that fanboys will downrate any negitive reviews for this game so expect that. This game isn't worth $20, In fact I gave the gift back to my friend so he could get a refund. For Free I wouldn't play this game. Cons: Seriously Bad Controls for Both Keyboard and Mouse. content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game looks amazing, runs well, and has a great concept. Sadly, I am not a ♥♥♥♥ing genius. The game is extremely hard and the game mechanics are not explained. There are so many different settings and options and I do not know what they do or how to use them (such as difficulty. The difficulty option is garbage. Instead of easy, medium, and hard mode, it is 0.00-???.) I tried to play but the cannons would not work. I searched the boat for the computer thingy that I saw in a video. Apparently, this thing was very important and turned on the boats AI. I found it but turning on the AI did not make the ship fight back when enemies came by. I also played some other mode where I had to capture a ship but I was killed everytime I got close. I placed a cannon but it did not work so I could not defend myself. I tried to steer to the ship I had to take over but my boat flipped over. I assume that I need to place some sort of ammo container but I could not find one in the inventory. I also noticed that every single object says press Q when you get to it but pressing Q only controls the AI unless you press it on a door. This is garbage and I have requested a refund. Maybe I will buy it when there is more explanation and help added. I am VERY VERY disappointed. I was expecting a fun game about fighting ships and flying vehicles but I got a game harder to control than Kerbal Space Program (and that says ALOT about how difficult it is). I rate 1/10. The 1 is for the good graphics and good music. This game is only fun to watch other people play. A waste of $20. I am very♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off about this.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great uninstall simulator. 10/10 Would uninstall againThe developers seriously need to address the insane learning curve that haunts this game. I understand that they are aware of this and are taking measures to combat the situation but more still needs to be done. The game seems like a complete cluster-f**k of huge buttons being thrown in your face right from the start. The UI is clunky and half of your screen is taken up by the GUI when in-game. Even with all of the "helpful" tutorials that come with the game it is still hard to grasp the basics. I appreciate that it is in early access but it is still not worthy of the £14.99 price tag. I do enjoy complex games that take a while to master but "From The Depths" takes a while just to navigate the menu and controls. The game has a huge potential and i love the concept. Hence the reason that i decided to pick it up. I just hope that the developers can continue to improve their game. Overall i do not recommend the game at the moment and this negative review will remain until the developers do more to address the situation.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Do not get this game until they fix the terrible building controlsPlaying this game feels like a chore, that is, if you want to create things. The combat in the game is very fun, but that is where the potential of this game comes to an end. In order to create even the smallest of boats, one must spend upwards of an hour to make it work properly, and even then you end up with a peice of♥♥♥♥♥♥that can't compete with the workshop blueprints. I feel like this game is unplayable to anybody not willing to spend at least 4 hours learning the mechanics, which sounds easy and tolerable at first, but ends up being a drag. You will buy this game, start it up and then think that for some reason you can jump right on in, and that you don't need to watch the tediously long videos on how to change the direction of a wooden triangle. You will start to build a boat, then halfway through get frustrated and go back to watch the videos, you will then repeat this process around 4 times within the first hour of the game.It is so frustrating that you start to get stressed, not a good stressed like facing a boss in dark souls, but the type you feel when you have an essay due in an hour and you haven't started it. I feel like the one and only reason this game is getting good reviews is that people don't want to admit that they can't build anything amazing so they act like the game is simple.All in all, if you buy the game stick to using other peoples stuff and actually play the game, don't spend hours attempting to learn the building basics that are on par with the difficulty of the blender software.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								3/10I saw all the pretty little screenshots and thought wow this must be an amazing building/combat game!!!BOY was i ♥♥♥♥ing wrong.1: the learning curve on this is ASTOUNDING. There are extensive tutorials for this game, but the tutorials throw you right into a MASSIVE builder, which is literally EVERYTHING you can build. Seriously? you just expect to us to comprehend all of that info?2: The combat is awesome... IF you or the other person knows what the hell they are doing. I see this game as a more advanced toribash.3: The limited amount of experienced players are mostly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S. I came across one guy who i had asked for help while we were battling. He taught me how to make a neat ship, it was a tiny little raft with one cannon. His ship literally steamrolled my ship. Did i mention how this game works? which finally brings me to my next point...4: BIGGER = BETTER. If your ship is the size of a planet, chances are the other guy's game will crash or he will be destroyed by the shear massiveness of the ship. For example, There was a ship i came across called the "titanic battleship" Sounds really impressive right? if you like a ship that is basically a giant ram. No matter where you came at the ship from, you would destroyed. For a noobie at a game like this, there are SUPER simple changes that could MASSIVELY improve the game. Like seperating the building portion into three parts, Boat, Air, Space.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								The building in this game is good especially the keyboard controlls BUUUUT  the way you stear the vehicle is bad. Maybe if they attached the character to the wheel would be best and using the normal controls for steering. Instead you just have to be on the vehicle and it uses different keys on the keyboard. The game controls are so cluttered that any new person has to drown in video tutorials to understand how to do anything. Also the UI is crap and WAY overcomplicated. you can build your own engine and guns is really cool but the menues and UI tries throw so much information at you that it becomes too much. Final gripe here is the bots. In first person there is this limb clipping where if you turn the arm turns before the head and you can see detachment which is annoying. They also have poor models and textures. Finally their movements are too wild in and the ability to fly and survive under water ruins the feel of the game.TLDR summery: controls are very bad, UI is very bad, player model is TERRIBLE, way too much learning and not enough playing, building is cool.This game has SO much potential and perhaps by release it will be one of my favorites but until then I reccomend you skip over this one for now.

number of helpful: 10 of 42 people (24%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Build your own vehicule (submarines, ships, planes, spaceships, ...) with blocks and fight the others, would be funny if the early access was not a bit too early. Because every main aspect of the game is not finish and all frustrating.First, let's build something. Anyway you dont have choice since this is the only thing you can do at first. So let's try ! Yeah, let's more see the video first looks a bit complicated. Beacause yes, a 1 hour video can quickly teach you how to do (I never thought one hour could both look so long and go so quick). You move the cursor with arrows, and click to place stuff (shouldn't it not be the contrary ?!). First surprise, the notion of "forward" depends on where you looking at ! Yeah, because nobody remember where is forward on a ship ... You have many keys, each one changing something and managing to not make building easier. Then, what to build ... there are hundreds of blocks. How is it possible ? Because many of them are useless copies of the previous ones ! Angle block just to make it look better, longer block for ... I don't know, isn't the main objective of blocks that everything is build of single same size blocks ? A good surprise, engines and weapons are complex pieces with many quite logical parts to tune it (like a canon with ammunitions, automated loaders). But some other are not: the engine is a complex part where everything must be conected, but helixes can be placed anywhere and magically get the power ! Anyway, I couldn't make neither my engine or canon work, so let's skip for the missions which magically unlocked.One aspect I forgot is that when you build your ship, water magically goes through it. Let it be clear, a boat for full of water sinks. Wood is slightly lighter than water, but with all the metal stuf like canons, it sinks. A boat only floats because of the air inside, like a baloon. So why here it doesn't think even if half of the bocks are the engines and the canon ? because the wood is as light as polystyrene ! So now, a polystyrene boat is not stable. So you need to put lot of lead under it to stop waving everywhere ! Boat do have a stabilizer, but it's not supposed to be heavy, just large to avoid lateral movement by friction. And friction is something this game totally forgot. So, now I have a fast boat, and I need to go somewhere. Let's have fun and crush into a big boat. I pushed the heavy polystyrene gallion on the side, then due to collision bugs we both started sinking, then physics rembered we are made of polystyrene so we start going upward, while friction kept not existing so we both accelerated, then finally out of water we jumped hundreds of meters high is the air, and then felt back in the water as deep as we were, and go on ... Next mission, I have a boat with cool saws on it and I need to destroy anither gallion. First surprise, my view is inside the ship, so I cannot see anything ! I found a way to have an outter view but the boat is too far. Next try, I hit the boat, but once I go deeper inside it falls on me and I cannot move. Tens of tries later and after adding saws on the boat, I destroy the right side of the gallion, make the bottom totally explode (it says I destroyed 40% of the ship) ... And the gallion is still floating like a piece of polystyrene. I had to destry 70% of it, and I never could make it because of stupid physics and collisions, and other ships firing at me.Other mission, on one plateform, few canons to use to defend, never could fire with one. Another one, the boat goes so fast it cannot turn. When I see the IA driving the planes like a sick ostrich, It says a lot about the playability. And I didn't talk about the useless robot you control and sinks deep in the water each time you lauch the building mode, or the fact that the games doesn't pause while building the so the boats keep waving everywhere and the parts you cut fall in the ship without anyway tot ake it back. Clever.So let's face it, this game is not finished, does not worth the 20€ it asks, neither the 8€ I paid in sold. Building anything is light year from the playbility of any minecraft-like game. The two main elements which make a boat go, the air inside and the friction, are totally absent. Driving anything will only bring you frustration. Looks funny on the paper, looks like many people already have fun on it, but right now it's too unfinished to even be called an alpha.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								After going to the forums to discuss issues I was having with the creative direction the game was taking (Removing features, implementing repeated unnecessary ideas, general things that made me worry that the game was suffering from "Perpetual alpha syndrome") I met with the Reply of the creator, Nick Smart.I tried to offer Nick constructive crticism, I told him his team was talented and that I was worried about the game experiencing alpha problems that will prevent a proper release of the game as it is advertised and described. He proceeded to directly insult me and insintuate I was a loser for spending so much time test playing his game for him. (Why did I pay you money again?)So, The game is experiencing a lot of problems; but the bigger problem is I don't know if the problems will be fixed or even cared about or viewed as problems because of lack of professionalism in Nick Smart. What I do know is that they are removing advertised features to streamline code on a very unstable game that slows down and crashes frequently for many, meaning that it can no longer be described as a sandbox strategy game in any but the "mobile strategy style" sense. It is still a sandbox game, but not as described on steam because they have definitively given up on certain design goals. They should update their advertisement to reflect this or reform their design goals.The company is obviouly lacking an end goal for WHAT this game wants to be, and they have no plan for addressing this problem. Because of this I am afraid it will never Leave Alpha. While this is a fun sandbox with some customisation, the game concept experiences too much turnaround as newer and increasingly poorer ideas get added far too frequently. By nailing so many additions to the game concept, they are splitting the game into coding and conceptual splinters. It is almost like they are willing to break their game in order to push it further toward a theoretical release that I honestly don't see coming.Buy this game if you want to have fun in an alpha application where you design cartoonish boats that don't obey physics, Don't expect much else, especially if what you expect is professional courtesy from Nick Smart; who frankly is unlikely to  get any more of my business after this venture. This is not "Early access" in my opinion, this is a "broken game". Buyer beware, if you must buy, wait for a 75%+ sale.This is a soft no for me, if the designer learns from his mistakes before it is too late, this game may have a future. I am totally willing to change my review if they learn to listen when half their forums hate major changes(Why ask for input if you are not going to take the input?). Though my position on the managment issues will likely remain.P.s. Hey Nick, thanks for reminding me to review your game in your forum tag. I would have totally forgotten otherwise.Very Smart of you.P.P.S. After posting this review, I have proceeded to be harassed by both the creator and his fans repeatedly over the span of several weeks. This is pathetic, unprofessional behavior and I hope to never do business with this company EVER again. I am amending my review, Because of the Behaviour of Nick Smart, His Employees, and his flying monkey-like forum troll fans this is now  a Hard NO. I cannot support business practices like this, even if the game were perfect, which it certainly damn isn't.TL:DR If I could still get a refund I would. Instead of taking criticism they lash out at paying customers, F*ck That. If you have to play this game, Well..."There be pirates aplenty on the seven seas." Don't pay these jerks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								I find the game fun, creative and entertaining. There are many brilliant designs on the steam workshop and the awesome battles just make the game better. The campaign can be difficult, especially if you are not careful with resources and do not bother with the diplomacy menu (you are enemies with a faction from the start).You can upgrade the character using points from levels which I find very interesting. I would not think that would exist in a game like this but it does and thhe devs have done it well. It is unfinished as some 'attributes' are not implemented but the weapons and skills can come in good use very quickly.Missiles, cannons and lasers are HIGHLY customisable. You can make missiles a certain length and make parts of a missile funtion differently. e.g. Make it 4 blocks long with a thruster, fuel tank, heat seeker and emp to make a small, heatseeking emp missile. You can create giant lasers with an advanced AI to shoot lasers from high up into space (Yes, there is a point high up in the air where you can place a craft and it will float without going up or down unless you use thrusters or push it.)You can create your own cannons to shoot down aircraft or act as a giant anti-ship gun. Or if you don't have much space/ don't know how to work these things you can use the simple weapons. Just one click and then you have a small missile/ laser/ cannon/ torpedo.The heartstones can be a bit of a pain in missions so do NOT bother with it in the campaign. The player has a limited 'charge' and the heartstones fill that up to keep the player alive. Unless you want to play the game in a restricted way do not enable these. Not enabling these will also make boarding and capturing ships a lot easier (only to be scrapped using the scrapper and the resources going to be used for a bigger 'project').Apart from the steep learning curve and complicated controls that are a bit hard to learn then all I have to say is...BUY THIS GAME(P.S. get a good CPU. The game can be demanding in huge battles or even just having one large ship.. Also some things can be very complicated and confusing just to try to get it to work.)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well, after reading so many positive reviews of this game and seeing some vids, I bought this game.The building part of this game is a dream, with having to build your guns and engines from parts and it actually making a difference how you arrange said parts. It is what I always wanted in a game like this, and this part is really brilliantly done.Then I spawned in a large ship to get a feel of how the game actually plays.Uh oh.The controls didn't really seem to do what I wanted and the ship decided to move on its own even after I told it to stop. At some point it got stuck going right for some reason? I could make it stop by holding the appropriate keys but it started moving again when I let go. I couldn't find out why.I started over, spawned in another ship, which seemed to stay somewhat put this time. However I forgot to tick the "Spawn in vehicle chair" option so I was somewhere else inside the vehicle. Ok, I'll go find the chair.I tried to make my way through the interior.  Well, let's just say being a moving entity inside a moving entity is something that many games don't get right. Maybe it's a game engine problem, I don't know.I spent 2 minutes trying to walk up a ramp to a door to make my way through the vehicle but I kept getting stuck against whatever and the camera clipping though stuff made it hard to orient in the confined space.This alone was a bit of a turnoff for me. If I constantly have to fight with the controls and camera to do things then I'm just wasting my time instead of making and controlling crazy vehicles. I understand due to the nature of this game that it can't be as smooth and clean as in, say, Minecraft, or even Starmade, but I did expect much better.I may try this game again when it's out of Early Access, as it really comes close to the game I always wanted (which is basically Space Engineers with weapons and engines and stuff actually built out of individual components).

content:

Early Access Review
								Submarines? Yep. Fighter jet? Yes, Battleship? Of course! Missile platform with mega sheilds that launches 58 missiles that you customized yourself? yes. Mothership that builds bombers and launches hundreds of hot air balloon laser defense systems while at the same time it can transfer between being a ship and a floating fortress? You can do that. Not to mention the open world campaign where you destroy 8 other factions in tremendous battles of 40 ships or more. The game will purposly move to slow motion to preserve frames and keep it from bugging out. You'll see why when you get there. This is the greatest battle game I have ever played.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game is a work of art!!! Talk about hard work from the developer. He handles bugs and adds features faster than any other developer listed on steam! My hats off to this guy! Steep learning curve, but thats because there are so many features. This is hands down the best voxel builder game on steam period! There are no other games around where the player can design and program the behavior of custom vehicles like From THe Depths. This game is challenging and the rewards are appropriately awesome. I spent about 17 hours designing a massive battleship with all kinds of weapons and the AI to control it and all the control and behavior blocks work like a charm.... you can build almost anything that you can think of and instead of just sitting there like alot of voxel games including minecraft, these come alive. The community is vibrant and workshop is a great repository of vehicle designs. Also a big plus, many of the top players take time to help people who have questions on how to build/design complex creations. If you post a question on the forumns it will get answered quickly and politely. This is the shining example of everything an early release game should be!!! Its literally light years ahead of the rest. This game can suck you in and reward the player until many hours have past and all you want to do is design ever cooler vehicles and fight the tough AI factions. The more I play the more I want to play. This game does not devolve into a grind or repetition, it evolves into an engaging EMERGENT experience that keeps on giving back to the player. This game is WAY BETTER than most AAA games released in terms of long term engagement. Get it and enjoy it!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29
Early Access Review
								Now that i have spent nearly 750h playing this game, i think i am experienced enough to rewiew it:Positve things first:+since this game was released, all the changes wich were made added some realism, like improved textures, better LUA/AI programming, etc. to help vehicles to behave more realistic and overall btter.+more stuff to play around with: more and more interesting weaponary and machinery was introduced in the space of a few patches, APS and CRAM-Cannons, aswell as improved Fuel engines and the (at the moment) stupidly powerful Steam engines!+PID and LUA: with the help of LUA-coding and some PID-blocks, you are able to completly reprogram the behavior of almost everything, from hovercrafts to missiles!+the campaing: the campaing now has 7 factions, wich all come with unique desings and aesthetics and, of course, ever increasingly powerful weapons. This leads to the player being forced to adapt, because you might be able to crush the first faction with some HE-minigun, but later stuff like shields, heavy armor and Laser-anti-projectile-systems come into play, so you need to change your tactic. This not only helps to make the campaingn less boring, but also lets you explore new types of vehicles/weapons.+difficulty options: In this game, if you want to increase difficulty, the enemy is not given absurd amonts of health, but more difficult desings spawn:  for example the Onyx Watch has a focus on heavy batlleships with lage HE cannons. On easy this doesnt change, but on expert they will spawn stuff like the Bulwark, a MASSIVE battleship with massive amounts of armor and HE gunsbut also low caliber sabot-anti-air miniguns or FRAG shells. Combine this with a complete shield bubble and moderatly good missile defese, this is a force to be reckoned with. Also there is the Eryie, wich is basically a more powerful FLYING Bulwark.+You can build absolutley EVERYTHING, from a submarine with lasers to a Spaceship with 500mm HEP-miniguns!its all up to you, what you build.Bad things:-the controls are as strange as ever, but after a few hours you get the hang of it: WASD are the avatar controls and space is to jump, but airplane controls are YZIKHJTG for roll/pitch/yaw/left/right/acceleration/decelleration-VERY steep learning curve: i spend ~100h in the desinger, testing my vehicles, before i was able to beat the campaing, because you need to get aquianted with all the machinery first.-The LAG! You will need a rather powerful PC, if you want to runn larger battles with acceptable FPS: an intel I5 8500 or better and a GTX 800 is recommended by me. (my system specs, i can run this game reliably in most cases).However, if you do naot have such a PC you can still play this game and have fun, but battles will take longer and the game will slow down time for improved FPS.All in all with a decent PC, this game is overwhelmingly awesome, because of the sheer amount of well-made content.And keep in mind, this is in the BETA-stage and the game is being constantly updated by the DEV. On the Forum you can share ideas and vehicles and even custom campaings (CC for short)!I would definitivley recommend this game to anyone with imagination and creativity9/10
