number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								So I'm going to be honest about this review. Sure I recommend this game - but only to those who are willing to put time into researching the basics of the game or are willing to try, fail, try fail, try, fail and eventually succeed. I can't really say mutch about the learning curve of the game, as I had watched 5+ hours of footage bofore even looking at the game's store page. From what I've read of the negative reviews of this game the overwhelming majority of people have less than 10 hours in-game and they complain about the lack of a tutorial (there is one, if you look). And the clunky UI and controls. Sure, if you don't like the UI, that's your choice - but those who are used to the UI will most likely agree with me when I say it's quite informative. As for the controls - yes they can be a little offputting at times, and currently not rebindable (I'm sure this will be added at a later date) but like the rest of the game - you get used to them. Oh, there is a mouse building mode (much like minecraft or space engineers) and that may fix your problems.Now, onto why I think this game is great:+The game has surprising amounts of depth (pun intended)+Encourages creativity in designs+Very expansive campaign mode+Useful building tools+Whilst only haveing a few types of basic block, there is a very wide variety of types of said base materials+Nothing is indestructableNow, some of the negatives:-People may not like the learning curve-The game recently became much more complex with the advanced cannons-Non-rebindable controls (will remove when added)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Minecraft and Carrier Command had a baby, and this is it.Yes, there is a learning curve, but it's a painless experience; building boats and vehicles in the designer, and practicing against whichever AI you choose to spawn is complex, but fun.  It will probably take you a while to figure out to make a ship, and make it move, but the satisfaction once you do is enormous.  You'll soon be churning out design after design in minutes once you've got the hang of it; and once you've got the hang of it, you can try your hand at the entertaining campaign, which an almost RTS-like / x-com management experience, punctuated by nail-biting, real time battles.Make no mistake, this is a PC gamers' game, old-school and simmy, with a steep learning curve, fiddly controls (at first), but the rewards are deeper than anything you'll find in the majority of games.  Weather you're expressing your creativity, or min-maxxing your builds, watching your creations come to life and SMASH THE **** out of other ships and craft is deeply, deeply satisfying.  It's not a quick-blast, but the kind of game you settle into for months on end.  We're talking Ultima Online and Eve levels of depth here, and that's not a comparison I make lightly.Oh, and in terms of content and stability?  I wouldn't have known it was early access if it didn't say so on the steam page.       Seriously, it's that good.  Patches are frequent, and there is already enough here to keep you busy for months on end.I heartily recommend this game.

Building a plane that goes 80 m/s and and wrecking your friends in some multiplayer is really satisfying. 7.9000964231/10 Would contemplate refunding again."You know, ♥♥♥♥ the hippies." -Robbaz

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's like pixel pirates in 3D. It's my new dwarf fortress. It's confusing, unintuitive, very difficult to understand, buggy, over ambitious... It's kind of my jam. The physics engine alone gives me a boner. For ages couldn't figure out why my ships kept capsizing at the slightest provocation. Turns out the game has physics, so the ships need keels. Didn't even know keels existed. Turns out they're a thing:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keel#/media/File:Capsizing_effect_of_keel.svgI now know what "keeping it on an even keel" and "keelhaul" meansKeelhauling is ♥♥♥♥ed up dude. I'm pretty sure they mention it in at least 1 Disney movie. If people actually knew what it meant I do not think they would have. Seriously that's a ♥♥♥♥ed up way to go. Walking the plank is for♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								HUGE learning curve, but great community to help you over it. Very satisfying destruction with developers who work hard. Tons of customization, and realistic limits (most of the time). Has it's own control scheme to help you build faster, but it still takes forever to build something you're truly proud of (not the developers' fault, just the way the game works w/ massive designs). Love the concept of ai-controlled vehicles, but the air ai can be a bit silly sometimes, and subs also have a few problems where they drag themselves on the bottom of the ocean. To sum up:Big learning curveTONS of customizationAWESOME explosions/fightsGreat community (from what I've seen)Time-Consuming (like most builders with this level of customization)Self-piloting vehicles (very difficult to code btw, gj developers)Still needs some work (hence early access)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Alright so some quick notes before I get into gameplay. 1) This game is CPU intensive. The recommended specs will get you by but treat them more like minimum. Farther into the game with more and larger ships, explosives and fragments the game will start crashing down on an I5 4590. Going to test it out with minimum specs a little bit later.2) This game will eat RAM. 4GB is what you should treat it as needing for itself ot for your computer.3) GPU? What GPU? This game runs beautifully across what many would consider terrible graphics solutions. However as you upgrade you do get better looking materials and therefore a better looking experience.Onto the fun stuff!This game is not for the impatient. It takes time to learn the skills and abilities to apply many different areas to create you first successful ship. My personal recommendation is to start out in the vanilla designer and first make a hull that can float and stay floating. Gradually work on things like making efficient and powerful engines. Test out guns and ammo. Find out if you prefer personal control or AI. Care for a more technical build that can out manuveur and outgun your opponents? Try making multirotor flier. Prefer to get straight to the action? Big boats and big guns. There are so many options out there to build and combine different pieces of this game. One playthrough ended up with a "capture chariot" becoming a flying fish. No guns but hey when you are travelling 75m/s just slap a couple rams up front and you are solid.

C'ya on the battlefield

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								I initially posted a very negative review. Now that I understand the game better I’m enjoying it, but I also have more criticisms, which I won’t post here because it is a long and detailed list.At its core, the concept of this game is amazing. There are many unique aspects which are inspired genius. It’s apparent that a lot of thought and a lot of work have gone into the game's mechanics.From my perspective the developer has taken the construction style of Minecraft, minus the landscaping and crafting, and nothing as complicated as red stone logic gates (expect maybe LUA blocks), and combined it with the vehicle design aspect of Kerbal Space Program, with more focus on weapons and defence and less on physics (e.g. no orbital mechanics!).There is an RTS style capaign in which you mine and use resources to spawn the voxel based vehicles you design and have AI pilot them.There is also a first person aspect, as you interact with the world through an avatar, which I believe is superfluous and detracts from the game with unnecessary added complexity, especially considering you can move the camera independantly and still interact in all the same ways without the avatar. On top of that there's a levelling system and a skill tree.It has probably the steepest learning curve of any game I have played, but that's not due to the concept, its due to UI design, controls and at times infuriating camera controls. I spent the first 5 hours or so hating the game. Sheer determination got me through. I still felt I had a lot to learn after 30 hours.I think the game could have broad appeal, but that will ultimately be limited by how well the developer can address the usability problems and simplify the learning curve. The in game tutorials are good, but not detailed enough. I hope links to external videos are removed from the game in favour of more tutorials.As an RTS, there may also be inherent limitations to what can realistically be simulated but I’m confident the developer will work how to balance the game’s performance (without forcing the player to manage that).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is by far one of the most enjoyable games I have played in a very long time. It gives me the same feeling Minecraft did on that first day. It's packed with content and endless possibilities. Functionality:One of the most powerful aspects of this game is the building system. The game offers two styles for building. One is much like Minecraft, and the other is unlike any game before. You are able to quickly and easily switch between the two by hitting F3. Where one building style lacks speed, the other picks up. Building vast expanses of wood for a ship? Try using the Keyboard mode. Trying to piece together the perfect engine? Use the mouse mode to be more accurate and percise while having full rotational control and snappy movement.Features:All that I have played at the moment is the Co-op campaign with my friend. We are about 15 hours in, and have built several things. The game is packed with tons of menus and features that can be somewhat overwhealming at first. As time goes, you begin to understand every menu and feature and at some point, about 10 hours in, it all clicks. Building becomes quick and easy, the battle events bring pure elation and excitement, and the laid back time between battles allows for you to truly create and expand. The game offers features for both visually focused players, and those who prefer stratergy. With an expansive and massive map, you will easily be able to put hundreds of hours into the game and still create new and exciting builds and fleets.Mechanics:One of the most driving aspects of the game is the adaptability of the physics. You can build almost any creation you wish. From submarine, to ocean liner, flying bases, planes, helicopters, airships, rockets, spacecraft, space stations... It's virtually endless. Even land vehicles are a thing. The physics allow for realistic events, like buoyancy, lift, drag, wind, gravity, and anything else which brings the world together. Building a boat takes a little planning as you must keep it from becoming too top heavy and flipping over. As well, the game tends to automatically create things like windows and various other structures based on block configuration, allowing for beautiful and dynamic builds without extreme effort.Visuals:On the surface, the visuals are simply acceptable. As you become more involved in the game, however, they start to make sense. The islands and ships you encounter, as well as those you build will become ever more beautiful. To account for issues during battle, the game will automatically slow and present awesome 'slow-mo' events to prevent your CPU from exploding. A very clever way of handling massive ship battles and constant explosions. The art style is something like Borderlands, which actually makes the game even better. Landmasses and the world looks more realistic, with your character and ships looking more Borderlandish. This makes the game feel happy, even with the dogs of war howling in the distance.Audio:Possibly the weakest point of the game. It has sub-par audio. Engine and ocean noises are there, but fairly generic. Music during battles is great, and interestingly, there is hardly ever music during peacetime. This doesn't seem to bother anyone though, as it presents a more calm tone and allows the user to focus on building. None of the noises are annoying, even after playing for 6 hours straight. The game audio is acceptable, but should be improved as development extends, which I believe will happen.Conclusion:Do you like building, learning, exploring, growing and being a pirate? Are you an engineer? Do you enjoy Minecraft but want something with a more interactive environment? This game is for you. It offers much more than just Co-op multiplayer as well. There are PVP teams, deathmatches, missions, singleplayer, design (creative) mode and several other game types. If you are looking for something revolutionary and are willing to put a few hours into learning the game, you will not be dissapointed. Whether you want to load your ships with AI and watch them rain hell, or control the weapons yourself and unleash terror upon your enemies, this game is astounding.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								From the Depths is an Early access Game (as of review) with not only alot of potential, but with alot of that potential already in the game. The premise is simple, build fighting craft and duke it out, once you start to play you realise it isn't that simple. From engines to custom guns it has a very steep learning curve but theres something about building that more effecient engine and that new triple barreled gun that is so satisfying, especially when you're bearing down on an enemy that can only hope to dent you. With the campaign and some story modes in the game there is so much to do for an early access. The story are set missions you need to accomplish, this are recommended for people with a bit more experience in the game though. The campaign is the first stop after building ships in the ship designer (with a brilliant keyboard build mode) the campaign pits you against other factions in a fight for the planet, you start off with one base and one boat but soon start to build up your fleet as you attack and defend to capture more resource points scattered around the map. This is where most of my time has been spent so far, even when you get defeated by a new airship that your enemy has developed its ok, because you go back to the drawing board and design something to counter it. All in all this is a fantastic game that i predict will become a huge success and I hope it does. I can't recommend it enough. The only thing I can find as an issue is the crashing, there can be quite a lot. They either need to fix the crashing or add an autosave as soon as possible. theres nothing worse than losing a large ship because you forgot to save.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								All I can say is WOW, well done. There arent very many games like this that can  keep my attention for very long, and this one has succeeded. Absolutely LOVE being able to tinker and create your own ships/planes/ submarines/ bases etc. A lot of games I decide to buy and test out end up being OK, but I usually feel a little let down , kind of like a "this is it?" feeling. I did not feel that with this game at all. Absolutely one hundred percent recommend you get this game. Definitely worth the money, an excellent game. This game literally lets you build whatever you want, however you want. SO MANY different ways to play and strategize.A Suggestion for the Devs:Maybe consider adding a "world mode" , where there is an economy , and unique places to explore on this planet. Have this mode be like an rpg mode, where you can trade, explore,  and have adventures with friends. instead of just fighting all the time. I absolutely LOVE building ships in this game, its so enjoyable and relaxing, and sometimes i find myself a little bummed about the fact that the game is about war, and fighting. I would absolutely love if there was a mode where you made the world youre on feel more alive, where you start off in a small town, a social hub of sorts where people can team up for adventures ( and maybe make your character bot slightly customizable) and build a small exploration OR cargo vessel and slowly make you way to resource zones and check out a world with a little more detail. maybe  add some wildlife ( sharks, more land animals. some trees, maybe underwater cave systems, etc) It doesnt have to be a HUGE difference, but maybe a modified map, with a few tweaks here and there to give it some more life. more things to do.  That would be very fun for me. I do enjoy the fighting aspect to this game, but if you did something like that, it would open up SO MANY possibilities for gameplay. you already have awesome gameplay basics, everything is so well done and detailed. Anyway i hope you see this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								A phenomenal building and combat game.At first glance, From the Depths' building system seems clunky and plain boring, but after a half hour you're getting the hang of it, and an hour later you have your own ship, which you painstakingly have constructed. Then that ship turns out to be a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ and gets blown up in it's first fight. So you build another, learning from your mistakes, and then another, and another, until you're a ♥♥♥♥ing badass and you understand everything there is to know about building an efficient killing machine. The level of customization for your creations in this game is literally ♥♥♥♥ing insane, and it's not even done yet. You get to choose from missiles, cannons, lasers, drills, rams, and other weapons, but it's not just that simple.  You can choose the SIZE of your missiles, their PAYLOAD, their RANGE, GUIDANCE METHOD, EVERYTHING. Same with the cannons, you can make the equivalent of a .50 caliber machine gun, or a tank cannon, or a machine gun tank cannon, or any damn thing you can think of. And then you can load it with the ammo you want. It's like ♥♥♥♥ing Chipotle with the choices in here.If you've ever found yourself in any building/sim game, and all of a sudden it's an hour-and-a-half later and you've built something amazing, then this game is for you. Brb, building a ship that is a gun.~Lucky

								One of the most addictive and fun games I have played in a long time.This game turned out to be a nice surprise to me as I very nearly didnt buy it and even when I did the steep learning curve almost put me off. If you are looking for a quick jump in and play without using your brain this is probably not for you but if you enjoy a game that you can tinker and play with your designs for hours to get them just right and enjoy a bit of complexity then Im sure you will enjoy it.The interface takes a bit of getting used to and you currently need to spend some time in the forums and on youtube figuring alot of the stuff out as things like engine design, weapons and even just figuring out how to build a ship that doesnt float like a brick or a plane that wont fly straight takes alot of practice. Stick with it and you will soon find yourself putting out better and more complex designs in no time. Just be aware this game is a massive time sink and I have found myself getting stuck into a design and before I realise it 8-10 hours have passed and I still have ideas to try.As an early access I am really enjoying it and cannot wait to see it improve even further !

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Have you ever dreamed of a game that is a mix of minecraft, total war, FPS action, with some pirateering thrown in for good measure? If so, this game is for you. In From the Depths, build a ship (or fleet of ships) in order to wipe out the opposing factions. You do this by capturing resource zones where you can drill for resources to build bigger better ships. This simple goal leads to a very open experiance. The map/planet of Nieter alone has about seven or so factions to interact with through a simple to understand diplomacy panel, a massive amount of space to conquer, with some islands sprinkled in to use however you like. That's not even mentioning the built in planet builder, where you get to create a whole new experiance, or the planets that the developer is probably planning to patch in. The planet itself is not whats interesting however. Its the ship building. You have a very wide range of blocks, each with different functions to build your fleet with. You can build everything from massive steel battleships, to wooden sail based gallions, to riverboat paddlesteamers. If you find that you dont like building ships, you can board and take over the enemy ships. You could say "Screw sailing" and build an airship if you so choose. You can costomize every aspect of your ship, even the guns/lazers/kim jong un approved missiles it carries. I definitely think that this game is worth the money. FAIR WARNING: This game is fairly difficult to learn. Be prepared to do some resarch/ watch some youtube videos.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was in the office, bored as a clam... browsing the Steam Store for something new that I could play once I got home, I saw this, and since I really like Minecraft, Legos, any game that gives me the chance to build and design I purchased this bad boy, and boy did I got a bargain.Started the game and took a head on dive into Creative mode.At first the quantity of things appearing on screen can be a bit overwhelming, the game tries to solve this with a few tutorials and hints on screen. At the beginning it will ask about the building mode you will want to use. If you're like me you're gonna end up using both, according to what you do. There is a briefly steep leaning curve, but thanks to modern technology you can always resort to the all mighty Google and his loyal servant Youtube. So saying the game is complex and hard is really no excuse at all, maybe you're just a bit lazy. Your first constructs will be floating blocks of wood that will be more dangerous to themselves than to their enemy, you will do boats that do backflips and roll over. You will build and destroy your creations over and over again. And then, maybe finally you start getting the hang of it, and you will be astounded with the great differences between your first builds and the last ones.You will come up with a crazy idea in the middle of the night and you will stop whatever the hell you're doing because you MUST see if you can come up with this huge deadly AP quad cannon.The creative mode is all fun and games, because you don't have any impediments about realizing your most wildly ideas about naval warfare and what not because everything its free. The fun part of this game, it's the campaign, this game mode is a trial by fire. If you don't know how to properly manage your resources and device constructs that can repel and counter the attacks you will suffer, you're gonna get your robotic♥♥♥♥♥kicked and then some more. Thankfully, thanks to the incredible huge versatility we have during building, the possibilities to overcome any and all challenges are endless. Huge♥♥♥♥♥cannons are a little bit OP and you can totally pummel anything that's within your range. There's tons of options about proper defense, anti missiles missiles, anti missiles laser systems (this last one can be quite the ♥♥♥♥♥ to proper build, I suggest using youtube) and thanks to the last update we have LUA programming for even more dangerous weapons of mass destruction. The naval AI can be a little clunky sometimes, but it's ok.It you like designing and tweek around, this is the game for you, it may be a little complicated at first, but once you get the hang of it, you start gliding on the build mode doing awesome things in really no time.I for one really liked this game, the community is great, the devs are great, this is a solid 10/10. I can hardly believe its still on Alpha, once we get the full release I most likely will die from a stroke because of the excitement. But hey, it was worth it.Get this game now.

Early Access Review
								This game is an Engineer's wet dream. There is almost no limit on what you can build and I like the learning curve. When you're mile long battleship works after toiling with it for hours, it is so rewarding. So many options on anything. This is a game you could possibly replay forever. Every campaign could be different just by using different designs. I will say this game runs horribly as it currently stands. My PC far exceeds even the recommended requirements for this game, yet even medium sized battles only average 12 fps. If they would optimize this game, I would have no problem saying this game is worth $100+ dollars. If you can put up with the low frames and sorry performance, you have yourself an easy buy here.Pros:-Extremely fun-Infinite Replayability-Rewarding learning curve-Build anything and watch it fight for you-Large variety in enemies and their respective tactics-Easily worth the priceCons:-Extremely low FPS, even on high end PC with lowest graphic settings

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								do you like to build things? Do you like explosions? Well this game lets you build almost anything which will eventually explode!This game (although still in alpha) is great if you like building and real time stratagy. it is an open world sandbox game with physics that lets you build ships, planes, helecopters, floating forts, and even an orbital death star if you want. If that seems a little too complicated than the steam workshop has lots of user created erm... vehicles to use in campaign mode or to use and abuse in the vehicle designer   The main campaign is about world domination, you get a small fort and a little boat in the corner of the world where you have to attack and defend againsed different factions each with their own different erm...vehicles using your own creations or things from the steam workshop fighting over precious resource zonesStory mode is a little sparse on content (The foundations are there for more ) you'll get given a vehicle/structure or specific number of resources to build with in order to complete a specific task. e.g. Build a fort and survive 3 waves of enemy.  This is a great game, the learning curve is a little steep for the new player and the ingame tutorials are a bit vague but just look at it as a challenge. The graphics are nice, the gameplay is nice and the stuff you can build is insane. There is plenty of community support on steam and on the From The Depths forums. The devs are very often on the forums too gathering loads of user feedback and creating patches/updates fairly regular (which is good for the game but bad for old aircraft...)

Early Access Review
								This game is allows for a very diverse play style, though mostly based around an RTS field of commands. If you've ever wanted to have a military simulator that allows for hand crafted units, you should take a look at From the Depths. Even if you don't end up playing a campaign. You can still have fun learning the ways of creating formidable warships or even aircraft and ground vehicles.As a person who owns a shoddy laptop (a 32 bit windows 7 with 2.98GBs usable RAM and an Intel i5 m480@2.67ghz), I find this game runs relatively well, especially at low resolutions. Although I have problems running large craft, I still find my experience enjoyable. One thing to note about this game is it's learning curve, so if you do buy it, check out the tutorials (at the time of writing this, it's in the top left region of the main menu).And finally, before buying this game, I highly recommend watching videos of people playing this game (like Enter Elysium for example). It may allow for a better understanding of how the game works.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								There's a Tl;Dr at the bottom for the lazy among us.  This is one of "those" games. It's complex, deep and rewarding but also approximately as welcoming as a brick wall to new players. To give you an idea, the default control scheme needs a video tutorial from the developer in order to make sense. Are you scared by that? Good, 'cause you should be, that's an intimidating intro to a review. However, it's not as bad as it sounds.   While the systems can be a bit impenetrable at first without some help there is plenty of help to go around. There's a big community of people willing to answer questions on the forums, video tutorials covering basically every aspect of the game and, when all else fails, a very informative UI once you get used to it. Communities like that rarely form around games that aren't worth the time. Also, while the systems can be a bit complicated it's for a reason. They're fairly unique and actually kind of elegant in a way, once you're used to them you wouldn't want to change them because they represent the sheer amount of customization possible in the game.  Speaking of systems and community and all that jazz, the dev seems really nice and updates are coming very regularly at time of writing. the last two months have seen two huge updates that not only tweaked and fixed things but also introduced entirely new components and systems into the game that have had big effects on how we design things. I have zero complaints about how this early access campaign is being run, and I've been burned a couple times now so I'm a bit more critical than most.  Now on to the fun bit... you can build pretty much whatever you could possibly imagine (or at least an angular interpretation of it). No, I'm serious, this isn't the typical minecraftian "build anything" shtick, you really can. If you feel like it you can build a working star destroyer in the same game that you build a scale model of the bismark, along with the queen anne, the enterprise (both nautical and otherwise), the avro arrow or some crazy original design that probably shouldn't work but does, all of which can have attached AI's that allow them to pilot themselves. More importantly though, there's a reason to build all that. This game actually has a campaign, with enemies to test your designs against and a goal to direct yourself towards. There's also workshop support for player made campaigns full of player made factions with player made designs that open up virtually infinite possibilities. Personally I think that's what most of these "build 'em ups" are lacking, a point. You have experiences to learn from to make a more efficient design, something to do when you're sick of sticking blocks to other blocks as well as some genuinely good strategy gameplay that let's you take direct control of any unit you bolt a controller to. It's the kind of game that people who enjoy this kind of thing could play for years without getting bored. And I haven't even touched the multiplayer, that's not (entirely) from lack of desire but from just the sheer wealth of things I can do on my own before having to resort to including other people to supplement the fun.The Tl;Dr  If you're too lazy to read a review to get an informed opinion then you probably should be looking at games that don't focus on menial tasks like building stuff.Seriously though, this is a fantastic game once you become acquainted with it, containing virtually infinite content for those inclined. There's something for people who like to build unique designs and people who like to watch other peoples unique designs explode into confetti. It provides a structured challenge to lend a point to the creative aspect of the game with systems that promote experimentation. It's one of the more well managed forays into early access with consistent content updates that have significant impacts as well as being a game that's good enough to play already. Basically, buy it is what I'm getting at.

Early Access Review
								I like to build stuff. I like to blow stuff up.This game lets me do this in a spectacular way.This game lets you design your own vehicles of destruction, and the choice is yours if you want to unleash them on your friends in multiplayer, or on the AI factions in the campaign.When you first start this game up and try to build something awesome, you will most likely fail. DON'T GIVE UP! Keep trying to improve on your designs, and eventually you will have built some incredible crafts that you can be proud of. It takes some time to learn the mechanics, but when you do learn them you will come to love this game. The recently added tutorials will help you to get started, and I insist that you give them a go early on to get a good grip on what to do, and what not to do.The developer is constantly working on cool updates and is very active on the game's main forum. Just yesterday better support for land vehicles and modding was added. Tank battles, here I come!

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								It just looks like your run-of-the-mill voxel buidling game, but it breaks away those preconceptions within minutes. The sheer scope of the game is mind-boggling! Create ships, planes with and without wings, space stations and ships, submarines, buildings, and newly added land vehicles, only limited by the strength of your PC!  Jump into the designer mode to realize your internal warlord, then spawn in any enemy to learn how its made! Learn, build, and destroy to your hearts content until your forces are strong enough to contend with the denizens of Neter, then subjegate them all in open campaign.  The community is very supportive, and the Devs are open, funny, and active on the forums.  there are tournaments, contests, RP players, replica builders, and scientists to welcome you.  Make sure you have a day off after you buy it, you'll need it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								From the depths is a fantastic idea with lot of potential that you can already experience in the Early Access.In this game you build a ship or aircraft (or a combination of both) using a combination of blocks (think minecraft) that you then use in a Campaign map to destroy other crafts, or in single event battles against others.The crucial element of this game is that each element of the build (engine, guns, missiles, hull) is itself built by blocks, that, depending on what you want to optimise, requires non-trivial choices of configurations. This reasoning applies to everything:* hulls: material and structure affects: attrition in water/air, area of exposure, weight vs armour.* guns: length of gun barrel, shell exit velocity, shell composition, reload time, barrel cool-out time, affects effectiveness of the shell on target, size, area of exposure to enemy fire.* missiles, mines and grenades, torpedo (pins, Infra-red detection, warhead size, etc.)* engine (cylinders, turbo-chargers, exhausts, etc.).For example, an engine can be built to be very heavy and efficient (in fuel consumption), but can also be lighter and less efficient, or optimised for low-RPM, or for high-RPM, and this depends solely on the blocks you choose, and how they are positioned in relation to each other.Finally, the combination of each of these pieces then makes the craft itself suitable for some things (e.g. a bomber, a battleship), but very unsuitable for others (a fighter, a submarine), and is therefore the combination of different designs that leads to total victory.Ah, and, of course, you then actually drive/fly the thing, or put an AI doing it for yourself. And there are a lot of other things (resources management and logistics, strategy and tactics in campaign), that I will not even touch here to simplify... It has the best ingame tutorial I ever seem (and I play computer games for more than 20 years), very good game mechanics, and lot of non-trivial decisions for the player.I strongly recommend this game.One of the major drawbacks of the current state of the game is FPS. Despite all the efforts from the developers, it is still in pretty bad shape, and I do hope that the code base on which this game is programmed allows to fix this outstanding issue.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								From The Depths. Status of review = Early Access.Graphics 8.5/10.For the game and what I believe it is supposed to be ( Building/RTS ) Things at this moment are Really well done, Everything looks fairly clean, including the water and land textures. as well as the majority of Block textures.Gameplay 8/10.I actually want to give this one a 10/10, But a few things hold me back. The majority of ship/fortress and or constructable control is what it needs to be. Resource gathering I find is grand for this game as you just need ot provide enough power and construct the appropriate collector to get what you need ( Over time that is ). But the shining gem that is still left in the dirt is the AI control and it's rather stunted options as to what you can do, a fair amount of ships that I have made or came across in the workshop do horribly dissapointing things. Flying/propelling directly into other constructables, Nose diving into terrain or water, or all together just blind running suicide missions into enemy ships.Overall 8/10.For it's place in Early Access it is quite well done and has a lot of potential to evolve into a really beautiful game.Worth it at full Price?Well unless you are a supporter of Early Access and know what that really means, or have a passion for a game of this type then I personally recommend waiting to grab this the next time it is on a Steam Sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								I find the game fun, creative and entertaining. There are many brilliant designs on the steam workshop and the awesome battles just make the game better. The campaign can be difficult, especially if you are not careful with resources and do not bother with the diplomacy menu (you are enemies with a faction from the start).You can upgrade the character using points from levels which I find very interesting. I would not think that would exist in a game like this but it does and thhe devs have done it well. It is unfinished as some 'attributes' are not implemented but the weapons and skills can come in good use very quickly.Missiles, cannons and lasers are HIGHLY customisable. You can make missiles a certain length and make parts of a missile funtion differently. e.g. Make it 4 blocks long with a thruster, fuel tank, heat seeker and emp to make a small, heatseeking emp missile. You can create giant lasers with an advanced AI to shoot lasers from high up into space (Yes, there is a point high up in the air where you can place a craft and it will float without going up or down unless you use thrusters or push it.)You can create your own cannons to shoot down aircraft or act as a giant anti-ship gun. Or if you don't have much space/ don't know how to work these things you can use the simple weapons. Just one click and then you have a small missile/ laser/ cannon/ torpedo.The heartstones can be a bit of a pain in missions so do NOT bother with it in the campaign. The player has a limited 'charge' and the heartstones fill that up to keep the player alive. Unless you want to play the game in a restricted way do not enable these. Not enabling these will also make boarding and capturing ships a lot easier (only to be scrapped using the scrapper and the resources going to be used for a bigger 'project').Apart from the steep learning curve and complicated controls that are a bit hard to learn then all I have to say is...BUY THIS GAME(P.S. get a good CPU. The game can be demanding in huge battles or even just having one large ship.. Also some things can be very complicated and confusing just to try to get it to work.)

								Good game with great potential. This game is diffrent form just about any other game i have seen. It has alot to offer, with a near infinate replayability and multi-player (i have not yet tried the multi-player so no comment on how well it works). Realy the only big problem with the game is the fact that when you start the game the learning curve is like rinning head first into a brick wall. The developers are obviously tring to fix this with tutorials built into the game. The tutorials that are built in make it more like running head first into a brick wall with a pillow on your head or a helmet depending on how much time you are willing to spend watching tutorials. the way i attempted to learn the game was by watching a lets play of it and then tring to do the things the guy in the lets play was doing and looking at the ingame tutorials whenever i got stuck. I don't recomend doing that, I ended up losing the game and restarting the campagn 4 times because of it. The only other thing that i think sould be changed is the difficalty right at the beginning of the game the 1st or 2nd enemy you fight is a army of flyers and warships. I think they sould add in A LOT more before that kind of thing shows up it makes the beginning of the game feel rushed and panicked (especially for a new player), and makes the learning curve feel even steeper because it puts you on a time limit to elimination.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								I do not often write reviews for games on Steam. It is not something I am inclined to do, given that most games do not entertain me enough that I feel justified in preaching about their good points, nor do they manage to bore or antagonize me so much that I must tell the world of the evils of their binary code nightmare.From The Depths is, as far as I can remember, the only game I have reviewed on Steam, and until something else as enrapturing floats along through the store, I am sure it will remain that way. The real joy of From the Depths is the engineering and building aspects. To take a concept, a simple outline of a deck shape, and then craft it over the course of several hours into a weapon of war is a joyous thing to those who love to tinker. Many hours I have spent refitting my various craft, the majority of them not spent in the grand strokes of deciding armament, propulsion, outline and armour. No, most of my time is frittered away testing. Endless testing, until I am absolutely satisfied, or completely frustrated at the performance of each system.And once your many hours of tinkering, designing, hairpulling and testing are over, you finally decide to put your craft through a live fire test. Unless you have been playing for a very long time, it will inevitably fail, or perform far below expectations during the test, usuallly because of a minor error in the design, or an enemy suited to counter what defenses you have in place.This is where From the Depths really differs from several 'Engineering' games. In From the Depths, I must consider bouyancy, drag on both the hull and superstructure, armour thickness from a variety of angles, armour spacing, and a myriad of other tiny details. It is in these minor details that the difference between a good and a great craft is made. Novel engineering is the name of the game, creating simple but efficient methods of doing things, testing out new ideas, scrapping bad ones, repurposing old ones. It is a game where my creativity matters far more than my ability to click on low resolution grass blocks.On a closing point, I think that the truly stand out feature of From the Depths is the relatively realistic damage model. Ships do not simply have a HP bar which indicates it's relative closeness to a complete and sudden loss of all structural integrity. The granularity of the damage model allows for several real life armouring techniques to be used, and in the event that they fail, makes for lovely looking wreckage.All in all, if you enjoy tinkering, building, or even just detailed damage modelling, then this is most definitely the game for you.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								From the depths, this game has really caught my eye on youtube from various people such as Robbaz and Lathland and i really desired to get it for myself I could of waited for a sale, but no I payed full price as I could not wait to get my grubby hands on this pure amazment of a game.DO NOT BELIEVE THE IDIOTIC REVIEWSPros-Unbelievable amount can be done-Creativity off the charts-Complex and intreging-lengthy campaign that can be tackled hundreds of times-calming-Fun-Developers that care and will update regually-inspiring-Everything can be adjusted or made (weapons, missles, cannons,engines,hulls,fortresses,Mega satalites)-Large community creations-nice adjustments to difficulty-Helpful forumCons-though complex it can be very tough to learn and can take days to even master the basics of building-lengthy time to build can take hours or days master your builds to full refined finished build (can be good)-Extremely large battles or a handful of highly complex vehicles can kill lower end pc's-bad multiplayer (i say yet because it is in Alpha-Beta and is not complete buggy-Bugs (Remember it is a alpha-Beta)I have played this on another PC a lot so dont mind my own play time.Overall i can say it is worth its full price as This has thousands of play hours waiting for you, to put into prespective i can barely make a Efficient engine For my battleships i have made. so please buy for yourself and if your not sure wait for a steam sale and pick it up for under £10Dont be affraid of how complex it is and take your time to learn and familiarise yourself to building(watch a few youtube videos {Robbaz and Lathland})9.2/10-one of the best creative games out There.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								August 7, 2015   So far, From the Depths is a wonderful game.  The options are endless.  However, it will take a while to get used to, I recommend reading a few guides before you attempt to build extreme masterpieces.  The in-game help is very extensive, so you'll never feel truly lost.  I have yet to explore many of the other options this game has to offer, because I have spent nearly 40 hours building basic propeller based ships.  I haven't even attempted airships, big fortesses, submarines, planes, or even laser based weaponry.  There will be many more hours of exploring this.  The campaign feels awkward, and the odds are extremly against you.  I haven't explored it very much, but I'm sure it has great potential if I ever figure it out.  The UI isn't as clunky as some people say.   9.5/10  (Still don't understand the campaign.)March 26, 2016   From the Depths is still as exiting as ever, the possibilites are even more endless now (as if I had even gotten close to running out of things to do), the From The Depths teams pumps out massive update after massive update. I now have 200 hours in the game, I still haven't really attempted the campaign (although it does look simpler now), and I have stuck to water based ships the whole time. There are almost too many things to do in the game, however I do have a complaint. Some of the multiplayer function do not run parallel to the single player functions. All that this means is that building may take slightly longer in multiplayer, due to the lack of th sort  of copy and paste option that is present in single player. I could see the From The Depths team adding this in eventually, as there are many people who play multiplayer and would love to have these options.   9.8/10 (Absence of multiplayer functions.)

								Thought it was just going to be another block builder set in a sea setting.It's another block builder. With guns. Guns that you can build the barrels to affect firing characteristics. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								NOTICE: This review was written during the alpha stage of the game.Do you like games like space engineers where you get to build machines and fight with them? Then this is your gameDo you like to drive boats and fly planes? Then this is your game.Do you like RTS games? Then this is your game.But seriously. This game will eat your life.You can build anything from submarines to spaceships. I even built an ICBM launching seacrawler with LASERCANNONS!!!Now to the actual review.Once you jump in the game you will immediately notice what is going on behind the menu. Those are actual ships from the game, fighting each other. At first you are locked from the campaing and only get to play around with the vehicle designer and story missions, which is not a bad thing. You will be spending most of your time in the designer anyway. Designer is more like a creative mode where you get to spend as much resources as you want and it is a good way to design ships with no fear of enemy attacking you, unless you want them to. Story missions however are small scenarios. There are a few story missions which unlock some blocks for you, so you want to do those as soon as possible. But BEWARE. Story missions are NOT easy.In the campaing mode you gather resources, build your armada, fight the enemy and do some politics. Not much politics. Mostly bribing. But it plays like an RTS game. You select your units and move them in the map. You build radar arrays to remove the fog of war. You build fortresses which gather resources and build you more ships. You can even automate shipbuilding to some extent. I've played the campaing for 12 hours now, and I only hold 1/4 of the map, with the most dangerous enemies yet to come. So campaing will take time.If you've read this far I have to warn you. The game has a very steep learning curve. It does have ingame tutorials, but they do not cover everything. Best advice: Read the descriptions on the blocks.And lastly the positives and the negatives:+ Freedom+ It is in alpha and works better than many released titles the days+ It doesn't really lag, it just goes into slow motion+ Helpful community+ Fully configurable AI controlled drones, weapons, ships and pretty much everything ( if your AI controlled plane decides to ram a mountain mid-battle, it's your fault not your planes.)+ All factions and their lore are community made. The dev chooses which ships to take from community made ships.+ A nearly perfect mix of building, fighting and RTS+ It has multiplayer+ Very steep learning curve (Keeps you interested, but also + GIGANTIC SPACE LASER STATION WITH INTERCONTINENTAL BALLISTIC MISSILES AND A FRICKING HUGE CANNON WITH EXPLOSIVE ROUNDS AND SUPERFAST FIRERATE THAT HAS SHIELDS AND A CRAB ON THE TOP...Negatives:- Very steep learning curve (it's also a positive, but might scare newcomers)- Some content is locked behind story missions- AI needs better tutorials ( Again this is alpha)Conclusion:If you want a good allround game with building, fighting and strategy then buy this game. It is alpha but you don't really notice it ingame. If you get stuck and don't know what to do, go to the forums and ask. The community is really helpful and might even download your vehicle blueprint, fix it and send it back to you, all while telling what exactly you did wrong.10/10 Would let the AI ram my plane to the side of a mountain while chatting with a friend.

Product received for free
Early Access Review
								What's not to like about LEGO in combination with physics, engineering and explosions?If you are the kind of person who likes to work out how things work, optimize your designs, and test them to destruction, then ye be warned: hours of your life may be at great risk of never returning when you start playing this game.I found that building ships, shoot them until they sink, and then reiterate with better guns, torpedoes and what have you, can be quite the joy. Especially if you delve into the community and take part in the community-run contests. There is a lot to learn in order to make effective ships, but don't let that stop you: it is quite wwasy to get started with.Even if you just want to design ships, aircraft and even tanks for your own pleasure, this game let's you eat your heart out.The graphics first put me off, and the loading at the start can take a little time. Some small bugs exist here and there, but are usually dealt with in the next update.Taking the game as a whole, I found it to overmatch my expectations. It wont be long or it'll be the game with the most hours played in my library.On a side note: I got it for free as a birthday present. But knowing what I know now, I'd invest the 20-odd euros which was its cost at that time happily myself.Just don't come here telling me I didn't warn you about losing many hours of your life to a game that looks like it came from the early 2000's...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								174 hours later, I regret nothing.Voxel survival games generally disagree with me on one major point: Mining.  I hate mining.  I hated in in EVE Online, in FFXIV, in Runescape, even in Minecraft, which can at least claim to offer some solace from the monotony by throwing in procedurally generated caverns and dungeons and such.  Starmade was promising for me, but unfortunately, the first thing you build in a Starmade campaign is - you guessed it - a miner.  Space Engineers made it prettier, but more complicated and ultimately just as boring.  Even Elite: Dangerous has mining, not that it forces you to participate in it, but still.Apparently somebody who developed FtD felt the same way and decided that resources should be acquired not by shooting at rocks but by capturing and defending points.  The mining gets done automatically, so you can be elsewhere doing other things while still getting all the materials you need for your next vehicle.  This is brilliant.  Obviously it's less of a skill-based mechanic (I guess you can be good at mining?) and more of a time-based one, but this makes sense for a real-time strategy game, which From the Depths most definitely is.On a macro level, the combat in From the Depths is similar to hybrid turn-based/real-time strategy games like Ogre Battle.  Once built, your vehicles can be moved off the board and replaced by simple sprites.  The point of this is to accelerate the game clock and allow you to move your vehicles across the map in seconds rather than days.  Of course, your enemies can do this too, so you need to consider visual range or else you might accidentally bump right into an enemy fleet that you'd rather avoid at the moment.  FtD has the potential for grand strategy campaigns, though currently the installed campaign is big but simple.The combat really shines on a micro level, though.  Vehicles conform to realistic physics.  Ships can float by the buoyancy of their materials (like wood) or by airtight pockets of ballast.  Too much weight on the top of a ship will cause it to capsize, or tilt one way or another.  Put your propulsion blocks off-center and you'll spin rather than turn, or dive rather than push forward.  When you've got everything perfect, that's great - but what happens if somebody blows a hole in your starboard ballast?  Combat is ultimately about exploiting the physical weaknesses in your opponent's vehicle while making yours as failproof as possible.  And there's certainly a lot of ways to make failure happen.  Customizable cannons with armor-piercing shells and penetration-fused explosives?  Check.  Depth charges and torpedoes?  Check.  AI-controlled drone vehicles launched from a mothership?  Check.  Laser-guided missiles, laser-assisted flak cannons and just your typical face-melting lasers?  Czech.  I think the best part of this game is arguably the hundreds of hours you could spend just learning to craft and perfect the weapon you need to counter a specific threat, or a variety of threats, and then dropping it on the deck of your ship before running into an enemy cruiser.If there's just one problem with this game, I'd say that the sound effects can get awfully monotonous.  I don't need to hear the water plunging sound every time I put my camera beneath the waves.  Before Advanced Custom Cannons came around, every cannon shot, big or small, played exactly the same sound effect.  Now the pitch varies based on the size of the cannon, but it's just the same .wav played faster or slower.  I'd like sound effects for engines, cannons, missiles, et cetera, to be moddable in-game so that I can put a real 20mm cannon sound behind my gatling guns.  That would be pretty neat.The other problem is that the multiplayer, like other voxel games, is hosted by players.  There's no matching queue for formal PvP.  There's "tournaments" but what this entails is putting a bunch of designs on a map and turning on their AI.  It's hard to call this PvP when it's effectively the same thing as hitting Autocalc in a Total War game.  The developers have been busy adding excellent and much-needed content, so it's not like I expect that they'll crank out a MOBA-style multiplayer mode in the next month or two, but it feels like the game is missing PVP (aside from the kind that will get you kicked out of a player-hosted server).  But I guess that's something that I can look forward to.If you like mining, you might not like this game.If you like Starmade, Robocraft, Space Engineers, World of Warships, or just blowing things up with a cannon, you'll like this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Have you ever dreamed of a game that is a mix of minecraft, total war, FPS action, with some pirateering thrown in for good measure? If so, this game is for you. In From the Depths, build a ship (or fleet of ships) in order to wipe out the opposing factions. You do this by capturing resource zones where you can drill for resources to build bigger better ships. This simple goal leads to a very open experiance. The map/planet of Nieter alone has about seven or so factions to interact with through a simple to understand diplomacy panel, a massive amount of space to conquer, with some islands sprinkled in to use however you like. That's not even mentioning the built in planet builder, where you get to create a whole new experiance, or the planets that the developer is probably planning to patch in. The planet itself is not whats interesting however. Its the ship building. You have a very wide range of blocks, each with different functions to build your fleet with. You can build everything from massive steel battleships, to wooden sail based gallions, to riverboat paddlesteamers. If you find that you dont like building ships, you can board and take over the enemy ships. You could say "Screw sailing" and build an airship if you so choose. You can costomize every aspect of your ship, even the guns/lazers/kim jong un approved missiles it carries. I definitely think that this game is worth the money. FAIR WARNING: This game is fairly difficult to learn. Be prepared to do some resarch/ watch some youtube videos.
